Description: 05/11/1998: Following the arrest of eight suspects related to a string of similar attacks, a motorcycle was set ablaze near the Lan Heung Hok restaurant in Macau, China. There were no casualties reported. The attack was believed to have been perpetrated by the 14 K Triad.
Sources: Harald Bruning, “Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,” Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.
“Eight Arrested in Macao Following Molotov Cocktail Attacks,” Lisbon RTP International Television in Portuguese, May 12, 1998.
Harald Bruning, “Police Raid 'Firebomb Factory' Amid Arson Attacks,” Hong Kong Standard, May 12, 1998.

Description: 05/11/1998: One hour following a similar attack on a private vehicle, three cars and 15 motorcycles parked on Avenida de Venceslau de Morais in Macau, China were set ablaze. The attack was part of a wave of similar attacks, believed to have been perpetrated by the 14 K Triad.
SpecificDescription1: Vehicles and Motorcycles in Macau, China
Sources: Harald Bruning, “Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,” Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.
“Eight Arrested in Macao Following Molotov Cocktail Attacks,” Lisbon RTP International Television in Portuguese, May 12, 1998.
Harald Bruning, “Police Raid 'Firebomb Factory' Amid Arson Attacks,” Hong Kong Standard, May 12, 1998.

Description: 05/11/1998: A private car was set ablaze on Avenida de Horta e Costa about 3:30 am in Macau, China. The blaze, which was quickly extinguished by firemen, caused no injuries. The attack was part of a wave of similar attacks, believed to have been perpetrated by the 14 K Triad.
Sources: Harald Bruning, “Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,” Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.
“Eight Arrested in Macao Following Molotov Cocktail Attacks,” Lisbon RTP International Television in Portuguese, May 12, 1998.
Harald Bruning, “Police Raid 'Firebomb Factory' Amid Arson Attacks,” Hong Kong Standard, May 12, 1998.

Description: 05/08/1998: A number of Molotov cocktails were thrown at a number of vehicles and motorcycles in Macau, China. The attacks, which occurred within a two-hour period, damaged 14 vehicles and 8 motorcycles, but caused no injuries. Two shops were also affected by the fire but suffered only minor damage. The group 14 K Triad was suspected in the attack.
SpecificDescription2: Vehicles and Motorcycles in Macau, China
Sources: Harald Bruning, “Macao Jittery After 22 Arson Attacks on Vehicles,” Hong Kong Standard, May 9, 1998.
“Further Fire Bomb Attacks in Macao,” Hong Kong RTHK Radio 4, May 8, 1998.
“Eight Arrested in Macao Following Molotov Cocktail Attacks,” Lisbon RTP International Television in Portuguese, May 12, 1998.

Description: 07/09/2008: On Wednesday evening through 07/11/2008 on Friday, in Tripoli, Liban-Nord, Lebanon, armed rival political factions engaged in armed and rocket attacks, killing five civilians and political affiliates and wounding over 85 civilians and political affiliates.  No group claimed responsibility, but it was believed that the 14 March Coalition and the 8 March Coalition were responsible.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in Tripoli, Northern Province (Ech Chimal), Lebanon.
SpecificDescription1: Assailants targeted gunmen from rival groups.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms and rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: National Counterterrorism Center, "Five Civilians and Political Affiliates Killed, Approximately Eighty-Five Civilians Wounded and Political Affiliates Wounded in Armed Attacks in Tripoli, Liban-Nord, Lebanon," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System (January 21, 2010).

National Counterterrorism Center, "Five Civilians and Political Affiliates Killed, Approximately Eighty-Five Civilians Wounded and Political Affiliates Wounded in Armed Attacks in Tripoli, Liban-Nord, Lebanon," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System (January 21, 2010).
BBC Monitoring Middle East, "Three Lebanese Killed in Tripoli Clashes," LexisNexis Academic, BBC Monitoring Middle East, July 09, 2008.

Description: 11/01/2004: The offices of three pan-Arab satellite television stations, one of which belonged to al-Arabiya, were destroyed by a car bomb explosion in Baghdad, Iraq. Al-Jazeera, whose office was not one of the three targeted, reported that a militant group calling itself the Brigades of the 1920 Revolution claimed responsibility on the Internet for the attack. Al-Arabiya, however, reported later that the Brigades had denied responsibility.
Sources: Charles Clover, Steve Negus and Dhiya Rasan, “Arab Media Under Pressure After Iraq Bomb,” Financial Times, November 01, 2004.

Description: 10/30/2004: Seven people were killed and 19 wounded when a suicide car bomb exploded outside the Baghdad offices of the Al-Arabiya satellite Arabic television station. A group calling itself Brigades of the 1920 Revolution claimed responsibility in a statement posted on an Islamist website, whose authenticity could not be confirmed. Shortly afterwards, another unknown group called the Jihad Martyr's Companies in Iraq claimed responsibility in a competing claim.
WeaponDetails: Suicide car bomb.
Sources: "Seven dead in car bomb attack outside Al-Arabiya Baghdad office," Agence France-Presse, October 30, 2004.
Robert H. Reid, "Iraq prime minister warns time running out for peaceful settlement in Fallujah; blast kills 15 in Tikrit," The Associated Press, October 31, 2004.
"Multiple acts of violence throughout Iraq," NBC Nightly News, October 30, 2004.

Description: 01/22/2009: On Thursday, unknown gunmen have abducted four foreign nationals from an unknown location in Mali.  According to reports, the group was returning from a culture festival in northern Mali when their convoy was ambushed and their vehicle was cut off from the others in the group. A Swiss couple, a German, and a British national occupied the vehicle.  Authorities believe the attack to be the work of Tuareg rebels, operating in the area.
LocationDetails: Attack occurred at an unknown location in the Saharan region of Mali, near the border with Niger.
SpecificDescription1: The target was a Swiss couple.
WeaponDetails: It is unknown if weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: United Press International, "No Trace of Tourists Kidnapped in Mali," www.upi.com (January 26, 2009).
Agence France Presse, "Qaeda Link Seen in Europeans' Kidnapping: Mali Official," Agence France Presse, January 28, 2009.
National Counterterrorism Center, "One Civilian Wounded in Assault, Four Others Kidnapped in Hijacking and Armed Attack by AQIM in Niger," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, December 2, 2009.

Description: 01/07/2009: On Wednesday, near the Adrar des Ifoghas mountains in Kidal, Mali, assailants kidnapped the head of Energy of Mali (EDM) Kidal and an EDM accountant, two civilians and one child and stole the vehicle they were using. The two civilians and the child were immediately released. On January 12, 2009, the remaining victims were released by their captors. No group claimed responsibility, although it was widely believed that Tuaregs were responsible.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at Adrar des Ifoghas Mountains
WeaponDetails: It is unknown if weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Agence France Presse, "Tuareg Rebels Release Two Hostages in Mali," LexisNexis Academic, Agence France Presse, January 12, 2009.
National Counterterrorism Center, "Two Government Employees, Two Civilians, One Child Kidnapped by Suspected Tuaregs in Kidal, Mali," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, December 2, 2009.

Description: 01/07/2009: On Wednesday, unknown insurgents kidnapped a Somali parliamentarian, named Ahmed Abdi Hussein, in the town of Burhakaba in the southern part of Somalia. The lawmaker was taken from a truck heading from the town of Baidoa to the town of Burhakaba. No group claimed responsibility, although it was widely believed that Tuareg rebels were responsible.
WeaponDetails: It is unknown if weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Press TV, "Lawmaker Abducted in Southern Somalia," http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=81099&sectionid=351020501 (January 7, 2009).
Africa News, "Insurgents Abduct MP," LexisNexis Academic, Africa News, January 7, 2009.
Shabelle Media Network, "Somalia; Insurgents Abduct MP," LexisNexis Academic, Shabelle Media Network (January 7, 2009).

Description: 02/13/2010: On Saturday evening at about 1915, a bomb blast ripped through the city's popular German Bakery, close to the Osho Ashram and across from the Jewish Chabad House. More than forty five people have been rushed to the hospital with varying degrees of injury such as burns and fractures. There was an unattended packet which exploded when a waiter tried to open it. The blast left a 6ft x 4ft hole in the wall. It appears a battery operated improvised explosive device was used. Two more deaths brought the death toll up to thirteen. A Reliance Group employee and a Sudanese footballer died on 02/20/2010. Vikas Tulsiyani died on 02/21/2010 and a college student, Rajeev Agarwal died on 02/20/2010 which brought the death toll up to fifteen. Final count is seventeen dead, 49 wounded. The Students Islamic Movement of India (SIMI) and the Indian Mujahideen claimed responsibility for the attack. The 313 Brigade, an operational arm of Al Qaeda, did not specifically claim responsibility for the attack, but a statement from top guerrilla commander Ilyas Kashmiri implies their involvement.
LocationDetails: The blast happened in a German Bakery near the Osho Ashram across from the Jewish Chabad House.
SpecificDescription1: The bomb exploded in a German bakery after a waiter opened an abandoned package, however, it is unknown if this was the intended target.
WeaponDetails: A battery operated improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: Indo-Asian News Service, "India: Police Say SIMI, Indian Mujahidin 'Claimed Responsibility' for Pune Blast," World News Connection, Indo-Asian News Service, February 24, 2010.
Syed Saleem Shahzad, "Al-Qaeda Chief Delivers a Warning," Asia Times Online, February 15, 2010.
National Counterterrorism Center, "Seventeen Civilians Killed, Forty-Nine Others Wounded in IED Attack in Pune, Maharashtra, India," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, July 8, 2010.

Description: 07/09/2013: An explosives-laden vehicle detonated at a supermarket parking lot in the Dahiyeh suburb of Beirut city, Mount Lebanon governorate, Lebanon. Fifty-three people were wounded in the attack. The 313 Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident, stating the Hezbollah-controlled area was targeted for their support of Syrian troops in the Syrian Civil War.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Bir el-Abed area of the Dahieh suburb.
WeaponDetails: A parked car bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "Behind the lines: A gaping Lebanese crater," Jerusalem Post, July 11, 2013.
"Explosion rocks Shia suburb in Beirut," Al Jazeera, July 9, 2013.
"Massive Beirut explosion rocks Hezbollah stronghold," Business Mirror, July 10, 2013.

Description: 06/28/2013: A roadside bomb detonated in Zahle town, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. This was one of two explosions that targeted a Hezbollah convoy in Zahle on this day. There were no reported casualties and minimal damages resulting from the blasts. The 313 Brigade (Syria) claimed responsibility for the attack.
WeaponDetails: A roadside, 90-mm anti-tank projectile was used in the attack.
Sources: "Bombs hit Hezbollah convoy in east Lebanon," Agence France Presse -- English, June 28, 2013.
"Unknown Syrian rebel group claims responsibility for Beirut bombing," Europe Online Magazine, July 10, 2013.
"Twin blasts on east Lebanon highway, no casualties," Lebanon Daily Star, June 28, 2013.

"Two bombs explode in Bekaa Valley, miss Hezbollah convoy," The Daily Star Online, June 28, 2013.

Description: 02/12/2016: Assailants abducted three traders in Emangre village, Meghalaya, India. The traders were rescued on February 16, 2016. The A'chik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF) claimed responsibility for the incident.
SpecificDescription1: Traders: Soleman Ali, Monid Zamal, Abu Samad
Sources: "Three Assam residents rescued in Garo Hills," Assam Tribune, February 17, 2016.
"India: Suspected Garo Militants Kidnap Assam-Based Businessman in Meghalaya," The Shillong Times Online, February 17, 2016.

Description: 11/17/2015: Assailants abducted Soleman Ali and Sahauddin Sheikh, two construction workers, from Silki village, Meghalaya state, India. The hostages were released on November 25, 2015. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected the involvement of both the Achik National Liberation Army (ANLA) and the Achik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF).
SpecificDescription1: Construction Workers: Soleman Ali, Sahauddin Sheikh
Sources: "2 abducted workers released," Assam Tribune, November 25, 2015.

Description: 09/28/2015: Assailants stopped a passenger bus and abducted nine people in Wageasi, Meghalaya state, India. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected that the attack was carried out by Achik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF).
Sources: "AMEF hand suspected in abduction of non-Garos," Assam Tribune, September 30, 2015.
"Engineer, passengers abducted," Calcutta Telegraph, September 30, 2015.

Description: 08/07/2015: Assailants attempted to extort money from a fuel supplier in Meghalaya state, India. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, police officials arrested two individuals in connection with the attack and identified one of them as an Achik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF) member.
Sources: "GNLA militants ambush Police convoy in Meghalaya," South Asian Terrorism Portal, August 10, 2015.

Description: 08/07/2015: Assailants extorted money from a tea company in Meghalaya state, India. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, police officials arrested two individuals in connection with the attack and identified one of them as an Achik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF) member.
Sources: "GNLA militants ambush Police convoy in Meghalaya," South Asian Terrorism Portal, August 10, 2015.

Description: 06/18/2015: Assailants threw explosive devices at a factory in Damas village, Meghalaya state, India. No casualties were reported. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Achik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF).
WeaponDetails: Two crude bombs were used in the attack.
Sources: "Ultras attack Meghalaya cement factory," Assam Tribune, June 18, 2015.
"Bombs hurled in Meghalaya cement factory," Chandigarh Tribune, June 18, 2015.
"6/19/2015: Nation: Bombs hurled at Meghalaya cement factory," Hindustan Times, June 18, 2015.

Description: 05/31/2015: Assailants threw an explosive device and opened fire at a transport weigh bridge in Sarangma village, Meghalaya state, India. At least 4-5 people, including a Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) Assistant Sub-Inspector (ASI), were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, police officials suspected that the Achik National Cooperative Army (ANCA) was behind the attack.
WeaponDetails: A thrown crude bomb and firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: "Militants fire in Meghalaya, 4 injured," The Echo Of India, June 1, 2015.
"4 injured in grenade attack in Meghalaya," Chandigarh Tribune, May 31, 2015.
"Militant attack in Garo Hills, 4 injured," Assam Tribune, May 31, 2015.

Description: 03/02/2015: Assailants threw an explosive device at an Indian Oil Corporation Limited petrol pump in Shillong city, Meghalaya state, India. Two workers were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected that either the Achik Matgrik Elite Force (AMEF) or the Garo National Liberation Army were involved.
WeaponDetails: A crude bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "GNLA refutes police claims on crude   bomb attack," Assam Tribune (India), March 3, 2015.
"Militants   attack petrol pump at Shallang, injure two," Meghalaya Times (India), March 2, 2015.
"2 injured in Meghalaya   bomb attack," Assam Tribune (India), March 2, 2015.

Description: 04/07/2017: Assailants opened fire on Ashfaq Ahmed in Sabzazar neighborhood, Lahore, Punjab, Pakistan. Ahmed, a retired University of Veterinary Sciences professor and Ahmadi civilian, was killed in the assault. Al-Alami faction of Lashkar-e-Jhangvi and the Jamaat-ul-Ahrar faction of Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) separately claimed responsibility for the attack. Sources also attributed the incident to Aalmi Majlis-i-Tahfuz-i-Khatam-i-Nubuwaat.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Sabzazar neighborhood.
Sources: "Pakistan: Four Arrested in Murder Case of Ahmedi Professor in Lahore," Dawn Online, May 21, 2017.
"Ahmadi professor murdered in Pakistan, third killing since last month," Hindustan Times, April 19, 2017.
"Another Member of Minority Religious Sect Slain in Pakistan," VOA News, April 19, 2017.

Description: 10/02/2013: A roadside bomb detonated near a Royal Thai Armed Forces teacher escort unit in Sa-ae village, Yala province, Thailand. At least four soldiers were killed and three civilians were wounded in the blast. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Aba Cheali Group.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Kadudo village in Krong Pinang district.
SpecificDescription2: Yala Task Force 13: Teacher Escort Unit
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "Thailand: Two soldiers killed in bomb attack in Yala Wednesday," The Nation Online, October 2, 2013.
"Yala bombing kills 4, injures 3," Bangkok Post, October 2, 2013.
"Thailand: Four soldiers killed in   bomb blast   in Yala," Thai News Service, October 4, 2013.

Description: 02/21/2020: Assailants opened fire on Solomon Tadesse, the Burayu police chief, in Burayu, Oromia, Ethiopia. Tadesse was killed and three people, including another police commander, were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Oromo Liberation Front and the Abu Torbe group.
Sources: "6 Ethiopians arrested for suspected involvement in grenade attack," Xinhua General News Service, February 24, 2020.
"Oromia Police Blames Rebel Forces for Recent Attack in Burayu Town," Ezega.com, February 23, 2020.
"Ethiopia: At least 29 people reportedly wounded in a grenade attack in Ambo town," Borkena.com, February 23, 2020.

Description: 04/03/2016: Assailants abducted Mohammed Mhaisen in Tripoli city, Libya. Mhaisen, a journalist, was wounded while detained, and released the next day on April 4th, 2016. The Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also attributed the attack to the Abdul Ghani Kikli Militia.
WeaponDetails: A dog was used in the attack.
Sources: "Hosted Product: Libya Daily Digest April 6, 2016," Libya Digest, April 6, 2016.
"Release of Misratan reporter kidnapped on way to see Serraj: report," Libya News Today, April 4, 2016.

Description: 04/20/2015: Assailants kidnapped Abdulrauf Al-Zaidi in Drebi neighborhood, Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. Al-Zaidi, a social media activist critical of Libya Dawn, was killed and his body was returned to his family on April 30, 2015. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abdul Ghani Kikli militia.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Drebi neighborhood of the city
Sources: "Hosted Product: Libya Review Security Arab May 5, 2016," Libya Digest, May 5, 2016.
"Libya security digest May 4, 2015," Libya Digest, May 4, 2015.

Description: 05/15/2013: Two rockets struck near an observatory on Mount Hermon in Quneitra district, Quneitra governorate, Syria. There were no reported injuries or damages. The Abdul Qader Husseini Battalions of the Free Palestine movement claimed responsibility for the incident, stating that the attack was meant to commemorate the anniversary of Israeli statehood (May 15, 1948).
LocationDetails: Incident occurred in the demilitarized zone in eastern Golan Heights
WeaponDetails: Two rockets were used in the attack.
GroupName: Abdul Qader Husseini Battalions of the Free Palestine movement
Sources: "Palestinian group says it fired rockets on Mount Hermon," JTA, May 16, 2013.
"Israeli military Syrian rockets hit Golan Heights," Philippine Times, May 15, 2013.

Description: 09/18/2015: Assailants fired a rocket into Sderot town, Southern district, Israel. There were no reported casualties, although a bus and house were damaged in the blast. The Sheikh Omar Hadid Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades also claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for events taking place at Al-Aqsa mosque.
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the attack.
Sources: "Rocket siren heard in Ashkelon," Jerusalem Post, September 18, 2015.
"Rockets fired from Gaza land in southern Israel," JTA, September 20, 2015.
"Gaza rocket hits parked bus in Israel town: police," Agence France-Presse Top News (English), t, September 18, 2015.

Description: 07/09/2014: Assailants fired rockets at Eshkol Regional Council, Southern district, Israel. There were no reports of casualties in the attacks, but three houses were damaged. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: Rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "Ashdod gas station suffers direct hit," Ynet News, July 11, 2014.
"Middle East-North Africa: Situation Update 10 July 2014," OSC Summary, July 10, 2014.
"IDF Reportedly Kills Two Terrorists Trying to Infiltrate Israeli Kibbutz, Continues Gaza Strikes," OSC Summary, July 9, 2014.

Description: 07/09/2014: Assailants fired a rocket targeting Negev Nuclear Research Center in Dimona city, Southern district, Israel. The rocket was intercepted by the Iron Dome without incident. The Ezzedine al-Qassam Brigades of Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) claimed responsibility for the attack.
WeaponDetails: Rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "Gaza militants launch rockets towards Israel's Dimona nuclear site," Reuters, July 9, 2014.
"Hamas fires at Dimona nuclear reactor; Iron Dome," Ynet News, July 10, 2014.
"Middle East-North Africa: Situation Update 10 July 2014," OSC Summary, July 10, 2014.

Description: 04/18/2014: Assailants launched mortars and opened fire on a Frontier Corps (FC) ammunition depot in Landi Kotal town, Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan. One person was wounded and the ammunition depot was damaged in the attack. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: Rockets, mortars, and firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: "Pakistan: Army ammunition depot in Landikotal gutted," The News Online, April 19, 2014.
"Pakistan: Soldier killed in Peshawar; army depot destroyed in Landi Kotal," Dawn Online, April 19, 2014.
"Series of explosions at FC fort in Landi Kotal; no casualties," DAWN Group, April 18, 2014.

Description: 02/22/2014: A suicide bomber driving an explosives-laden vehicle detonated at a Lebanese Army checkpoint on Al-Assi Bridge at the entrance to Hermel city, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. In addition to the bomber, three people, including one civilian, were killed and at least 15 people, including several civilians, were injured. Both the Al Nusra Front in Lebanon, as sub-group of Al Nusra Front, and the Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was in response to Hezbollah involvement in Syria.
WeaponDetails: An explosives- laden vehicle packed with 125 kg of explosives
Sources: "Al-Qaida group claims Lebanese army suicide attack," Associated Press International, February 23, 2014.
"Army picks up the pieces after deadly bomb," Lebanon Daily Star, February 23, 2014.
"Lebanon's army target of "terrorist attacks": president," Xinhua News Agency, February 23, 2014.

Description: 02/19/2014: A suicide bomber in an explosive-laden vehicle detonated at the Iranian Cultural Center in Bir Hassan, Mount Lebanon, Lebanon. This was one of two nearly simultaneous attacks targeting the cultural center. At least 11 people, besides the assailants, were killed and at least 128 people were injured across both attacks. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation to Hezbollah and Iran's involvement in the Syrian conflict. The group also demanded that their members be released from Lebanese prisons.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Bir Hassan neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: An explosive-packed vehicle was used in the attack.
Sources: "Beirut bombings toll rises to 11: official news agency," Agence France Presse -- English, February 21, 2014.
"Ethiopian worker's death raises Beirut bombing toll," The Daily Star (Lebanon), February 21, 2014.
"EU to support Lebanon, after explosions in Beirut," New Europe, February 20, 2014.

Description: 02/19/2014: A suicide bomber in an explosive-laden vehicle detonated at the Iranian Cultural Center in Bir Hassan, Mount Lebanon, Lebanon. This was one of two nearly simultaneous attacks targeting the cultural center. At least 11 people, besides the assailants, were killed and at least 128 people were injured across both attacks. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation to Hezbollah and Iran's involvement in the Syrian conflict. "Ethiopian worker's death raises Beirut bombing toll," The Daily Star (Lebanon), February 21, 2014.

Description: 02/12/2014: An explosives-laden vehicle was found and defused in Arsal city, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A car bomb loaded with 50 kg of explosives was used in the attack.
Sources: "Lebanon arrests top al-Qaeda linked fighter," Nigerian Tribune, February 13, 2014.
"Lebanon arrests Al Qaeda-linked militant behind car bomb blasts," Oman Tribune, February 13, 2014.
"Lebanon army arrests jihadist chief, defuses car bombs," Focus Bulgaria, February 12, 2014.

Description: 02/12/2014: An explosives-laden vehicle was found and defused in Corniche Al-Mazraa neighborhood, Beirut city, Beirut governorate, Lebanon. Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Corniche al-Mazraa neighborhood
WeaponDetails: A car bomb loaded with 100 kg or explosives, multiple explosive belts, and mortar shells was used in the attack.
Sources: "Lebanon arrests Al Qaeda-linked militant behind car bomb blasts," Oman Tribune, February 13, 2014.
"Lebanon arrests militant leader, defuses car-bomb," Turkish Press, February 12, 2014.
"Lebanon army arrests jihadist chief, defuses car bombs," Focus Bulgaria, February 12, 2014.

Description: 01/25/2014: Assailants fired three mortars into Masharia Al-Qaa near Hermel city, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. No casualties were reported. Al-Nusrah Front in Lebanon claimed responsibility for the incident and warned that similar attacks would continue until Hezbollah halted its intervention in Syria's civil war and Sunni prisoners were released in Lebanon. The Marwan Al-Hadid Brigades also claimed responsibility for this attack.
LocationDetails: Incident occurred in the Masharia Al Qaa area
WeaponDetails: Mortars were used in the attack.
Sources: "Lebanon Sunnis refuse to join Hizbollah-Al Qaeda war — Hariri," Jordan Times, January 25, 2014.

Description: 01/25/2014: Assailants fired rockets from Syria into Hermel town, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. No casualties were reported. Al-Nusrah Front in Lebanon claimed responsibility for the incident, stating that attacks would continue until Hezbollah left Syria and Sunni youths in Lebanese prisons were released. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades also claimed responsibility for the attack.
WeaponDetails: Five rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "Militant group claims Hermel rocket attack," The Daily Star Online, January 27, 2014.
"Militant group claims Hermel rocket attack," Lebanon Daily Star, January 26, 2014.
"Five rockets from Syria hit Lebanon's Hermel," Lebanon Daily Star, January 25, 2014.

Description: 01/16/2014: An explosive device detonated at a Khasadar Forces checkpost in the Sadokhel area of Landi Kotal tehsil, Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan. At least one Khasadar member was killed and another was injured as a result of the blast. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Sadokhel area of the city.
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "Khasadar killed in Landi Kotal blast," DAWN Group, January 17, 2014.
"Bomb   blast   kills Khasadar personnel in Landi Kotal," The Nation (AsiaNet), January 17, 2014.
"Khassadar sepoy killed in Landikotal   bomb blast," Daily The Pak Banker, January 17, 2014.

Description: 12/17/2013: Assailants fired rockets at a residential area in Hermel town, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. At least one person was injured as a result. This was one of two rocket attacks on Hermel on this day. Both Al-Nusrah Front in Lebanon and the Marwan Hadid Brigades claimed responsibility for the attack. The Marwan Hadid Brigades stated the attack was retribution for Hezbollah's involvement in Syria and the continued killing and detention of Sunni youths in Lebanon.
WeaponDetails: Rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "Xinhua: Rockets Fired From Syria Hit Lebanon's Bekaa, 4 Injured," Xinhua, December 17, 2013.
"Syria rockets wound two soldiers in Lebanon's Hermel," Lebanon Daily Star, December 17, 2013.

Description: 12/17/2013: Assailants fired rockets at a Lebanese Army barracks in Hermel town, Beqaa governorate, Lebanon. At least two people were injured as a result. This was one of two rocket attacks on Hermel on this day. Both Al-Nusrah Front and the Marwan Hadid Brigades claimed responsibility for the attack. The Marwan Hadid Brigades stated the attack was retribution for Hezbollah's involvement in Syria and the continued killing and detention of Sunni youths in Lebanon.
WeaponDetails: Rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "Xinhua: Rockets Fired From Syria Hit Lebanon's Bekaa, 4 Injured," Xinhua, December 17, 2013.
"Syria rockets wound two soldiers in Lebanon's Hermel," Lebanon Daily Star, December 17, 2013.
"Rockets fired on Lebanon barrack from Syria," World Bulletin, December 17, 2013.

Description: 11/19/2013: An suicide bomber in an explosives-laden vehicle detonated outside of the Iranian embassy in Bir Hassan, Mount Lebanon, Lebanon. This was one of two explosions outside the Iranian Embassy on this day; this second attack targeted responders to an earlier bombing. In addition to the two bombers, at least 26 people were killed, including an Iranian cultural attache, and 151 people were injured across both blasts. Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incidents, stating that there would be more attacks unless Iran ceased operations in Syria.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Iranian Embassy.
WeaponDetails: An explosives- laden vehicle was detonated by its driver in the attack.
Sources: "Explosions target Iran embassy in Beirut," Al Jazeera, November 19, 2013.
"Two blasts near Iranian embassy in Beirut," Reuters, November 19, 2013.
"Iran lauds Lebanon in dealing with terror attack," Xinhua News Agency, November 29, 2013.

Description: 11/19/2013: A suicide bomber detonated outside of the Iranian embassy in Beirut city, Mount Lebanon governorate, Lebanon. This was one of two explosions outside the Iranian Embassy on this day; this first attack was intended to draw a crowd. In addition to the two bombers, at least 26 people were killed, including an Iranian cultural attache, and 151 people were injured across both blasts. Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incidents, stating that there would be more attacks unless Iran ceased operations in Syria.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Iranian Embassy.
WeaponDetails: An explosive belt was used in the attack.
Sources: "Explosions target Iran embassy in Beirut," Al Jazeera, November 19, 2013.
"Two blasts near Iranian embassy in Beirut," Reuters, November 19, 2013.
"Iran lauds Lebanon in dealing with terror attack," Xinhua News Agency, November 29, 2013.

Description: 08/22/2013: Assailants fired a rocket from Lebanon into Acre, Northern, Israel. The rocket was intercepted by the Iron Dome defense system between Acre city and Nahariya city in North district, Israel. There were no reported casualties in the attack. This was one of three rockets fired from Lebanon at Northern district on this day. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades group claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the attack.
Sources: "Israel: Rockets Fired from Lebanon Breach Iron Dome Defence System," International Business Times India, August 22, 2013.
"Al Qaeda Lebanon Branch Claimed Rocket Attack on Israel," The Guardian Express, August 23, 2013.
"4 Rockets Fired from Tyre Area at Israel, Army Finds Launch Pads — Naharnet," Naharnet, August 22, 2013.

Description: 08/22/2013: Assailants fired a rocket into Nahariya, Northern, Israel. There were no reported casualties in the attack. This was one of three rockets fired from Lebanon at Northern district on this day. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades group claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the attack.
Sources: "Rockets from Lebanon hit northern Israel, no casualties," Reuters, August 22, 2013.
"Blasts heard in northern Israel," BBC, August 22, 2013.
"Rockets from Lebanon hit northern Israel," Abu Dhabi National, August 22, 2013.

Description: 08/22/2013: Assailants fired a rocket into Nahariya, Northern, Israel. There were no reported casualties in the attack. This was one of three rockets fired from Lebanon at Northern district on this day. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades group claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the attack.
Sources: "Rockets from Lebanon hit northern Israel, no casualties," Reuters, August 22, 2013.

Description: 07/16/2013: A roadside bomb detonated in front of a Hezbollah convoy near Majdal Anjar, Beqaa, Lebanon. One person was killed and at least three people were injured in the blast. The Abdullah Azzam Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident, stating they carried out the attack due to the group's intervention in Syria.
WeaponDetails: A remote-triggered roadside bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "Suspect arrested over attack on Hezbollah convoy," Lebanon Daily Star, July 23, 2013.
"Four Hezbollah members wounded in east Lebanon ambush," Lebanon Daily Star, July 16, 2013.
"Roadside bomb explodes on highway linking Beirut to Damascus, 2 wounded," Xinhua News Agency, July 16, 2013.

Description: 08/07/2020: Assailants attacked Mohamed Salem al-Kholani, the Taizz Military Police commander in Jabal Habashy district, Taizz, Yemen. Kholani was not harmed but three of his bodyguards were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
SpecificDescription1: Military Police Commander: Mohamed Salem al-Kholani
Sources: "Yemeni military leader survives attempted assassination in Taiz," Debriefer.net, August 8, 2020.

Description: 05/08/2019: Assailants shot and killed Muhammad Sultan Naji, a civilian, in Birayn, Taizz, Yemen. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
Sources: "Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 8 May 2019," Summary, May 7, 2019.

Description: 04/25/2019: Assailants opened fire on Security forces in Jumhuri, Taizz, Yemen. A civilian was killed and eight civilians were injured in the ensuing clashes. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Jumhuri area.
WeaponDetails: Sniper rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Violent clashes in Taiz after Abu Abbas brigades attack members of the security campaign in the Old City," Almasdar Online, April 25, 2019.
"Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 26 April 2019," Summary, April 25, 2019.

Description: 04/20/2019: A sniper shot and killed a civilian, 'Aliyah al-Hayzami, in Taizz, Yemen. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
WeaponDetails: Sniper rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Taiz.. Intensifying of clashes between "Abu Abbas" brigades and security campaign to arrest wanted security forces in Wadi al-Madam," Almasdar Online, April 21, 2019.
"Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 20 April 2019," Summary, April 19, 2019.

Description: 04/19/2019: Assailants opened fire on a police patrol in Al-Jomhouri, Taizz, Yemen. A senior security officer was killed and an unknown number of officers were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Wadi al-Madam area.
WeaponDetails: Sniper rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Gunmen assassinate Deputy security and order officer at Taiz Police Department," Almasdar Online, April 20, 2019.
"Unknown gunmen ambush security patrol in Yemen's Taiz, officer killed," Xinhua General News Service, April 20, 2019.
"Two people killed, others wounded amid assassination of officer south of Taiz," Yemen News, April 20, 2019.

Description: 01/19/2019: Assailants abducted soldier 'Ammar Naji al-'Arshani at the Al Birayn Checkpoint in Maafer, Taizz, Yemen. Al-Arshani was killed and his body returned to his family on January 25, 2019. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
Sources: "Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 31 January 2019," Summary, January 30, 2019.

Description: 09/01/2018: Assailants opened fire on patrol and road security forces soldiers at the Taj Shamsan Hotel in Taizz, Yemen. At least two soldiers were killed and three soldiers were injured in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Mudhaffar area of the city.
Sources: "Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 2 September 2018," Summary, September 1, 2018.

Description: 08/12/2018: Assailants attacked military police forces guarding the Al Thawrah hospital in Taizz city, Taizz, Yemen. An unknown number of assailants and four soldiers were killed and 10 soldiers and an unknown number of assailants were injured in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
Sources: "Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 13 August 2018," Summary, August 12, 2018.

Description: 04/26/2018: Assailants shelled residential areas in Mount Sabr district, Taizz, Yemen. At least one civilian was killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Abu Abbas Brigade.
Sources: "Yemen: Open Source Terrorism Roundup 27 April 2018," Summary, April 26, 2018.

Description: 01/24/2017: Assailants detonated explosives targeting the Political Security Organization (PSO) building in Taizz, Yemen. There were no reported casualties in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Abbas Brigade.
Sources: "Yemen: Security Roundup 2000 GMT 25 January 2017," Summary, January 25, 2017.
"Gulf of Aden Security Review - January 25, 2017," Critical Threats, January 25, 2017.

Description: 01/20/2019: An explosives-laden vehicle detonated near a Military Intelligence Directorate office in Al-Mutahelek al-Junoubi neighborhood, Damascus, Syria. There were an unknown number of casualties in the blast. A second explosives-laden vehicle was discovered and defused in the area. The Abu Amarah Battalion claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Al-Mutahelek al-Junoubi neighborhood.
Sources: "Explosion heard in Syrian capital Damascus," Xinhua News Agency, January 20, 2019.
"Bomb explodes on southern edge of Damascus; separate bombing kills three in Afrin," Haaretz, January 20, 2019.
"'Huge' Blast Hits Damascus Near Security Facility," Radio Free Europe, January 20, 2019.

Description: 08/04/2018: An explosive device planted in the vehicle of Aziz Asber detonated in Masyaf, Hamah, Syria. Asber, the Syrian Scientific Research Centre facility director in charge of the regime chemical weapons program, and his driver were killed in the blast. The Abu Amarah Battalion claimed responsibility for the attack.
SpecificDescription1: Vehicle of Facility Director: Aziz Asber
Sources: "Syria blames Israel for assassination of top scientist," Jerusalem Post, August 6, 2018.
"Senior Syrian scientist killed in blast," BBC, August 5, 2018.
"Car bomb kills prominent rocket scientist in Syria," UPI, August 7, 2018.

Description: 01/10/2018: An explosive device detonated at a Syrian Army weapons depot in Slinfah, Lattakia, Syria. At least three soldiers were killed in the blast. The Abu Amarah Battalion claimed responsibility for the attack.

Description: 11/26/2014: Assailants launched rocket-propelled grenades at the private residence of Imhemed Shoaib in Zawiya, Libya. Description: 08/19/2014: Assailants launched rockets and mortar shells that landed and detonated near Toiba town, Zawiya district, Libya. There were no reported casualties in the blasts. This was one of four coordinated attacks in Zawiya district on the same day. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incidents to the Abu Obaida bin Jarrah Brigade.
WeaponDetails: Mortars and rockets were used in the attack.

Description: 08/19/2014: Assailants launched rockets and mortar shells that landed in Kerkozh area near Zaqiya city, Zawiya district, Libya. There were no reported casualties in the blasts. This was one of four coordinated attacks in Zawiya district on the same day. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incidents to the Abu Obaida bin Jarrah Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Kerkozh Toiba area to the east of the city.
Sources: "SOCAFRICA: Libya Incident Tracker: 16 – 22 August 2014," SOCAFRICA, August 16, 2014.

Description: 08/19/2014: Assailants launched rockets and mortar shells that landed and detonated in Al Hachan neighborhood, Zaqiya city, Zawiya district, Libya. There were no reported casualties in the blasts. This was one of four coordinated attacks in Zawiya district on the same day. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incidents to the Abu Obaida bin Jarrah Brigade.

WeaponDetails: Grad missiles and mortars were used in the attack.

Description: 08/19/2014: Assailants launched rockets and mortar shells that landed and detonated in Mayah city, Zawiya district, Libya. There were no reported casualties in the blasts. Description: 11/17/2015: Assailants abducted fifty-four people from an unknown number of road blocks in Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. The hostages were released in two groups of 27 a few hours apart from each other on November 18, 2015. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the abduction to the Abu Salim Martyr's Brigade.
Sources: "Libya: Clashes and mass kidnappings as confrontation looms between militias controlling Tripoli," International Business Times UK, November 19, 2015.

Description: 03/03/2015: Assailants abducted Khalifa Majid Harun 'Abd al-Salam and Munir Ali 'Abd al-Qadir near Derna city, Derna district, Libya. Al-Salam, a military colonel and Al-Qadir, a National Security Directorate (NSD) officer, were executed the same day. Barqa Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected that the Abu Salim Martyr's Brigade may have been involved in the attack.
SpecificDescription1: Husayn al-Juwayfi Battalion Colonel: Khalifa Majid Harun ‘Abd al-Salam
WeaponDetails: A pistol and an automatic weapon were used in the attack.

Three assailants were killed in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG).
WeaponDetails: Two .45-caliber pistols were used in the attack.
Sources: "Three ‘Abu Sayyaf bombers’ killed in encounter off Zamboanga City," CNN Philippines, November 25, 2020.
"3 suspected Abu Sayyaf members killed in Zamboanga," MSN Philippines, November 25, 2020.

Description: 10/30/2020: Security forces discovered and defused an explosive device planted near a road in Timbangan, Sulu, Philippines. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attempted attack to the Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG).
WeaponDetails: An explosive device constructed from a 90-mm recoilless rifle HEAT round, mixed with five liters of ammonium nitrate/fuel oil (ANFO), and connected to a blasting cap and a timer was used in the attack.

"Bombing plot foiled in Sulu," ABS-CBN News, October 30, 2020.

Description: 09/19/2020: Security forces discovered and defused an explosive device at the Jolo Pier in Walled City, Jolo, Sulu, Philippines. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected the involvement of the Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG)
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Walled City neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: An explosive device constructed from a rifle grenade, two electric blasting caps, a spark plug, and concrete nails was used in the attack.

The victims included soldiers, police, and civilians. The East Asia Division of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources also attributed the attack to the Abu Sayyaf Group (ASG).

This was one of three related attacks in the area on this date. At least 16 people, including two assailants, were killed and 78 people were injured across two of the attacks. The victims included soldiers, police, and civilians. The Achik Matgrik Army (AMA) claimed responsibility and stated that the shop was targeted for selling alcohol and cigarettes to underage individuals. At least two officers were killed and three others were wounded in the blast. Achik National Cooperative Army (ANCA) claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation to the authorities' alleged harassment of the families of ANCA members. Moreover, authorities suspected that the Garo National Liberation Army (GNLA) was behind the attack; however, the GNLA denied any involvement in the incident.
WeaponDetails: A remote-triggered roadside bomb was used in the attack.

Description: 07/27/2014: Assailants abducted a civilian in Mendipather area, Meghalaya state, India. The outcome of the abduction is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the abduction to the Achik National Cooperative Army (ANCA).
Sources: "Civilian abducted by ANCA militants in Meghalaya," South Asian Terrorism Portal, July 31, 2014.

Description: 01/15/2016: Assailants abducted seven traders near Wageasi, Meghalaya state, India. One hostage escaped and the remaining six victims were released on January 20, 2016. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected that the attack was carried out by the Achik National Liberation Army (ANLA).
SpecificDescription1: Traders: Tustu Paul, Manoranjan Sarkar, Putul Mukherjee

"Goalpara traders abducted, search on," Calcutta Telegraph, January 17, 2016.

Description: 02/03/2014: Assailants abducted the nephew of a former finance secretary of the Achik National Liberation Army (ANLA) in Wageasi area, North Garo Hills district, Meghalaya state, India. The victim, Meghnath R. Marakwas, was killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, the attack was attributed to the ANLA.
LocationDetails: The incident took place in North Garo Hills district.
Sources: "ANLA abducts,  kills two," Calcutta Telegraph, February 4, 2014.

Description: 02/01/2014: Assailants abducted a former finance secretary of the Achik National Liberation Army (ANLA) in Nongolpara area, North Garo Hills district, Meghalaya state, India. The former ANLA member, Ronald R. Marak, has not been found, although police suspect that he has been killed. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, police stated that the ANLA killed Marak as retribution for deserting the group.
LocationDetails: The incident took place in North Garo Hills district.
SpecificDescription1: Former Achik National Liberation Army (ANLA) Finance Sectretary: Ronald R. Marak
Sources: "ANLA abducts,  kills two," Calcutta Telegraph, February 4, 2014.

Description: 01/18/2014: Assailants opened fire on Chinmay Gotmare's vehicle between Jaksongram and Adugre villages, Meghalaya state, India. Gotmare, the South Garo Hills Deputy Commissioner, was unharmed. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspect that either the Garo National Liberation Army or the Achik National Volunteer Council (ANVC) was involved.
LocationDetails: The incident took place in South Garo Hills district.
SpecificDescription1: Vehicle of Deputy Commissioner: Chinmay Gotmare
Sources: "India: Meghalaya Official Escapes Attack by Militants on Highway," Salantini Janera, January 21, 2014.
"Garo Hills DC escapes militants' attack," Assam Tribune, January 18, 2014.

Description: 08/22/2011: On Monday evening at 2100, in Baija area of East Garo Hills, Meghalaya, India, Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) commandos were ambushed by a group of six suspected Garo National Liberation Army (GNLA) militants. The vehicle carrying the team was damaged in the attack. No casualties were reported and no group claimed responsibility. The GNLA denied its involvement in the attack and blamed instead its rival group the Achik National Volunteers Council (ANCV) claiming that they fired on the police vehicle suspecting the police to be GLNA militants.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in the Baija area of East Garo Hills district in Meghalaya, India.
SpecificDescription1: A vehicle transporting the Special Weapons and Tactics (SWAT) commandos
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: South Asia Terrorism Portal, “GNLA Attacks SWAT Team in Meghalaya," Shillong Times, http://satp.org/satporgtp/detailed_news.asp?date1=8/23/2011&id=7#7 (August 23, 2011).
Press Trust of India, “Encounter between Garo Rebels, Police in Meghalaya," LexisNexis Academic, Press Trust of India, August 23, 2011.
United News of India, " Militants Attack SWAT Convoy," LexisNexis Academic, United News of India, August 23, 2011.

Description: 08/13/2002: Separatists militants attacked a truck carrying civilians near Raksamgiri village, in India’s northeastern state of Meghalaya. They lined up passengers on the road and started shooting at them from a close range. 12 people died and 20 others were seriously wounded. This attack occurred one day before the Indian annual celebration of Indian Independence Day. The attack was reported to be a joint attack by militants of the Achik National Volunteer Council (ANVC), the United Liberation Front of Assam and the National Democratic Front of Bodoland (NDFB). They warned people not to take part in the celebrations.
LocationDetails: Near Raksamgiri village, 430 kilometers west of Meghalaya state's capital, Shillong
SpecificDescription1: Civilians in a truck in Meghalaya state
Sources: “Rebels kill 15 in northeast India,” Agence France Presse, August 13, 2002.
“Separatist guerrillas kill 15 people in India's remote northeast,” BC Cycle, August 13, 2002.

Description: 08/10/2001: Five policemen were killed and two were wounded in an ambush of a police jeep by Achik National Volunteer Council members near Songsak, Meghalaya State, India.
LocationDetails: This incident took place near Songsak.
SpecificDescription1: Police Patrol near Songsak, Meghalaya State, India
Sources: “Five policemen killed in ambush,” The Press Trust of India, August 10, 2001.
“Indian troops kill five tribal rebels in northeast India,” Agence France Presse, August 12, 2001.
“Tribal militants kill five paramilitary soldiers in northeast India,” Agence France Presse, August 10, 2001.

Description: 03/25/2015: An assailant attempted to extort money from a civilian in Ramdenggonggre village, West Garo Hills district, Meghalaya state, India. The assailant was apprehended by local residents during the extortion attempt and there were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources identified the assailant as Ramseng R. Sangma, a member of the Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B).

Description: 11/22/2014: Assailants abducted Anil Kumar Srivastava from his private residence in Rongara village, Meghalaya state, India. The outcome of the kidnapping of Srivastava, a National Buildings Construction Corporation (NBCC) engineer, is unknown. The Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B) claimed responsibility for the attack.
Sources: "NBCC engineer abducted by suspected ultras," Assam Tribune, November 24, 2014.

Description: 06/30/2014: Assailants kidnapped a teacher that worked at the Dalu Higher Secondary School in Dalu village, Meghalaya state, India. The hostage was rescued by police on July 1, 2014. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Achik Songna An'pachakgipa Kotok (ASAK). Officials, however, suspect that the Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B) was behind the incident.

Description: 04/01/2014: Assailants threw a grenade near a liquor store and bus station in Williamnagar town, East Garo Hills district, Meghalaya state, India. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, a police official attributed the attack to the Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B).

No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, police attributed the attack to the Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B).

Description: 02/03/2014: Assailants abducted two civilians in West Garo Hills, Meghalaya state, India. Both victims were shot and killed later that day by their captors. Description: 01/11/2014: Assailants threw an explosive device at an Assam Oil Corporation gas station in the Hawakhana neighborhood, Tura town, West Garo Hills district, Meghalaya state, India. There were no reported casualties; however, two vehicles were damaged by the blast. The Achik Tiger Force (ATF) claimed responsibility for the attack, stating that the bombing was intended to send a message to those paying taxes to other banned groups that they should pay taxes to the ATF as well. However, the police also blamed the Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B) for the incident.
LocationDetails: Incident occurred in Hawakhana area
WeaponDetails: A crude bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "India: Meghalaya Rebel ANVC-B Denies Involvement in Tura Bomb Blast; New Group Claims Responsibility," The Shillong Times Online, January 13, 2014.

Description: 01/07/2014: Assailants attacked a group of police officers in Edenbari town, Meghalaya state, India. Two police officers were injured in the attack. The Achik National Volunteer Council-B (ANVC-B) claimed responsibility for the incident, stating that they carried out the attack because they suspected that the police officers were rivals disguised as police, since they had refused to produce any documents.
