Description: 01/26/1980: In Arlington, Virginia, United States, the home and car of Vietnamese anti-communist journalist, Nguyen Thanh Hoang, were firebombed by unknown perpetrator(s), while Hoang and his 7-year-old daughter were asleep in the Highland Street home. The home was destroyed to rubble, but Hoang and his daughter were able to escape the fires. Prior to this incident, Hoang had received threatening letters urging him to stop his anti-communist policies. Additionally, after the incident, two letters which claimed responsibility for the bombings, were signed by a group identifying itself as the "Action Squad," and sent to Hoang.
LocationDetails: at residence and vehicle on Highland Street
SpecificDescription1: Nguyen Thanh Hoang, Vietnamese anti-communist journalist, owner of Tien Phong magazine
WeaponDetails: firebombs
Sources: Ronald D. White, "Violence Finds Viet Editor In His New Arlington Home," The Washington Post, March 24, 1980.
Kristan Metzler, "Murder trail runs dry ; Fear, mistrust stymie police probe of 1990 exile's killing," The Washington Times, October 4, 1994.
Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

Description: 1985-04-08: Action Struggle Against the World (suspected) operated an attack in West Germany (FRG).
WeaponDetails: Explosive

Description: 1987-03-21: Active Espirit de Corps of the Argentina Army operated an attack in Argentina.
WeaponDetails: Explosive
GroupName: Active Espirit de Corps of the Argentina Army

Description: 06/23/2003: Suspected militants from the Adan Abyan Islamic Army (AAIA) fired machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at a six truck military medical convoy in the Habaab region of Yemen’s Abyan Province. The attackers wounded seven people, including several medics, in the ambush.
LocationDetails: This incident occurred in the Habaab region of the Abyan province, 50km east of Aden.
SpecificDescription1: A six truck military medical convoy that was crossing the Hattat region
WeaponDetails: The attackers fired machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at the convoy.
Sources: Dr. Sarah Meyers, “Militants Attack Military Convoy in Southern Yemen,” World Markets Analysis, June 23, 2003.
“Yemeni troops besiege islamist extremists suspected of medical convoy attack,” BBC Monitoring International Reports, June 24, 2003.
Ahmed Al-Haj, “Yemeni soldiers advance on mountain hide-out of militants accused of attacking military convoy,” Associated Press Worldstream, June 24, 2003.

Description: 10/06/2002: A dinghy containing explosives detonated against the side of the French oil tanker MV Limberg. One crew member was killed and twelve others were injured. The vessel caught fire and leaked approximately 90,000 barrels of oil into the Gulf of Aden. Al Qaida later claimed reponsibility via the now defunct website Jihad.net.
LocationDetails: Attack occurred in the waters of the Gulf of Adem off the coast of Yemen.
WeaponDetails: The sailors on board the french oil tanker reported seeing a small dighy pull alongside the ship before the explosion occurred. French investigators found traces of TNT explosives on the Limburg.
Sources: British Broadcasting Service “Yemen ship attack ‘was terrorism’”. October 13, 2002.
British Broadcasting Service “Hunt on for Yemeni Jailbreakers”. February 4, 2006.

Description: 08/28/1999: A large explosion went off in the City Center in Sana'a, Yemen, setting the city's largest shopping center on fire. Officials insisted that the bombing was a ''criminal act,'' while the police said there was no evidence that the explosion was a terrorist act with political motivations. However, the Adan Abyan Islamic Army (AAIA) claimed credit for this attack. Two people were killed and twelve others were injured in the explosion.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the City Center of Sanaa.
SpecificDescription1: City Center Shopping Mall in Sana'a, Yemen
Sources: “Explosions rip through Yemen cities,” United Press International, August 28, 1999.
Kathleen Engman, “Islamic group claims role in Yemen car bomb attack,” Calgary Herald, August 30, 1999.
“Yemen denies Islamist claim on explosion,” Agence France Presse , August 30, 1999.

Description: 12/07/2019: Assailants opened fire and killed Colonel Mohamed Saleh al-Radfani, a senior Security Belt Forces official, in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources also attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party, which denied involvement.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Mansura neighborhood of the city.
WeaponDetails: Assault rifles were used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Assassinations rock Aden following Yemeni government's return," Middle East Eye, December 12, 2019.
"Spotlight: Tightened security measures in Yemen's Aden to curb spike of assassinations," Xinhua General News Service, December 10, 2019.
"Terrorism Digest 9-10 Dec 19," BBC Monitoring, December 10, 2019.

Description: 08/30/2019: An explosive device detonated targeting Security Belt leaders, including Wadah Omar, in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. At least five bodyguards were injured in the blast. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also suspected the involvement of Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Resurgence of terror groups in Yemen is a cause of concern for Arab coalition forces," Abu Dhabi National, September 2, 2019.
"Aden's terror groups must be dismantled," Abu Dhabi National, August 31, 2019.
"Suicide attack kills 3 separatists in Yemen's Aden: security," France24, August 30, 2019.

Description: 08/30/2019: A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden motorcycle by crashing into a Southern Resistance Forces (SRF) vehicle in Aden, Adan, Yemen. At least seven people, including one assailant and six SRF members, were killed and an unknown number of people, including civilians, were wounded in the attack. The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden motorcycle was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Resurgence of terror groups in Yemen is a cause of concern for Arab coalition forces," Abu Dhabi National, September 2, 2019.
"Daesh suicide bomber kills 3 STC fighters in Aden," Saudi Gazette, August 30, 2019.
"Daesh claims Aden suicide attack on separatist fighters," Lebanon Daily Star, August 30, 2019.

Description: 08/15/2019: Assailants opened fire and killed a soldier in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. The Aban-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities questioned the validity of this claim.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Mansura neighborhood.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State (suspected)
Sources: "Suspected IS gunmen shoot soldier in Yemen's Aden dead," Al-Masdar Online website, August 16, 2019.
"The assassination of a soldier in the counter-terrorist forces after a post attributed to ISIS adopts the operation," Almasdar Online, August 16, 2019.
"Terrorism Digest: 16-17 Aug 19," BBC Monitoring, August 17, 2019.

Description: 08/01/2019: At least four suicide bombers detonated explosives-laden vehicles including a car, a bus and three motorcycles targeting a police station in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. At least 15 people, including four assailants, were killed and 29 others were injured in the attack. This was one of two incidents in Aden on this day. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack. Houthi extremists also initially claimed responsibility but then later denied involvement.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Omar Al-Mokhtar area of the city.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden car, an explosives-laden minibus, and explosives-laden motorcycles were used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "The Latest: IS in Yemen claims Aden police station attack," ABC News, August 2, 2019.
"60 Killed In Aden Twin attacks – Yemeni Official," Daily Independent (Nigeria), August 1, 2019.
"Yemen: Dozens killed in attack on military parade," Deutsche Welle, August 1, 2019.

Description: 09/10/2018: Assailants opened fire on the convoy of Colonel Abu-Muhtam in Haswah, Adan, Yemen. Abu-Muhtam, the Security Belt's 4th Battalion commander, was not harmed but an unknown number of security personnel were injured in the assault. No group claimed responsibility for the attack; however, sources attributed the attack separately to Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and the Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State.
SpecificDescription1: Convoy of 4th Battalion Commander: Colonel Abu-Muhtam
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Xinhua: Yemen's Security Official Escapes Assassination Attempt In Aden," Xinhua, September 10, 2018.
"Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security, CT Developments 2000 GMT 11 September 2018," Summary, September 10, 2018.

Description: 03/13/2018: A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden vehicle targeting an army mess hall of the Hizam Brigade in Al-Derain, Aden, Yemen. At least six people, including the assailant, were killed and 30 more, including staff and civilians, were wounded. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Al-Derain neighborhood.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "IS suicide bombing kills six in Yemen’s Aden," The Nation Pakistan, March 14, 2018.
"Suicide bomb targets UAE-backed force, kills five in Aden," Saudi Gazette, March 13, 2018.
"Fresh-faced teenage jihadi cheerfully poses with an explosive belt 'before blowing himself up in suicide bomb attack in Yemen'," Long Room.com, March 14, 2018.

Description: 03/04/2018: Assailants shot and killed two soldiers in the Mansura neighborhood in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Mansura neighborhood.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "IS says it was behind drive-by shooting in Yemen," MENA English (Middle East and North Africa Financial Network), March 5, 2018.
"IS claims deadly drive-by shooting in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua General News Service, March 4, 2018.
"Yemen: Roundup of Political, Security Developments 2000 GMT 5 March 2018," Summary, March 4, 2018.

Description: 02/24/2018: Two suicide bombers detonated explosives-laden vehicles and six other assailants attacked a counterterrorism headquarters in Gold Mohur area of the Tawahi, Aden, Yemen. In addition to four assailants, 14 people were killed and 40 others were injured in the attack; the victims included both civilians and security personnel. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Gold Mohur area of the Tawahi neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: Two explosives-laden vehicles, two explosives-laden belts, and firearms were used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Twin suicide blasts rock Yemen port city of Aden," CNN Wire, February 24, 2018.
"Yemen: twin-suicide attack leaves 14 killed, 40 wounded," MENA English (Middle East and North Africa Financial Network), February 26, 2018.
"At least 14 killed in Yemen attack, Islamic State claims responsibility," ABC Online, February 25, 2018.

Description: 11/29/2017: An explosives-laden vehicle detonated outside the Ministry of Finance headquarters in Aden, Adan, Yemen. At least five people were killed and 12 people were injured in the blast. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the blast. In addition, sources attributed the attack to Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Khur Maksar neighborhood.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Islamic State claims deadly car bombing attack in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua General News Service, November 29, 2017.
"Car Bomb in Yemen’s Aden Leaves 4 Dead," Latin American Herald Tribune, November 29, 2017.
"IS claims responsibility for Aden car bomb which killed five," Gulf Daily News, November 29, 2017.

Description: 11/25/2017: Assailants opened fire on Colonel Hamud Muhammad al Hamidi near his house in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. Al Hamidi, head of investigation at the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) was killed in the attack. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Al-Qahirah area of the Mansura neighborhood.
SpecificDescription1: Head of Investigation: Colonel Hamud Muhammad al Hamidi
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Unknown assailants assassinate security official in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua General News Service, November 25, 2017.
"Yemen: Open Source Terrorism Roundup 28 November 2017," Summary, November 27, 2017.
"Yemen: Open Source Terrorism Roundup 25 November 2017," Summary, November 24, 2017.

Description: 11/14/2017: Two suicide bombers detonated an explosives-laden vehicle at a security forces base in Mansura, Shaykh Uthman, Aden, Yemen. In addition to the two assailants, nine people were killed and at least 18 others, including security personnel and civilians, were injured in the blast. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Mansura neighborhood.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "6 killed in suicide car bombing in Aden," Gulf News, November 14, 2017.
"At least six killed in Yemen suicide bombing claimed by Islamic State," Reuters India, November 14, 2017.
"Six dead in suicide bombing in Yemen," Siasat Daily, November 14, 2017.

Description: 11/05/2017: Two suicide bombers detonated explosives-laden vehicles outside the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) building in Khur Maksar neighborhood, Aden, Yemen. Following the blasts, additional assailants then stormed the compound, set the building on fire, and took an unknown number of hostages. Overnight four additional suicide bombers detonated as security forces attempted to retake the building. At least 55 people, including nine assailants, were killed and 47 other people were injured in the attack; the victims included security forces and civilians. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack. Sources also suspected that the incident was carried out by Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Khur Maksar neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden vehicle, explosives-laden vests, and firearms were used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "At least 15 killed in ISIL attack on Yemen security HQ," Al Jazeera, November 5, 2017.
"Yemen hostage crisis claimed by IS ends with 35 dead," Bangladesh Daily Star, November 6, 2017.
"Death toll rises to 35 in Aden attack," Gulf News, November 6, 2017.

Description: 01/11/2017: An explosives-laden vehicle detonated targeting a Hizam Brigade convoy in Lawdar, Abyan, Yemen. One Hizam Brigade member was killed and five members, including commander Amin al Sayyid, were injured in the blast. Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also suspected that the Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State may have carried out the attack.
SpecificDescription1: Convoy of Commander: Amin al Sayyid
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State (suspected)
Sources: "'Qaeda' car bomb wounds Yemen security official," Agence France-Presse Top News (English), t, January 11, 2017.
"Yemen: Security Roundup 2000 GMT 12 January 2017," Summary, January 12, 2017.
"Gulf of Aden Security Review - January 11, 2017," Critical Threats, January 11, 2017.

Description: 12/18/2016: A suicide bomber detonated targeting Sulban military base in Aden, Adan, Yemen. In addition to the assailant, at least 52 soldiers were killed and 90 soldiers were injured in the blast. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden vest was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Suicide bomber kills more than 40 in Yemen," CNN, December 18, 2016.
"Islamic State's Aden attacks reflect group's strategy aimed at fomenting chaos before seizing territory in Yemen," IHS Global Insight, December 21, 2016.
"Islamic State suicide attack kills 52 in southern Yemen," Boston Globe, December 19, 2016.

Description: 12/13/2016: Assailants shot and injured Osama Khalid Haidra, a popular resistance committee member, in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Mansura neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: A silenced pistol was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "See How ISIS Terror Group Assassinated A Security Officer In Yemen.... Graphic Photos," Nigeriadailynews.news, December 14, 2016.
"Gulf of Aden Security Review - December 15, 2016," Critical Threats, December 15, 2016.

Description: 12/10/2016: A suicide bomber detonated targeting Sulban military base in Aden, Adan, Yemen. In addition to the assailant, at least 57 soldiers were killed and 29 soldiers were injured in the blast. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden belt was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "52 soldiers die in Yemen bombing; WORLD BULLETIN," The Daily Telegraph (London), December 19, 2016.
"ISIS suicide bomber kills 35 Yemen soldiers," News24, December 11, 2016.
"Toll rises to 48 in   Daesh-claimed  Yemen attack," The Gulf Today, December 11, 2016.

Description: 11/22/2016: Assailants shot and killed Colonel Abd-al-Rahim al-Dali'i, an Aden International Airport security official, in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State and Al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) separately claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Abdul Aziz area of the Mansura neighborhood.
SpecificDescription1: Aden International Airport Security Colonel: Abd-al-Rahim al-Dali'i
WeaponDetails: A silenced pistol was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "ISIS gunmen assassinate Aden Airport security officer ," Almasdar Online, November 23, 2016.
"IS militant kills Yemeni Colonel, films shooting on head-cam," Yahoo! India, November 23, 2016.
"Yemen: Security Roundup 2000 GMT 22 November 2016," Summary, November 22, 2016.

Description: 09/30/2016: Assailants opened fire on the vehicle of Colonel Ali Muqbil in Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. Muqbil, a senior intelligence official, was killed in the attack. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Mansura neighborhood.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Suicide bomber kills one person, wounds three in Yemeni port city," Reuters India, October 1, 2016.
"Unknown gunmen kill intelligence colonel in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua News Agency, September 30, 2016.
"Yemen spy boss gunned down," Arab News, September 30, 2016.

Description: 09/29/2016: An explosive device attached to the vehicle of a police officer detonated in Aden, Adan, Yemen. The officer was injured in the blast. The Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: An explosive device attached to a vehicle was used in the attack.
GroupName: Adan-Abyan Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Suicide bomber kills one person, wounds three in Yemeni port city," Reuters India, October 1, 2016.
"Unknown gunmen kill intelligence colonel in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua News Agency, September 30, 2016.
"Gulf of Aden Security Review - September 29, 2016," Critical Threats, September 29, 2016.

Description: 12/21/2011: Businessman Ratan Saha was kidnapped by suspected members of Adivasi Cobra Militants of Assam (ACMA) in Kokrajhar, Assam, India. In response, locals violently protested the kidnapping and demanded that Saha be released in 24 hours. There were no reports of the outcome of the kidnapping.
LocationDetails: In the city
WeaponDetails: No weapons detail given
Sources: "Trader abducted in Kokrajhar district," Times of India, December 23 2011.

Description: 10/11/2014: Assailants abducted a grocery store owner and his employee in Majuli area, Sonitpur district, Assam state, India. The whereabouts of the victims were unknown. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to the Adivasi National Liberation Army (ANLA), which kidnapped the employees because they had failed to make ransom payments.
SpecificDescription1: Grocery Store Employees: Naba Sarma, Sandu Newar
Sources: "ANLA militants abduct duo," Calcutta Telegraph, October 13, 2014.
"Small time businessman and employee kidnapped in Assam," Business Standard India, October 12, 2014.

Description: 11/21/2012: At least three assailants abducted Gobin Goswami, the headmaster of Kuwoni Lower Primary School in Golaghat district, Assam state, India. Specific motive and the outcome of the kidnapping is unknown; however, Adivasi National Liberation Army (ANLA) is responsible for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Folongni area
Sources: "School headmaster kidnapped," Press Trust of India, November 21, 2012.
"Abducted   teacher still traceless," The Times of India (TOI), November 24, 2012.

Description: 12/24/2008: On Wednesday morning, at 0110, in Matipul, Karbi Anglong, Assam, India, a bomb was detonated on railway tracks between Khatkhati and Bokajan. Police arrested four All Adivasi National Liberation Army (AANLA) militants in connection to the blast. The rail track was partially damaged in the explosion but no casualties were reported. No group claimed responsibility.
LocationDetails: The attack took place on railway tracks between Khatkhati and Bokajan in Matipul, Karbi Anglong, Assam, India.
SpecificDescription1: Railway tracks between Khatkhati and Bokajan
WeaponDetails: Unknown explosives were used in the attack.
Sources: South Asia Terrorism Portal, "Four AANLA Militants Arrested in Assam," http://satp.org/satporgtp/detailed_news3.asp?date3=2008%2F12%2F26#1 (December 26, 2008).
Shillong Times, "Bomb Found, Major Disaster Averted in Guwahati," Shillong Times, December 25, 2008, http://www.theshillongtimes.com/a-25-Dec.htm.
South Asia Terrorism Portal, "Bomb explosion in Assam," http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/detailed_news3.asp?date3=2008%2F12%2F25#1 (December 25, 2008)

Description: 12/23/2008: On Tuesday, unidentified militants shot dead a senior tea executive in Carramore tea estate along the India-Bhutan border under Harisinga Police Station in Udalguri, Assam, India. Deputy Manager Gautom Kotoky of Corramore Tea Estate, owned by McLeod & Russell Group, was killed. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, however, suspected Adivasi National Liberation Army militants were suspected.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in Udalguri, Assam, India.
SpecificDescription1: Deputy Manager Gautom Kotoky of Corramore Tea Estate
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: United News of India, "Tea Estate Manager Killed," LexisNexis Academic, United News of India, December 23, 2008.
Press Trust of India, "Tea Garden Executive Shot Dead in Assam," LexisNexis Academic, Press Trust of India, December 23, 2008.
South Asia Terrorism Portal, "Militants Kill Tea Estate Official in Assam," http://satp.org/satporgtp/detailed_news3.asp?date3=2008%2F12%2F24#2 (Decemebr 24, 2008).

Description: 12/13/2007: A bomb planted in a train compartment on its way from Dibrugarh to Delhi, India, exploded killing five people and injuring five others. There is, however, no official toll on the number of casualties. Dilip Beg, a top leader of the Adivasi National Liberation Army (ANLA) claimed responsibility for the attack to reporters by telephone from an undisclosed location, asking for more rights and recognition for the community in the state.
LocationDetails: The bomb went off between Naojan and Chungajan.
SpecificDescription1: Travelers in a train between Dibrugarh and Delhi.
WeaponDetails: The bomb was planted in a train compartment.
Sources: "India: 5 Killed in Blast on Delhi-Bound Train in Assam,” OSC Feature - CNN-IBN, December 13th, 2007.
"India: Tribal Insurgent Group ANLA Claims Responsibility for Assam Train Blast,” New Delhi The Times of India, December 13th, 2007.

Description: 06/07/2007: Rajar Agarwal, an Indian civilian and son of businessman Dilip Agarwal, was kidnapped by four suspected Adivasi National Liberation Army (ANLA) perpetrators with small arms from an autorickshaw in the morning near Toukata Tea Estate in Sonari, Savasgari District, Assam State, India. No claim of responsibility was reported.
LocationDetails: Near Toukata Tea Estate in Sonari.
WeaponDetails: Small arms.
Sources: “Highlights: northeast Indian press 7-9 June 2007,” India – OSC Summary, June 9, 2007.

Description: 02/03/2013: An explosive device detonated on railway tracks in Goabari village, Kokrajhar district, Assam state, India. No deaths were reported as the explosion occurred a few minutes after the train had passed. The Adivasi People's Army (APA) was responsible for the incident.
LocationDetails: Located In Kokrajhar District
WeaponDetails: A remote-triggered explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: "Acts of Adivashi ultra group cause of concern," Assam Tribune, February 7, 2013.
"Blast on railway track in Kokrajhar, no injury," Afternoon Voice (India), February 4, 2013.
"India: Suspected Militants Attack Railway Track in Assam; Police Launch Operation," The Telegraph Online, February 4, 2013.

Description: 11/16/2011: Unidentified gunmen shot and wounded Zakir Hussain at Grahampur Bazar in Kokrajhar district, Assam state, India. Hussain was a leader in the Assam Minorities Students' Union (AMSU); he held the position of Kamandanga unit assistant secretary. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities suspect that the Adivasi People's Army was involved in the attack.
LocationDetails: Kokrajhar district
SpecificDescription1: Zakir Hussain, the AMSU Kamandanga unit assistant secretary
Sources: "Amsu leader shot in Kokrajhar," The Times of India, November 18, 2011.

Description: 07/10/2011: On Sunday evening at 2030, in Guwahati, Assam, India, militants of the Adivasi People's Army (APA) bombed the Guwahati-Puri Express train. Four of the train's coaches were derailed and over 100 people were injured. The blast caused an unknown amount of property damage to the tracks and train. Police said the bomb was placed on the track with wires and other trigger materials, which were found after the bombing. The APA claimed responsibility for the attack through an email on 07/11/2011. Police however suspected that National Democratic Front of Bodoland (NDFB) militants were responsible for the attack.
LocationDetails: The attack took place on the Guwahati-Puri Express near Guwahati, Assam, India.
WeaponDetails: Unknown explosives were used in the attack.
Sources: Hindustan Times, “Assam on High Alert After Train Bombing,” Hindustan Times, July 9, 2011, http://www.hindustantimes.com/Assam-on-high-alert-after-train-bombing/Article1-719751.aspx.
Xinhua News Agency, “One Hundred Injured in Alleged Bomb Attack on Train in India,” Xinhua News Agency, July 11, 2011, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-07/11/c_13977269.htm.
United News of India, "Tribal Group Claims Responsibility for Railway Tracks Blast in Assam," Access World News, United News of India, July 12, 2011.

Description: 12/03/2017: Assailants opened fire on Dr. Walter Reopert near the Erta Ale Volcano in Zone 2 district, Afar, Ethiopia. Reopert, a German tourist, was killed and his guide was injured in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected that the attack was carried out by the Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred near the Erta Ale volcano.
Sources: "German Killed In Attack At Ethiopia Volcano," AFP (World Service), December 5, 2017.
"Ethiopia likely to mount raids on Eritrea-based Afar militants in retaliation for militant killing of European tourist," IHS Global Insight, December 5, 2017.
"Singapore: Gunmen kill German tourist in Ethiopia's Afar region," Channel NewsAsia Online, December 5, 2017.

Description: 01/17/2012: Assailants attacked a group of tourists at the Erta Ale volcano in Afar region, Ethiopia. The assailants killed five European tourists and kidnapped two Ethiopians and two Germans. The Germans were released on March 6, 2012. The whereabouts of the Ethiopian victims are unknown. The Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unit Front (ARDUF) claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: Incident occurred near the Erta Ale camp on the volcano.
Sources: "Ethiopia deny claims by rebel group that their troops shot foreign tourists," Associated Press Newswires, January 24, 2012.
"Five Europeans killed in Ethiopia attack," Agence France Presse, January 18, 2012.
"UPDATE 2-Ethiopia says Eritrea-trained gunmen killed tourists," Reuters News, January 17, 2012.

Description: 03/01/2007: Five British Embassy personnel, workers and relatives of workers, along with 9 Ethiopian guides & embassy personnel, were taken hostage during a tour of the Afar region in Hamedela, Ethopia, by the Afar Revolutionary Democratic Unity Front.
LocationDetails: In the Hemedale area
SpecificDescription2: Local workers & service personnel working for British Embassy
WeaponDetails: Grenades were used to disable the group's vehicles in order to avoid pursuit.  There is a likelihood that small arms were involved, but that can't be verified.
Sources: David Williams, “SAS Stand by after embassy staff are seized in Ethiopia”,  The Daily Mail, March 03, 2007
Jamie Doward and Naomi Loomes and Jason Burke, “News: Kidnap Britons  sighted in Eritrea: Ethiopians fear that the abduction marks an escalation of  conflict”, The Observer, March 4, 2007
“Kidnapped Ethiopians released: ministry“, Agence France Presse, April 22, 2007

Description: 1978-07-18: AFB operated an attack in Austria.
WeaponDetails: Automatic firearm

Description: 12/16/2008: On Tuesday morning, at 1100, a group calling itself the Afghan Revolutionary Front planted a bundle of dynamite in the third floor restroom of the menswear department inside the Printemps department store in Paris, Ile de France, France. The group sent a letter to police saying several bombs were planted in the department store and that they demanded that France withdraw from Afghanistan. No casualties or damages resulted from the attempted bombing.
LocationDetails: The attack took place at the Printemps department store in Paris, Ile de France, France.
WeaponDetails: Dynamite was used in the attack.
Sources: Jim Bittermann and Niki Cook, "Dynamite Found at Paris Department Store," Cable News Network, December 16, 2008.
Jean-Pierre Verges, "TNT Discovered at Famed Paris Department Store," Yahoo News, http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20081216/ap_on_re_eu/eu_france_explosives_defused (December 16, 2008).

Description: 02/07/2011: On Monday night around 0300, near Akwa village of an unspecified city in Bakassi province, Cameroon, two policemen were killed when unidentified militants attacked a police post with unknown firearms. No group claimed responsibility, but the militant group Africa Marine Commando (AMC) was thought to be responsible for the attack.
LocationDetails: At a police post near the village of Akwa in Bakassi province, Cameroon.
SpecificDescription1: A police post was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.

Agence France Presse, "Cameroon Rebels Kill Police in Kidnap Raid: Sources," LexisNexis Academic, Agence France Presse, February 7, 2011.

Description: 02/06/2011: On Sunday, in the Gulf of Guinea off the coast of Bakassi, Cameroon, unidentified armed militants kidnapped 11 Cameroon government officials off a boat by unknown means; no casualties were reported. The hostages were released on 02/16/2011. No group claimed responsibility, but the militant group African Marine Commando (AMC) was thought to be responsible for the attack.
LocationDetails: The hostage taking occurred in the Gulf of Guinea off the coast of Bakassi, Cameroon.
WeaponDetails: Unknown weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Xinhua News Agency, "Eleven Cameroonian Officials Kidnapped in Bakassi Peninsula," Xinhua News Agency, February 8, 2011, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/08/c_13722048.htm.
Washington Post, "Thirteen Cameroonian Hostages Freed, Mayor Says," Washington Post, February 17, 2011, http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/17/AR2011021703061.html.
Agence France Presse, "Cameroonians in Contact with Kidnapped Officials," LexisNexis Academic, Agence France Presse, February 8, 2011.

Description: 11/16/2010: On Tuesday night into Wednesday 11/17/2010, between 2300 and 0200, in an unspecified location off the coast of Bakassi, Cameroon, two security guards, three Cameroon Rapid Intervention Battalion soldiers were killed and several other people were injured when unidentified gunmen using water vessels and unknown firearms attacked an offshore water vessel, which was operated by the French oil company Perenco. One militant was also killed in the attack and no damage was reported. The militant group African Marine Commando claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: At an oil platform in an unspecified location off the coast of Bakassi, Cameroon.
SpecificDescription1: A Perenco water vessel was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: Voice of America, "Oil Firm Says Five People Killed in Cameroon Boat Attack," Voice of America, November 17, 2010, http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Oil-Firm-Says-5-People-Killed-in-Cameroon-Boat-Attack--108684719.html.
Agence France Presse, "Attack On Oil Platform Leaves Six Dead in Cameroon's Disputed Bakassi Peninsula," World News Connection, Agence France Presse, November 17, 2010.
Xinhua News Agency, "Five Killed in Boat Attack Off Cameroon," Xinhua News Agency, November 17, 2010, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-11/17/c_13611083.htm.

Description: 03/28/2010: On Sunday, off the coast of Cameroon in the Gulf of Guinea, attackers hijacked a Nigerian boat carrying goods. The captain and one crew member were taken hostage. It is unknown if the attack caused any property damage. No casualties were reported and no group claimed responsibility for this incident, but it was suspected that the African Marine Commando were responsible. The assailants demanded $1.5 million for the release of the hostages and the boat.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in an unspecified area off the coast of Cameroon in the Gulf of Guinea.
SpecificDescription1: A Nigerian boat carrying goods was hijacked.
WeaponDetails: Unknown weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Reuters, "Nigerian Boat Hijacked Off Cameroon Coast," Reuters, March 29, 2010, http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE62S25R.htm.
Jane’s Intelligence, “Militants Hijack Nigerian Vessel Off Cameroon's Bakassi,” Terrorism Watch Report, March 30, 2010.
World Markets Research Centre, "Pirates Attack Nigerian Vessel Off Cameroonian Coast, Demand Ransom," LexisNexis Academic, World Markets Research Centre, March 31, 2010.

Description: 03/12/2010: On Friday night around 0200, off the Bakassi peninsula in southwest Cameroon, unidentified assailants attacked two fishing vessels of China’s Dalian Beihai Fishing Company looting equipment and kidnapping seven crewmen. The ships returned to the port of Limbe around 0700 with two sailors on board slightly injured. It is unknown if the attack caused any property damage. The Africa Marine Commando claimed responsibility for the attack and are demanding $15,000 for the release of the hostages.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in an unspecified area off the Bakassi peninsula.
WeaponDetails: Unknown weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Agence France Presse, "Kidnappers Demand 15,000 Dollars for Seven Chinese Fishermen," World News Connection, Agence France Presse, March 15, 2010.
World Markets Research Centre, "Seven Chinese Fisherman Kidnapped Off Cameroon Coast," LexisNexis Academic, World Markets Research Centre, March 15, 2010.

06/27/2018: A suicide bomber detonated outside a Levant Front headquarters at Kawa Hadad Roundabout in Afrin, Aleppo, Syria. This was one of three coordinated bombings in Afrin and one of two blasts at the same roundabout on this date. At least 10 people, including one assailant, were killed and 20 other people were injured across all both attacks; the victims included Levant Front members and civilians. The Afrin Falcons claimed responsibility for the incidents.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Kawa Hadad Roundabout.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden belt was used in the attack.
Sources: "1ST LEAD," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, June 27, 2018.
"Two bombs rip through Syria's Afrin killing at least 10," TRT World, June 27, 2018.
"Bomb explosions rock Syria's Afrin," BBC Monitoring, June 27, 2018.

Description: 06/27/2018: An explosives-laden motorcycle detonated outside a Levant Front headquarters at Kawa Hadad Roundabout in Afrin, Aleppo, Syria. This was one of three coordinated bombings in Afrin and one of two blasts at the same roundabout on this date. At least 10 people, including one assailant, were killed and 20 other people were injured across all both attacks; the victims included Levant Front members and civilians. The Afrin Falcons claimed responsibility for the incidents.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Kawa Hadad Roundabout.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden motorcycle was used in the attack.

Description: 06/27/2018: An explosives-laden vehicle detonated outside Dersim Hospital along Jindayris Road in Al Fillat neighborhood, Afrin, Aleppo Syria. At least one person was killed and 13 other people were injured in the blast; the victims included Levant Front members and civilians. This was one of three coordinated bombings in Afrin; this third blast targeted people being transferred to the hospital from two earlier explosions. The Afrin Falcons claimed responsibility for the attacks.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred along Jindayris Road in the Al-Fillat neighborhood.
Sources: "1ST LEAD," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, June 27, 2018.
"Two bombs rip through Syria's Afrin killing at least 10," TRT World, June 27, 2018.
"Bomb explosions rock Syria's Afrin," BBC Monitoring, June 27, 2018.

Description: 03/18/2020: Assailants shelled Afrin, Aleppo, Syria. At least five people were killed and 15 people were inured in the attack. The Afrin Liberation Forces (HRE) claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: Artillery was used in the attack.
Sources: "Xinhua Middle East news summary at 2200 GMT, March 18," Xinhua General News Service, March 19, 2020.
"Shelling by Kurdish forces kills five in Syria's Afrin | Ahval," Ahval, March 18, 2020.
"Artillery shells kill 4 civilians, injure 15 in Aleppo’s Afrin," Orient-News.Net, March 18, 2020.

Description: 08/27/2019: An explosive device detonated on a minibus in Azaz, Aleppo, Syria. At least two people were killed and nine other people were injured in the blast. The Afrin Liberation Forces (HRE) claimed responsibility for the attack.
Sources: "Syria Syrian Kurds begin pullout from Turkish border," An Nahar, August 27, 2019.
"Syrian Kurdish group claims killing two Turkey-backed rebels," Hawar News Agency website, August 29, 2019.

Description: 06/09/2019: Assailants attacked Turkish Armed Forces (TSK) soldiers in Afrin, Aleppo, Syria. At least one soldier was killed and seven other soldiers were injured in the incident. Afrin Liberation Forces (HRE) claimed responsibility and stated that the attack was carried out in response to operations conducted by the TSK in Afrin. Sources also attributed the incident to the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) and the People's Protection Units (YPG).
Sources: "Kurdish attack in N. Syria kills 1 Turkish soldier: monitor," Xinhua General News Service, June 26, 2019.
"Turkey 'neutralizes' 10 PKK/YPG militants in Syria's north," Turkish Daily, June 11, 2019.
"Weekly Roundup of Syrian Kurdish Affairs 9-15 June 2019," Summary, June 9, 2019.

Description: 10/14/2016: Assailants attacked government positions in Malakal, Upper Nile, South Sudan. At least 56 assailants were killed in the ensuing clash. Agwelek Forces claimed responsibility for the incident.
Sources: "Fresh Fighting in South Sudan Kills 50," BBC World Service, October 17, 2016.
"South Sudan: Fighting around South Sudan town of Malakal kills 56, says government," Thai News Service, October 19, 2016.
"Fighting breaks out between army, rebels near South Sudan state capital," Radio Tamazuj Online, October 14, 2016.

Description: 10/05/2016: Assailants launched a rocket at Sderot, Southern district, Israel. There were no reported casualties in the attack. Ahfad al-Sahaba-Aknaf Bayt al-Maqdis claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for the recent detainment of five Salafists by Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement).
WeaponDetails: A homemade rocket was used in the attack.
Sources: "Gaza rocket strikes in southern Israeli city of Sderot; damaged caused," Jerusalem Post, October 5, 2016.
"Shell Fired from Gaza Hits Southern Israeli City, IDF Responds," Latin American Herald Tribune, October 5, 2016.
"Terrorized Israeli Children Cower Under Desks, Recite Psalms, as Qassam Rocket From Gaza Lands Near Sderot School," Algemeiner.com, October 5, 2016.

Description: 08/21/2016: Assailants fired a rocket into Sderot, Southern district, Israel. There were no reported casualties in the attack. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for the imprisonment of PFLP member Bilal Kayid. Ahfad al-Sahaba-Aknaf Bayt al-Maqdis also claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the attack.
GroupName: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP)
Sources: "Rocket fired from Gaza strikes Sderot in southern Israel," JTA, August 21, 2016.
"Israeli army attacks Gaza town in reprisal against rockets," Xinhua General News Service, August 21, 2016.
"Israel Retaliates After Palestinian Rocket Hits Southern City," Bloomberg, August 21, 2016.

Description: 07/01/2016: Assailants in Gaza Strip fired a rocket at a preschool in Sderot, Southern district, Israel. There were no reported casualties in the blast. Ahfad al-Sahaba-Aknaf Bayt al-Maqdis claimed responsibility for the attack. However, officials attributed the incident to Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement).
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the attack.
Sources: "ISIS affiliated terror group takes credit for Gaza rocket attack," Jerusalem Post, July 2, 2016.
"Gaza rocket hits southern Israel: army," Xinhua General News Service, July 1, 2016.
"Gaza rocket hits Israeli city, none wounded: a...," Qatar Peninsula, July 1, 2016.

Description: 10/08/2018: Assailants shot and killed Syed Ahmed Abbas Rizvi, a police officer, in Karachi, Pakistan. Hizb-ul-Ahrar (HuA) claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities questioned the veracity of this claim and instead attributed the attack to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan) and Lashkar-e-Jhangvi.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the New Karachi neighborhood of the city.
WeaponDetails: A 30-bore pistol was used in the attack.
Sources: "Pakistan: Second cop martyred in less than a week," The News Online, October 9, 2018.
"Cop shot dead in Karachi," Business Recorder, October 9, 2018.
"Shia policeman martyred in a targeted terrorist attack in Karachi," Arab Herald, October 8, 2018.

Description: 02/02/2018: Assailants opened fire on Matiullah in Dera Ismail Khan, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Matiullah, the Imambargah Hazrat Abbas caretaker, was killed and another person was injured in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Dera Ismail Khan district.
Sources: "Two killed in Dera Ismail Khan attacks," DAWN Group, February 3, 2018.
"Pakistan- Two men shot dead in target killing incidents in DI Khan," Global English (Middle East and North Africa Financial Network), February 2, 2018.

Description: 01/31/2017: Assailants threw a grenade at Imambargah Saqa-e-Sakina in Block-Q of North Nazimabad neighborhood, Karachi, Pakistan. There were no reported casualties as the device failed to detonate. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Block-Q of the North Nazimabad neighborhood.
Sources: "Assailants hurl grenade at imambargah," The Express Tribune, February 1, 2017.
"Takfiri terrorists throw hand grenade on Shia mosque in Karachi," ABNA24.com, February 2, 2017.
"Pakistan: Imambargah targeted in Karachi with hand grenade," Times of Islamabad Online, February 1, 2017.

Description: 12/10/2016: Assailants opened fire on Yousuf Hussain in Abbottabad, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Pakistan. Hussain, a Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) Deputy Manager of Operations, was killed in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Lashkar-e-Jhangvi and Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
SpecificDescription1: Deputy Manager of Operations: Yousuf Hussain
WeaponDetails: A pistol was used in the attack.
Sources: "Sectarian killing?: PESCO official gunned down in Abbottabad    ," The Express Tribune, December 11, 2016.
"Pakistani Shia officer martyred in terrorist attack in Abbottabad / Photos," ABNA24.com, December 11, 2016.

Description: 10/29/2016: Assailants opened fire on a Shia procession in Nazimabad neighborhood, Karachi, Pakistan. At least five people, including one United Kingdom citizen and one United States citizen, were killed and six others were injured in the assault. Lashkar-e-Jhangvi claimed responsibility for the attack. Sources also attributed the attack to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Nazimabad neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: Two pistols were used in the attack.
Sources: "British tourist among five killed in sectarian attack on Shia Muslims in Karachi; Exclusive: Naiyyar MehdiZaidi, from London, and two of his brothers were shot and killed when two gunmen opened fire at a Shia Muslim gathering," The Independent, October 30, 2016.
"Gunmen Attack Shiites in Pakistan's Karachi, Killing 5," VOA News, October 29, 2016.
"Gunmen kill five Shiite Muslims in Karachi," Agence France-Presse Top News (English), t, October 29, 2016.

Description: 10/17/2016: Assailants threw a grenade at the Dar-e-Abbas Imambargah in Liaquatabad neighborhood, Karachi, Pakistan. At least 1 person was killed and 20 others were injured in the blast. Lashkar-e-Jhangvi claimed responsibility for the attack. Sources also attributed the incident to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the FC Area of Liaquatabad.
WeaponDetails: A hand grenade was used in the attack.
Sources: "Pakistan: Two mourners injured in sectarian attack in Karachi," The News Online, October 19, 2016.
"Boy killed, 20 injured in grenade attack on Imambargah," Business Recorder, October 18, 2016.
"Bomb attack near Shiite mosque kills 1 in southern Pakistan; Bomb attack near Shiite mosque kills 1 in southern Pakistan," The Canadian Press, October 17, 2016.

Description: 10/07/2016: Assailants opened fire on Shia civilians in Block 3, Gulshan-e-Iqbal neighborhood, Karachi, Pakistan. At least one person was killed and another was injured in the assault. This was one of two attacks carried out by the same assailants in Karachi on this date. Lashkar-e-Jhangvi claimed responsibility for the incidents. Sources also attributed the attack to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Block 3 area of Gulshan-e-Iqbal neighborhood.
SpecificDescription1: Shia Civilians: Syed Jawwad Raza, Syed Adeel Abbas
WeaponDetails: A 9-mm pistol was used in the attack.
Sources: "One group involved in at least five sectarian attacks, say police," Dawn (Pakistan), November 29, 2016.
"Pakistan Article Discusses Arrest of Ex-Senator, Sect Leaders After Surge in Sectarian Killings," The News Online, November 13, 2016.
"No headway made in probes into sectarian killings," The News International, October 21, 2016.

Description: 11/20/2015: Assailants opened fire on Imdad Hussain in Yakatut neighborhood, Peshawar city, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan. Hussain, an Awami National Party (ANP) vice president, was killed in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Yakatut neighborhood.
Sources: "Pakistan: Protests erupt in Peshawar after killing of ANP leader," Dawn Online, November 21, 2015.
"ANP office bearer killed in Peshawar, protest erupts," DAWN Group, November 20, 2015.
"Gunmen kill four paramilitary soldiers outside Pakistan mosque," Agence France-Presse Top News (English), t, November 20, 2015.

Description: 02/18/2015: Assailants opened fire on Mohammed Karim in North Nazimabad neighborhood, Karachi city, Sindh province, Pakistan. Karim, a member of the Ismaili community, and his driver were killed in the attack. Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan) claimed responsibility and stated that the attack was part of a series of planned attacks against members of the Shia and Ismaili communities in Karachi city.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the North Nazimabad neighborhood
Sources: "'SSP man' fleeing after sectarian killing held," Dawn (Pakistan), February 19, 2015.
"MQM denounces trader's murder," Pakistan Press International, February 19, 2015.

Description: 03/20/2014: Assailants opened fire on Anwar Jafri near the Coast Guard roundabout in Korangi neighborhood, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan. Jafri, a Crime Branch sub-inspector, was killed and a civilian was injured in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahle Sunnat Wal Jamaat (ASWJ-Pakistan). In addition, two Lashkar-e-Jhangvi members were also arrested in connection with the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Korangi neighborhood, near the Coast Guard roundabout.
Sources: "Pakistan: Suspects of Noted Singer Murder Being Tried in Military Court," Dawn Online, July 28, 2017.
"Three cops among eight lost lives in Karachi," Business Recorder, March 21, 2014.
"Karachi: Cop, passerby killed in an attack on police," The Nation, March 20, 2014.

Description: 12/15/2016: Assailants opened fire on a military base in Abud Wak, Galguduud, Somalia. At least one soldier was killed and two soldiers were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
Sources: "Highlights: Somalia Daily Media Highlights 15 December 2016," Summary, December 16, 2016.

Description: 11/28/2016: Assailants raided a politician's residence in Guriceel, Galguduud, Somalia. No casualties were reported in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
Sources: "Program Summary: Marka Radio Shabeelle Somali 0500 GMT 28 Nov 16," Radio Shabeelle, November 28, 2016.

Description: 11/14/2016: Assailants raided Radio Galgudud in Guriceel, Galguduud, Somalia. There were no reported casualties, though the radio station was shut down in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
Sources: "Highlights: Somalia Daily Media Highlights 15 November 2016," Summary, November 16, 2016.

Description: 09/08/2015: Assailants attacked a building housing Abdilatif Abdullahi Warsame in Guriceel, Galguduud, Somalia. Warsame, the Galmudug commerce minister, was unharmed, although eight people were killed in the ensuing clashes that lasted until September 9, 2015. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Dhusamareb district.
SpecificDescription1: Office of Minister: Abdilatif Abdullahi Warsame
Sources: "Highlights: Somalia Daily Media Highlights 15 September 2015," OSC Summary, September 14, 2015.

Description: 08/02/2015: Assailants abducted a journalist from Dhusamareb, Galguduud, Somalia. The whereabouts of the journalist, identified as Nafiso Hersi Oogle, are unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
Sources: "Gulf of Aden Security Review - August 03, 2015," Critical Threats, August 3, 2015.

Description: 08/01/2015: Assailants abducted two journalists from Dhusamareb, Galguduud, Somalia. The whereabouts of the journalists, identified as Abdullahi Farah Roble and Leylo Nor, are unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
SpecificDescription1: Journalists: Abdullahi Farah Roble, Leylo Nor
Sources: "Gulf of Aden Security Review - August 03, 2015," Critical Threats, August 3, 2015.

Description: 07/31/2015: Assailants abducted three journalists from Dhusamareb, Galguduud, Somalia. The whereabouts of the journalists, identified as Mohamed Abdi Mohamed, Abdijamal Moalim Ahmed, and Bashiir Mohamoud Salad, are unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
EntityName1: Somali National Television (SNTV); Kalsan TV; Horncable TV
SpecificDescription1: Journalists: Mohamed Abdi Mohamed, Abdijamal Moalim Ahmed, Bashiir Mohamoud Salad
Sources: "Gulf of Aden Security Review - August 03, 2015," Critical Threats, August 3, 2015.

Description: 07/19/2015: Assailants attacked government soldiers in Galguduud, Somalia. Two soldiers were killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Bangeele area.
Sources: "Highlights: Somalia Daily Media Highlights 22 July 2015," OSC Summary, July 21, 2015.

Description: 06/07/2015: Assailants attacked military bases in Dhusamareb, Galguduud, Somalia. It is unknown if the ensuing clash resulted in casualties. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea (Somalia).
Sources: "Ahlu Sunna rebels seize control of Central town," Global English (Middle East and North Africa Financial Network), July 30, 2018.

Description: 01/15/2012: An explosive device and grenade attack targeted the Shabelle Valley Administration in Howl Wadaag neighborhood, Beledweyne town, Hiiraan region, Somalia. No casualty information was available. No group claimed responsibility, but sources suspected Ahlu Sunna Wal Jama'a.
LocationDetails: Incident occurred in the Howlwadag village area of the city.
Sources: "Somali forces in central town targeted with explosion attacks," Shabeelle Media Network.net, January 16, 2012.

Description: 04/08/2009: On Wednesday the pro-government, Al Sunnah Wal Jama'a, militia group has captured an American national suspected of having been brought to Somalia, to be a suicide bomber, by the fundamentalist Al Shabaab. According to a statement released by the group, Omar Mohammad Jama, was captured at an unknown location in central Somalia, while traveling from Mogadishu to Hargeysa, where his intended target was.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in central Somalia.
WeaponDetails: It is unknown if weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Somaliweyn WWW-Text, "Alleged Somali American Suicide Bomber Recruit 'Arrested'," World News Connection, Somaliweyn WWW-Text, April 8, 2009.
The Toronto Star, "Canadian Tied to Somalia Plot," LexisNexis Academic, The Toronto Star, April 8, 2009.

Description: 12/28/2008: On Sunday, fighting broke out between the Somali insurgent group al Shabaab and a local militia called Ahlu-Suna in Dhusamareb, Galguded, Somalia. Suna fighters attacked the Shabaab fighters to take back the town, which the al Shabaab militants had gained control of. One Shabaab figher was killed. There was no reported damage.
SpecificDescription1: The targets were al Shabaab militants.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: Agence France Presse, "Somalia: 'Intense' Fighting Between Al-Shabaab, Local Militia Kills One," World News Connection, Agence France Presse, December 28th, 2008.
Agence France Presse, "Somalia: Al-Shabaab, Militia 28 Dec Fighting Over Central Region Town Kills Five," World News Connection, Agence France Presse, December 28th, 2008.

Description: 12/27/2008:  On Saturday, a local Islamic fundamentalist militia, Ahlu-sunah Wal-jamea, attacked Al Shabbab fighters occupying Guriel, Galguded.  According to local reports, at least ten people were killed in the fighting, eight of them fighters.  Six people were also wounded when a mortar round fell on the emergency room of the Guriel city hospital.  Al Shabbab fighters were driven from the town, which is now in the control of the local militiamen.
SpecificDescription1: The targets were Al Shabaab fighters.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.  A mortar was used in the attack.

In addition to the assailant, at least 126 people were killed and 55 other people were injured in the blast; the victims included aid workers, Ahrar al-Sham members, and civilians. Description: 02/12/2017: Assailants, including suicide bombers in explosives-laden vehicles, attacked Busra square in Daraa city, Syria. This was one of three related incidents in different Daraa neighborhoods on the same day. At least 23 people, including 15 assailants and six soldiers, were killed and three other people were injured across all three attacks. Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham claimed responsibility for the incidents. Sources also attributed the attacks to Ahrar al-Sham, Jaysh al-Islam (Syria), and the Free Syrian Army.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Busra square.
WeaponDetails: Artillery, mortars, homemade Jahannam cannons, and heavy machine guns were used in the attack.

This was one of seven projectile attacks in different Aleppo neighborhoods on the same day. At least 12 people were killed and 200 others were injured across all seven incidents. At least 35 people, including Syrian Armed Forces (SAF) soldiers and civilians, were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to the Al-Nusrah Front, Ahrar al-Sham, and the Free Syrian Army.

Ajnad al-Sham, Ahrar al-Sham, and Al-Nusrah Front all claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also attributed the attack to the Free Syrian Army.

An unknown number of Russian Armed Forces soldiers were injured in the attack. Ahrar al-Sham, the Shamiya Front, and the Free Idlib Army all claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also attributed the attack to the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL).

In addition to the three bombers, at least 15 people were killed and 100 others were injured across all eight attacks. Several groups, including Al-Nusrah Front, Ahrar al-Sham, the Shamiya Front, Jaish al-Mujahideen (Syria), Ansar al-Din Front, Al-Sham Legion, Authenticity and Development Front, and Ajnad al-Sham, all claimed responsibility for the incident. Description: 11/06/2019: Assailants abducted a Kurdish civilian near Rajo, Afrin district, Aleppo, Syria. The hostage was killed and his body was discovered on February 1, 2020. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Ahrar al-Sharqiya.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Afrin district.
Sources: "Kidnapped businessman 'found dead' in Turkey-held Syrian area," BBC Monitoring, February 2, 2020.

Description: 10/12/2019: Assailants abducted and executed at least nine people along the international highway in Surab Sharqiyah, Raqqah, Syria. Among those executed was Hevrin Khalaf, the Future Syria Party secretary general. Ahrar al-Sharqiya claimed responsibility for the attack and stated, "You Kurds are traitors, all of you in the [PKK] party are operatives." The group later retracted this statement and denied any involvement in the incident.

The group came when the local Aitarak militia pro-Indonesian militia called for help against pro-Independence forces. The Besi Merah Putih attackers shot a man in the chest and split his head open with a cutlass.

Description: 02/08/2010: On Monday, in Bhardaha-3, Saptari District, Nepal, cadres of the Akhil Terai Mukti Morcha detonated a bomb at the residence of Shyam Sundar Shah; wounding his daughter, Parbati (11), and son, Karan (6). The wounded were taken to the Bhardaha sub-health post for treatment. The commander of the group in Saptari, Bishwagit, claimed responsibility over the telephone, saying that Shah had spied against them. Bishwagit further threatened to take physical action against Shah is he did not "mend his ways". However, speaking at a press meet held in Rajbiraj on Sunday, Shah said that Bishwajit had demanded Rs 1 lakh (2147. 31 USD) as donation and was threatened of physical action if he did not pay the donation. No damages were reported in the attack.
SpecificDescription1: The residence of Shyam Sundar Shah was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: Unknown explosives were used in the attack.
Sources: Jane’s Intelligence, “IED Wounds Children in Nepal's Saptari,” Terrorism Watch Report, February 9, 2010.
