Description: 01/24/2006: A bomb exploded on Golestan Road next to the Natural Resources Department in Ahvaz, Khuzestan Province, Iran, injuring an unspecified number of people but causing no deaths. This attack seems to be related to another bomb attack in another location that occurred simultaneously. A group called The Arab Struggle Movement for the Liberation of Ahvaz claimed responsibility for the blasts.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Golestan Road in Ahvaz.
Sources: “Ahvaz Bomb Blasts Kill 9 People, Wound 45; Politicians React,” Mehr News Agency, January 24, 2006.
“German EU Presidency Criticizes Iran’s Execution of 4 Arabs,” Associated Press Worldstream, February 1, 2007.
Usamah Mahdi, “Ahvazi Arab Party Threatens More Attacks on Iranian Establishments, Interests,” Ilaf, January 25, 2006.

Description: 01/24/2006: A bomb exploded on Kianpars Street inside Saman Bank in Ahvaz, Khuzestan Province, Iran, killing at least nine people and wounding 15 others. There was presumably property damage as well, though the extent of it was not reported. This attack seems to be related to another bomb attack in another location that occurred simultaneously. A group called The Arab Struggle Movement for the Liberation of Ahvaz claimed responsibility for the blasts.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Kianpars Street in Ahvaz.
Sources: “Ahvaz Bomb Blasts Kill 9 People, Wound 45; Politicians React,” Mehr News Agency, January 24, 2006.
“German EU Presidency Criticizes Iran’s Execution of 4 Arabs,” Associated Press Worldstream, February 1, 2007.
Usamah Mahdi, “Ahvazi Arab Party Threatens More Attacks on Iranian Establishments, Interests,” Ilaf, January 25, 2006.

Description: 06/12/2005: On the same day as the bombings in Ahvaz, there were three bombings in Tehran. One person was killed and four were injured in the first bombing, the second caused minor damage to a building, and the third was a stun bomb that caused no casualties or damage. The stun bomb was planted in front of the home of Seyed Taqi Mousavi, a cleric who had survived previous assassination attempts. Authorities blamed a London-based Arab group for the bombings.
SpecificDescription1: residents of the city of Tehran, Iran
SpecificDescription2: cleric in Vahidiyeh district of Tehran
Sources: "Iran:  No Casualties in Further Bomb Blasts in Tehran," IRNA, June 12, 2005.
"Iranian News Agency Says 8 Dead, 74 Injured From Tehran, Ahvaz Bombings," IRNA, June 13, 2005.
"Iran Regime Blames US-Backed Arab Separatists for Pre-Election Bombings," Agence France Presse, June 13, 2005.

Description: 06/12/2005: Four bombings occurred in the city of Ahvaz, Iran in the days leading up to the presidential elections. The Arab Martyrs of Khuzestan, The Arab People's Democratic Front, and The Armed Renaissance Group of Ahvaz all claimed responsibility for the bombings. In addition, Iranian officials blamed US and Britain backed Arab opposition groups. According to official media, as many as 8 were killed and 75 injured, while other sources put the numbers at 6 dead and 90 injured.
SpecificDescription2: residents of the city of Ahvaz, Iran
Sources: "Iranian Officials Blame Groups Outside Iran for Ahvaz Explosions," Iranian Student News Agency, June 12, 2005.
"Iranian Official Says 3 Groups Claim Responsibility for Bomb Attacks in Ahvaz," Iranian Student News Agency, June 13, 2005.
"Iran Regime Blames US-Backed Arab Separatists for Pre-Election Bombings," Agence France Presse, June 13, 2005.

Description: 04/03/2019: Assailants abducted a Sudanese soldier in Mukha district, Taizz, Yemen. The soldier was killed shortly after the abduction. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Amaliqah Brigades.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Yakhtul area.
Sources: "Report Says Sudanese Soldier Kidnapped, Killed by UAE-Affiliated Forces Infiltrated by ISIS in Yemen," Al-Wasat, April 6, 2019.

Description: 04/03/2019: Assailants threw Molotov cocktails and rocks at Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) soldiers in Qalqilya, West Bank. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
WeaponDetails: Molotov cocktails and rocks were used in the attack.
Sources: "Stoning, Firebombing Aimed at IDF in Samaria," Jewish Press, April 3, 2019.

Description: 01/01/2019: An assailant threw a pipe bomb at Israeli soldiers near Yabad, West Bank. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
Sources: "Palestinian Authority Terrorist Bombs IDF Forces," Jewish Press, January 3, 2019.
"Pipe bomb thrown at IDF soldiers in northern West Bank; no injuries," The Times of Israel, January 2, 2019.

Description: 12/25/2018: Assailants threw incendiary devices at a passenger bus driving near Efrat, West Bank. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
WeaponDetails: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
Sources: "Firebombing Attack on Highway 60," Jewish Press, December 25, 2018.
"Watch: Terrorists hurl firebombs at Israeli bus south of J'lem," Arutz Sheva, December 25, 2018.

Description: 06/03/2018: Assailants in Gaza fired projectiles into southern Israel. There were no reported casualties, as the rockets were intercepted by the Iron Dome. This was one of two similar projectile attacks overnight. The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident, and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for the recent killing of a volunteer Palestinian medic.
WeaponDetails: Rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "UPDATE 3-Israel strikes Hamas sites in Gaza after militants fire rockets," Reuters UK, June 2, 2018.
"Indonesia: Israel, Gaza exchange fire after Palestinian nurse killed at border," The Jakarta Post Online, June 2, 2018.
"Israel, Gaza exchange fire after Palestinian...," Dotemirates.com, June 3, 2018.

Description: 06/02/2018: Assailants in Gaza fired two projectiles into southern Israel. There were no reported casualties, as one rocket was intercepted and the other failed to reach Israel. This was one of two similar projectile attacks overnight. The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident, and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for the recent killing of a volunteer Palestinian medic.
WeaponDetails: Mortars were used in the attack.
Sources: "UPDATE 3-Israel strikes Hamas sites in Gaza after militants fire rockets," Reuters UK, June 2, 2018.
"Indonesia: Israel, Gaza exchange fire after Palestinian nurse killed at border," The Jakarta Post Online, June 2, 2018.
"Israel, Gaza exchange fire after Palestinian...," Dotemirates.com, June 3, 2018.

Description: 10/31/2016: An assailant opened fire on an Israel Defense Forces (IDF) checkpoint near Beit El, West Bank. The assailant was killed and three soldiers were injured in the ensuing clash. The Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred near Beit El.
WeaponDetails: An AK-47 assault rifle was used in the attack.
Sources: "Developing: 3 Israelis hurt in West Bank shooting attack near Ramallah," Jerusalem Post, October 31, 2016.
"Three Israelis Wounded in Shooting Attack Near West Bank Settlement," Haaretz, October 31, 2016.
"Palestinian policeman injures 3 Israeli soldiers in West Bank shooting," JTA, October 31, 2016.

Description: 03/14/2016: An assailant rammed his vehicle into an Israeli military vehicle responding to the scene of an earlier attack near Kiryat Arba, West Bank. The assailant was killed and three soldiers were injured in the attack. This was one of two coordinated attacks in the area on the same day. Both the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade and Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) separately claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponType1: Vehicle (not to include vehicle-borne explosives, i.e., car or truck bombs)
Sources: "4 Israeli soldiers injured in 2 West Bank car-ramming and shooting attacks," JTA, March 14, 2016.
"Two Israelis Wounded in Two Car-ramming Attacks Near Hebron," Haaretz, March 14, 2016.
"3 Palestinians carry out shooting, car-ramming attacks, shot dead: army," Yahoo! UK and Ireland, March 14, 2016.

Description: 01/13/2016: The Israeli Air Force opened fire on assailants as they were attempting to plant an explosive device on the border in northern Gaza Strip. At least one assailant was killed and three others were injured in the attack. Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident.
Sources: "IAF attacks terror cell in the northern Gaza," Ynet News, January 14, 2016.

Description: 12/03/2015: An assailant opened fire at the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) Hizma checkpoint in Pisgat Ze'ev neighborhood, Jerusalem, West Bank and Gaza Strip. The assailant was killed and at least two people, including one soldier, were injured in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources identified the assailant, Mazin Hasan Ureiba, as a member of the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Pisgat Ze'ev neighborhood.
Sources: "Israeli injured in stabbing attack near Halamish in Binyamin region," Jerusalem Post, December 4, 2015.
"Israeli police officer hurt in stabbing attack in Jerusalem's Old City," Jerusalem Post, December 3, 2015.
"Palestinian killed after alleged shooting attack near Hizma checkpoint," Ma'an News Agency, December 3, 2015.

Description: 11/06/2015: An assailant stabbed an Israeli citizen outside a supermarket in Shaar Binyamin area, West Bank and Gaza Strip. The victim was wounded in the attack. An individual, Baraa Issa, a member of the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in protection of al-Aqsa Mosque.
Sources: "Israeli seriously wounded in West Bank stabbing attack," Ynet News, November 6, 2015.
"Israeli Wounded in Stabbing Attack Near Jerusalem; Assailant in Attempted Car Ramming Attack Shot," OSC Summary, November 6, 2015.
"Wave of terror October 2015," IMFA, October 14, 2015.

Description: 10/13/2015: Two assailants stabbed and opened fire on passengers on a bus in Jerusalem city, West Bank. At least four people, including one assailant, one dual Israeli-American citizen, and two other civilians, were killed and twelve others, including the second assailant, were wounded in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however sources identified the assailants as Baha Alian, a member of Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, and Bilal Ranem, a member of Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the intersection of Olei Hagardom and Moshe Barazim streets.
WeaponDetails: A knife was used in the attack.
Sources: "Third victim of Armon Hanatziv attack dies," Jerusalem Post, October 27, 2015.
"Breaking: More than 20 wounded in 2 separate terror attacks in Jerusalem," Jerusalem Post, October 13, 2015.
"American-Israeli man dies of wounds from Jerusalem terror attack," JTA, October 27, 2015.

Description: 10/01/2015: Assailants opened fire on a civilian vehicle near Beit Burik village, West Bank and Gaza Strip. A married couple, one of whom was a United States citizen, were killed and one assailant was injured in the attack. The three attackers were later arrested by Israeli forces. The Abd el-Qader el-Husseini Brigade, an affiliate of the Fatah party's armed wing, claimed responsibility for the incident. Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) also claimed responsibility and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for the death of the Dawabsheh family.
Sources: "Israel denies claim Palestinians sent warning of impending shooting attack," Jerusalem Post, October 2, 2015.
"Distressing details revealed in Henkin murder investigation," Ynet News, November 2, 2015.
"Two killed in shooting attack near West Bank settlement," Haaretz, October 1, 2015.

Description: 06/29/2015: Assailants opened fire on a civilian vehicle near Shvut Rachel, West Bank. At least one person was killed and three others were injured in the assault. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP), the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade, and Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) separately claimed responsibility for the attack.
GroupName: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP)
Sources: "Shooting wounds four Israelis near West Bank settlement," Agence France Presse -- English, June 30, 2015.
"Israeli man succumbs to wounds following West Bank shooting," Haaretz, June 30, 2015.
"Terror attack in West Bank: Four Israelis," Ynet News, June 30, 2015.

Description: 06/19/2015: Assailants opened fire on two Israeli civilians near the Dolev settlement, West Bank, West Bank and Gaza Strip. One civilian was killed and the attack and the other was wounded. Hamas (Islamic Resistance Movement) claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out to commemorate the Hamas members involved in the death of three Israeli teens in the West Bank in 2014. The attack was additionally attributed to Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
WeaponDetails: A 9-mm pistol was used in the attack.
Sources: "IDF, Shin Bet scour West Bank for terrorist who shot Israeli dead near Dolev on Friday," Jerusalem Post, June 20, 2015.
"Seven Palestinians Indicted for Involvement in West Bank Killing of 2 Israelis in June 2015," The Jerusalem Post Online, August 17, 2015.
"Israel Bombs Gaza after Rocket Lands in South; Breaks Up Terror Cell," Media Line, July 16, 2015.

Description: 05/03/2015: An assailant attempted to stab an IDF soldier at a checkpoint near Bethlehem city, West Bank, West Bank and Gaza Strip. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
Sources: "IDF Foils Terrorists Attacks near Jewish Community in Samaria," Social Dashboard, May 4, 2015.

Description: 05/03/2015: Assailants attempted to stab Israeli soldiers in Yakir Jewish settlement area, West Bank, West Bank and Gaza Strip. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
Sources: "Jerusalem light rail attacker shot by security guards," JTA, May 4, 2015.
"IDF Foils Terrorists Attacks near Jewish Community in Samaria," Social Dashboard, May 4, 2015.

Description: 04/06/2015: An explosive device detonated near the Hamas Headquarters and a mosque in Sheikh Radwan neighborhood, Gaza city, Gaza Strip. There were no reported casualties in the blast. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources separately attributed the attack to Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade and the Supporters of the Islamic State in Jerusalem.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Sheikh Radwan area.
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
GroupName: Supporters of the Islamic State in Jerusalem
Sources: "Yarmouk Camp Beheadings: Hamas Arrests Prominent Isis Preacher in Gaza," International Business Times India, April 7, 2015.
"Explosive device set off near Gaza mosque," Ma'an News Agency, April 7, 2015.
"Bomb Explodes Near Hamas Headquarters," Israel National News, April 7, 2015.

Description: 12/01/2014: An assailant stabbed an Israeli civilian near Betar Illit city, West Bank, West Bank and Gaza Strip. The civilian and the assailant were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Etzion Gush area near the city.
Sources: "Suspected Palestinian attacker stabs 2 in settlement supermarket, then shot by guard," Reuters, December 3, 2014.
"Suspected Palestinian attacker stabs 2 in settlement supermarket, then shot by guard," Zawya.com, December 4, 2014.
"'Terrorist' Stabs Israelis in 'East Jerusalem Settlement,' Security Guard Shoots Assailant," Ynetnews, December 3, 2014.

Description: 09/20/2013: An assailant abducted Tomer Hazan from Shaare Tikvah town, West Bank, West Bank and Gaza Strip. Hazan, an Israel Defense Forces (IDF) soldier, was killed and his body was discovered in a well near Qalqiliya city on September 21, 2013. Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was intended to show that "the voice of the martyrs is the strongest voice." Nadal Amar, the assailant, also indicated that he carried out the attack in hopes of trading the body of the victim for his imprisoned brother.
Sources: "Israel soldier 'abducted and killed'," BBC, September 21, 2013.
"Israeli soldier killed in West Bank," Al Jazeera Online, September 21, 2013.
"Palestinian kills Israeli soldier in West Bank: army," The Daily Star Online, September 21, 2013.

Description: 1982-04-12: Al-Aqsa-Group operated an attack in Lebanon.
WeaponDetails: Rockets

Description: 11/16/2005: Four people were killed and 45 injured when a car exploded near the Jammu-Kashmir bank in the Lal Chowk area of Srinagar, India. The group Al-Arifeen claimed responsibility for the explosion in a telephone call to the Kashmir News Service.
SpecificDescription1: A Jammu-Kashmir Bank branch in Srinagar
Sources: Shujaat Bukhari, “4 killed, 45 hurt in Srinagar car bomb blast,” The Hindu, November 17, 2005.
“Suicide car bomb kills five, injures 60 in Indian Kashmir,” Agence France Presse, November 16, 2005.
Mujtaba Ali Ahmad, “2 killed, 40 injured in car bomb explosion in Indian Kashmir's capital,” The Associated Press, November 16, 2005.

Description: 04/06/2005: Unidentified assailants attacked a newly inaugurated bus center in India’s Jammu and Kashmir State. Several people were injured in the attack. Al-Nasireen Group, Al-Arifeen, Save Kashmir Movement and Farzandan-e-Millat organizations claimed responsibility for the attack.
SpecificDescription1: The Srinagar and Muzaffarabad Transportation Center
Sources: “Pakistan FM Spokesman Condemns Attack on Kashmir Bus Center,” Agence France Presse, April 6, 2005
“Four groups claim responsibility for Kashmir attack,” PTI News Agency, April 6, 2005.

Description: 04/01/2004: The Al-Arifeen organization claimed responsibility for bombing a government building in Srinagar, India. The device was placed in the restroom of the building and the explosion injured one person. The group claimed that they could have killed more people but this was just a warning for the employees of the corporation not to take part in preparations for countrywide elections during the month of April.
Sources: "Bomb explodes in government building in Indian Kashmir in anti-poll protest," MCN International, April 1, 2004.
"Rebels set off bomb to press for poll boycott in Indian Kashmir," Agence France Presse, April 1, 2004.
"Explosion in government building in Indian portion of Kashmir injures two people," Associated Press, April 1, 2004.

Description: 9/19/2002: Suspected militants shot a National Conference worker in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Azad Ahad Khan was shot from close range and died later in hospital. The group Al-Arifeen claimed responsibility for the incident. The incident occurred during escalated violence leading up to the second round of state elections.
LocationDetails: A street in Srinagar city
SpecificDescription1: Azad Ahad Khan, a National Conference worker
Sources: Sheikh Mushtaq and Terry Friel, "Rally turns violent in Indian Kashmir ahead of vote," Reuters News, September 20, 2002.
Sheikh Mushtaq, "Rebels kill Indian Kashmir ruling party worker," Reuters News, September 20, 2002.

Description: 09/11/2002: Mushtaq Ahmed Lone, the Kashmir Law Minister, was assassinated at an election rally in Kupwara, India, by suspected Islamic militants. Security officials said a militant, clad in a burqa and seated in the segregated women's enclosure, took an AK-47 assault rifle from under his robe and opened fire on Lone as he rose to address the rally. At least two other gunmen in the crowd also opened fire simultaneously, killing the Minister's two bodyguards and wounding the five others, who were standing nearby. All three militants escaped in the ensuing confusion. Lashkar-e-Taiba, Al Barq and Al-Ariseen each claimed responsibility, but the actual party responsible has not been verified.
Sources: Rahul Bedi, "Kashmir Minister Shot Dead at Rally," The Daily Telegraph London, September 12, 2002.
Edna Fernandes, "Kasmir Minister Killed by Gunmen," The Financial Times, September 12, 2002.
Amy Waldman,"Kashmir Increases as Elecion Nears," The New York Times, September 12, 2002.

Description: 01/29/2017: Assailants shot and killed Hisham Hassan Mohammed Al-Hamadi, a police officer, in Bilad al-Qadeem, Capital, Bahrain. Al-Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
Sources: "Cop killer, several others arrested," DT News is Bahrain's, February 22, 2017.
"Bahrain police officer killed in attack claimed by militants," Ynet News, January 29, 2017.
"Policeman shot dead in Bahrain "terrorist" act," Xinhua General News Service, January 29, 2017.

Description: 01/14/2017: Assailants opened fire on a police patrol in Bani Jamra, Northern region, Bahrain. At least one police officer was injured in the attack. Al-Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation to the executions of its members the previous day.
WeaponDetails: Two Kalashnikov rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Two suspected of shooting at police," Gulf Daily News, January 23, 2017.
"Terror group claims responsibility for Bani Jamra shooting," Gulf Daily News, January 16, 2017.

Sources: "Two policemen injured in   blast   near petrol station in Bahrain," Xinhua General News Service, February 1, 2015.

Description: 12/09/2014: An explosive device detonated in Karzakan village, Northern governorate, Bahrain. One civilian was killed and one other person was wounded in the blast. Al Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A remote controlled bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "One killed in Bahrain blast, second bomb in two days," Reuters, December 9, 2014.

Description: 12/08/2014: An explosive device detonated near a police officer in Damistan village, Northern governorate, Bahrain. The police officer was killed in the attack. Al Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident; however, officials attributed the attack to Hezbollah.
WeaponDetails: A homemade bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "A Man and a Policeman Killed by Two Bombs in Different Places of Bahrain," Latin American Herald Tribune, December 10, 2014.

Description: 03/03/2014: An explosive device was discovered and defused in Daih village, Capital governorate, Bahrain. This was one of three coordinated bombings at this site on this day. The Al-Ashtar Brigades and the Popular Resistance Brigade separately claimed responsibility for the attacks.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Budaiya Road in the neighborhood of Daih, Bahrain.
Sources: "Bahrain puts groups on terrorism list after bomb kills three police," Reuters, March 4, 2014.

Description: 03/03/2014: Two explosive devices detonated near police officers at a funeral procession in Daih village, Capital governorate, Bahrain. No casualties were reported in the blasts. This was one of three coordinated bombings at this site on this day. The Al-Ashtar Brigades and the Popular Resistance Brigade separately claimed responsibility for the attacks.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Budaiya Road in the neighborhood of Daih, Bahrain.
WeaponDetails: Two explosive devices were used in the attack.
Sources: "Bahrain puts groups on terrorism list after bomb kills three police," Reuters, March 4, 2014.
"Four blast suspects are remanded," Gulf Daily News, March 10, 2014.
"AL DAIH PLOT WAS MUCH BIGGER," DailyTribune, March 10, 2014.

Description: 03/03/2014: An explosive device detonated near police officers at a funeral procession in Daih village, Capital governorate, Bahrain. The blast killed three officers and injured 11 other people. This was one of three coordinated bombings at this site on this day. The Al-Ashtar Brigades and the Popular Resistance Brigade separately claimed responsibility for the attacks.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Budaiya Road in the neighborhood of Daih, Bahrain.
WeaponDetails: A remote-controlled homemade explosive device was used in the attack.

"Four blast suspects are remanded," Gulf Daily News, March 10, 2014.
"AL DAIH PLOT WAS MUCH BIGGER," DailyTribune, March 10, 2014.

Description: 08/03/2013: A gas cylinder placed inside a vehicle detonated near a recreational area in Budaiya town, Northern governorate, Bahrain. There were no reported casualties in the attack. The Al-Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: A car packed with two gas cylinder bombs (only one detonated) was used in the attack.
Sources: "Car bomb explodes west of Bahraini capital Manama," Reuters, August 3, 2013.
"Jordan condemns car bomb explosion in Bahrain," Jordan Times, August 5, 2013.
"Bahrain car bomb blast," Gulf Times, August 4, 2013.

Description: 07/17/2013: An explosives-laden vehicle detonated outside Shaikh Eisa Bin Salman Mosque in Riffa city, Southern governorate, Bahrain. There were no reported casualties in the explosion. Al Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the attack.
WeaponDetails: A car rigged with explosives was used in the attack.
Sources: "Car bomb explodes outside mosque in Bahrain," Reuters, July 18, 2013.
"BAHRAIN LOSES THREE BRAVE SONS," DailyTribune, March 4, 2014.
"Three car blast suspects arrested," Gulf News, July 21, 2013.

Description: 05/29/2013: A remote-controlled explosive device detonated near police officers removing roadblocks in Bani Jamra village, Northern governorate, Bahrain. Seven officers were injured in the blast. Al-Ashtar Brigades claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: Incident occurred west of Manama
WeaponDetails: A remote-controlled homemade explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: "'Dirty bomb' raises alarm," Gulf Daily News, June 4, 2013.
"Seven policemen injured in blast in Bahrain," Xinhua News Agency, May 30, 2013.
"7 policemen injured in Bahrain blast," Gulf News, May 30, 2013.

Description: 11/05/2020: Assailants attacked a J&K Bank branch in Tak Mohalla, Shopian, Jammu and Kashmir, India. No casualties were reported, though money was stolen in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Badr.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Tak Mohalla area.
Sources: "2 Al-Badr militants killed in encounter with security forces in J-K''s Shopian," Outlook India, November 10, 2020.
"Gunmen loot Rs 60 lakh from J&K Bank cash van in Shopian," Greater Kashmir, November 5, 2020.

Description: 08/19/2020: Assailants abducted Nisar Ahmad Bhat, a Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) panchayat member, in Khanmoh, Shopian, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Bhat was killed and his body was recovered on August 28, 2020. Al-Badr claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the victim, Nisar Ahmad Bhat, had been involved in "anti-movement activities."
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Shopian district.
Sources: "Kashmir: Body found, suspected to be that of missing Panchayat member," Hindustan Times, August 28, 2020.
"Four militants killed in encounter in J-K, one surrenders," Outlook India, August 28, 2020.
"Panch goes missing in South Kashmir," Chandigarh Tribune, August 25, 2020.

Description: 08/02/2020: Assailants abducted Shakir Manzoor in Rambhama village, Kulgam, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Manzoor, an off-duty Army soldier, was found deceased on or before August 9, 2020. Al-Badr claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that Manzoor was killed; however, the fate of Manzoor has not been confirmed by authorities.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Kulgam district.
Sources: "‘Abducted’ soldier’s family protests in Srinagar, seeks his whereabouts," The Hindu, November 11, 2020.
"Kashmir: Body found, suspected to be that of missing Panchayat member," Hindustan Times, August 28, 2020.
"Four militants killed in encounter in J-K, one surrenders," Outlook India, August 28, 2020.

Description: 01/31/2019: Assailants threw a grenade at security personnel in Anantnag, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Seven people, including two Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) soldiers and five civilians, were injured in the blast. Al-Badr claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Sherbagh area of the city.
Sources: "Seven injured in grenade blast in Indian-run Kashmir," Press Trust of India, January 31, 2019.
"India: Al Badr claims responsibility of Anantnag attack," Rising Kashmir Online, February 1, 2019.
"India: J-K: Five civilians, two CRPF jawans injured in grenade attack by militants," The Indian Express Online, January 31, 2019.

SpecificDescription2: Civilians: Abdul Ahad Pinchoo, Manzoor Ahmad Sheikh, Gulzar Ahmad Tanga
Sources: "India: Pulwama: Woman Shot Dead, Elderly Man Dies In Blast," Kashmir Observer Online, August 17, 2018.
"Al-Badr Mujhadeen claims responsibility of Pulwama attack," Greater Kashmir, August 17, 2018.
"Mother of two shot dead in Pulwama village Civilian killed, 3 hurt in Awantipora grenade attack," Premium Official News, August 20, 2018.

Description: 06/04/2018: Assailants threw a grenade at Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) personnel in Tahab, Pulwama, Jammu and Kashmir, India. Seven people, including three civilians and four CRPF officers, were injured in the blast. Jaish-e-Mohammad (JeM) and Al-Badr claimed responsibility for the incident.

Description: 04/03/2008: On Thursday, two police constables, Tariq Ahmad Bhat and Nazir Ahmad Dar, were abducted by Imran Group of Al-Badr Mujahideen militants in Surigam village, Kupwara, Jammu and Kashmir province, India. No claim of responsibility was made for the incident. On 04/04/2008 on Friday, Imran Group of Al-Badr Mujahideen militants killed the two kidnapped police constables by splitting their throats in the Batnoor forest outside Kupwara district, Jammu and Kashmir province, India. Jaish-e-Mohammad claimed responsibility for the killing.
LocationDetails: The hostage attack took place n Surigam village, Kupwara, Jammu and Kashmir province, India while the killing took place in the Batnoor forest outside Kupwara district, Jammu and Kashmir province, India.
SpecificDescription1: Two police constables, Tariq Ahmad Bhat and Nazir Ahmad Dar,
WeaponDetails: An unknown knife (knives) was used in the attack.
Sources: South Asia Terrorism Portal, "Abducted policemen killed by militants in Jammu and Kashmir," http//:wwwsatp.org (accessed April 5, 2008).
Agence France Presse, "Separatist Strike Hits Indian Kashmir as Two Police Slain," Lexis Nexis, Agence France Presse, April 5, 2008.
United News of India, "Bodies of Police Constables Recovered in Kashmir," Lexis Nexis, UNI, April 5, 2008.

Description: 02/24/2005: Two Islamic militants attacked Indian Kashmir’s Administrative Headquarters in Srinagar, India. The perpetrators stormed the complex trapping more than 250 employees inside. Indian police rescued the trapped civilians after two hours of captivity inside the complex. The two perpetrators, three policemen and two civilians were killed in the fighting. Both Al-Mansoorian and Al-Badr claimed responsibility for the attack.
Sources: “Seven killed, 250 civilians rescued in Kashmir suicide attack,” Agence France Presse, February 24, 2005.
“7 dead in Indian-administered Kashmir attack, hundreds rescued,” Xinhua General News, February 24, 2005.

Description: 11/28/2002: Perpetrators fired a rocket at a state-owned radio station, All India Radio, in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, India, damaging some equipment and the exterior of the building. Pro-Pakistan al Badr claimed responsibility for the incident, which claimed no casualties.
SpecificDescription1: State-owned All India Radio station building in Srinagar
WeaponDetails: A rocket was used in the incident.
Sources: "Delhi TV Reports Rocket Attack on Kashmir Radio, Television Stations,” New Delhi Doordarshan DD-1 National Television, November 28, 2002.
Izhar Wani, "Rocket Explosion Rocks Capital of Indian Kashmir, Rebels Kill Three,” Agence France Presse, November 28, 2002.

Description: 07/13/1999: Militants of the Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) group claimed to have entered the residential complex of the Indian Border Security Forces and taken twelve hostages, after killing three officials. All the hostages were freed the next day and the body of one militant was recovered. Despite the claim of responsibility, officials, believed that the Al- Badr group was responsible for the attack.
SpecificDescription1: A Campus of the Border Security Forces in Madar, India
Sources: "All Hostages Rescued,” The Hindu, July 15, 1999.
"BSF Camp Attacked, 12 Taken Hostage,” The Hindu, July 14, 1999.

Description: 02/28/2011: On Monday, in the town of Al-Mahfad, Ataq, Shabwah, Yemen, armed Al-Bakazim tribesmen kidnapped a Tajik doctor, Abdul-Hamidjon Ochilov, who was working for Russian Tekhnostroyeksport Hospital. Authorities claim the kidnappers demanded compensation from the government for the 45 families who were killed by a suspected U.S. airstrike against a supposed Al Qaeda training camp in Al-Majala district of Abyan in late 2009 among other unstated non-monetary demands. No casualties were reported and no group claimed responsibility. As of 03/03/2011, Ochilov was reported to be in good health but still under custody of his kidnappers.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the town of Al-Mahfad, Ataq, Shabwah, Yemen.
SpecificDescription1: Abdul-Hamidjon Ochilov, a Tajik doctor who was working for Russian Tekhnostroyeksport Hospital,
WeaponDetails: Unknown weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: Xinhua News Agency, "Yemeni Armed Tribesman Kidnap Uzbekistani Doctor," Xinhua News Agency, March 1, 2011, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-03/01/c_13754551.htm.
BBC Monitoring, "Yemeni Tribe Abducts Russian Doctor," Factiva, Saba, March 3, 2011.
Times of Central Asia, "Tajik Doctor Kidnapped in Yemen," Factiva, Times of Central Asia, March 2, 2011.

Description: 08/27/2010: On Friday in Ahwar District, Abyan Province, Yemen, two employees of a foreign investment company were kidnapped by members of the al-Bakazim tribe. The victims, who were Turkish and Syrian, were taken to nearby al-Mahfad district in Abyan. The perpetrators demanded the release of one of their members who had been charged with having ties to al Qa'ida.
Sources: "2 Foreigners Kidnapped by Armed Tribesmen in S. Yemen," Xinhua General News Service, August 27, 2010.

Description: 09/15/2009: On Tuesday, in Herat, Herat, Afghanistan, assailants detonated an improvised explosive device planted underneath a bridge and targeting a government vehicle, wounding one government employee and one child and damaging the vehicle and the bridge. Al-Fatah claimed responsibility.

No group claimed responsibility, but it was believed that Fatah was responsible, and the hostage is alive.

Description: 06/20/2008: On Friday, three Israelis were injured when a group of armed Palestinians opened fire on them near the Israeli settlement of Neve Tsof, north of Ramallah, in Palestine's West Bank. WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the firearm attack.

The attack was in retaliation for ongoing Israeli atrocities against Palestinians. No casualties were reported.
WeaponDetails: A homemade projectile was used in the attack.
Sources: Maan News Agency, "Fatah and Hamas Affiliated Brigades Claim Launching Projectiles at Kissufim," Maan News Agency, June 6, 2008.

Description: 10/24/2007: One Israeli soldier and one Israeli civilian were wounded and five cars were damaged when an al-Aqsa Martyrs’ Brigade (Al-Fatah) perpetrator emerged from a parked blue van 150 meters from a bus stop and sprayed the area with small arms (automatic rifle) fire before entering the vehicle again, whereupon it drove away and the shooter fired on five moving vehicles, wounding the civilian. This took place late in the morning near Ariel, West Bank (Occupied Territories), Palestine. The perpetrator was not apprehended.
LocationDetails: At a bus stop near Ariel.

Description: 12/23/2016: Two assailants hijacked an Afriqiyah Airways plane flying from Sabha to Tripoli, Libya. The hijackers diverted the plane to Malta and threatened to detonate explosives if their demands were not met. All 109 passengers and six crew members were safely released and both assailants were arrested when the plane landed at the Malta International Airport. The assailants, Ali Saleh and Moussa Soko, identified themselves as members of Al-Fateh Al-Jadid and stated that the attack was carried out in creation of the new group.
WeaponDetails: A grenade and pistols were used in the attack.
Sources: "Xinhua: 1st LD: Libyan Plane Hijackers Charged With Terrorism At Malta Court," Xinhua, December 25, 2016.
"Libyan plane hijackers surrender in Malta; passengers and crew freed," Trend News Agency, December 24, 2016.
"UPDATE 6-Malta hijack ends peacefully as Gaddafi loyalists surrender," Reuters UK, December 23, 2016.

Sources: Deutsche Presse-Agentur, “Three Iraqi civilians killed in Kirkuk,” January 1, 2008.

Description: 04/22/2015: Assailants fired projectiles that landed and detonated in Jisr al-Shughur, Idlib governorate, Syria. At least seven people were killed in the blasts. Al Furqan Brigades, Ahrar al-Sham, and Al-Nusrah Front all claimed responsibility for the attack.

Description: 05/14/2014: Explosive devices planted in a tunnel detonated underneath the Wadi Al Deif checkpoint in Murrat al-Numan, Idlib governorate, Syria. At least 20 soldiers were killed and an unknown number of soldiers were wounded in the blast. The Islamic Front (Syria), in collaboration with the Al Furqan Brigades, claimed responsibility for the incident.

WeaponDetails: An estimated 60 tons of explosives concealed in a tunnel was used in the attack.

05/10/2001: A putative spokesperson of Al-Hamas Mujahideen called a news agency and claimed responsibility for the grenade attack on Secretary General Maulvi Mohammad Abdullah Tahri of the Democratic Freedom Party. The single grenade exploded outside the offices of the Democratic Freedom Party in Srinagar, India. There were no injuries in the attack.
Sources: Kashmir: Unknown group attacks Shah's party office with grenade; no casualties,” New Delhi Hindustan Times, May 10, 2001.
Hand grenade misses Kashmir separatist leader's office,” Agence France Presse, May 10, 2001.

Description: 04/23/2004: The Saudi group, Al-Haramin Brigades claimed responsibility for a bombing that killed 10 people and wounded 148 more in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. A suicide car bomb exploded outside the headquarters of the Saudi Domestic Security Forces destroying the structure’s façade. The attackers drove their car up to the barrier outside the General Security building and detonated their explosive device as two security guards approached them.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the headquarters of the Saudi Domestic Security Forces.
SpecificDescription1: Saudi Arabian Domestic Security Forces Headquarters in Riyadh
WeaponDetails: A car bomb exploded outside the Saudi Arabian Domestic Security Forces Headquarters building.
Sources: "Saudi Group Claims Responsibility for Riyadh Blast,” Xinhua General News Service, April 22, 2004.
"Suicide Bomb Kills Four At Saudi Police Headquarters,” The Irish Times, April 22, 2004.

Description: 12/29/2003: A parked car belonging to an intelligence officer exploded in Riyadh's Al-Salam neighborhood, in front of his house, causing no injuries in Saudi Arabia. The "Occupied Al-Haramayn Brigades", the "Special Death Brigade", claimed responsibility, warning of further attacks on officers who specialize in counterterrorism.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Al-Salam neighborhood of Riyadh.
SpecificDescription1: Vehicle of an intelligence officer in Riyadh
Sources: Michael Theodoulou, “Saudi Blast Follow Terror Alert,” The Times, December 30, 2003.
“Al-Haramayn Brigades Issues Statement on Attack on Saudi Intelligence Officer,” BBC Monitoring International Reports, December 31, 2003.
“Saudi Car Blast Claimed by Al-Haramayn Brigades-Web Site,” BBC Monitoring International Report, December 31, 2003.

Description: 12/04/2003: The number three official at the Saudi Ministry of the Interior on Counterterrorism, Major General Abdelaziz al-Huweirini, and his brother, were shot in Saudi Arabia. The Saudi government has not disclosed any details on the incident. The group Al Haramain Brigades, has claimed responsibility for the attacks. The Al-Haramayn Brigades took credit for the attack.
EntityName1: Saudi Arabian Ministry of the Interior
Sources: “Tom Saudi Counterterrorism Official Wounded in Assassination Bid: New York Times,” Agence France Presse, December 30, 2003.
Douglas Jehl, “Al Qaeda Links Seen in Attacks on Top Saudi Security Officials,” The New York Times, December 30, 2003

Description: 09/10/2015: An explosive device detonated at Al-Khamis Police Station in Bilad al-Qadeem, Capital governorate, Bahrain. There were no reported casualties in the blast. Al-Haydariyah Battalion claimed responsibility for the incident.
Sources: "Bomb attack on Bahrain police station, no casualties," Arab News, September 11, 2015.
"\'No casualties in Bahrain police station blast': police," Daily Tribune, September 11, 2015.
"Highlights: Gulf Press 11 September 2015," OSC Summary, September 10, 2015.

Description: 03/09/2013: Gunmen kidnapped two members of the Central Security forces in Al Hudaydah Governorate, Yemen. The whereabouts of the victims is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities attributed the abduction to members of the Al-Herak Al-Tihami Movement.
Sources: "Yemen: Roundup of Security Incidents 11 Mar 13," Yemen -- OSC Summary, March 10, 2013.

Description: 08/09/2002: A grenade attack in a Christian hospital in Taxila, 25 kilometers west of Islamabad, Pakistan, killed 2 nurses, one paramedic, one of the attackers, and wounded about 20 others. This attack occurred few days after the attempt on the Murree Christian School, not far from the Capital.
SpecificDescription1: Christian patients in a hospital in Taxila
Sources: “Four dead in grenade attack on Pakistan hospital,” Channel News Asia. August 9, 2002.
“Another Deadly Militant Attack in Pakistan,” CNN, August 9, 2002.
“4 Dead in attack at Christian Hospital,” The Commercial Appeal, August 9, 2002.

Description: 08/05/2002: An organization called al-Intiqamu al-Pakistani claimed the responsibility for the attack on a Christian school in Muree, 40 kilometers northeast of Islamabad. The armed assault caused the death of five people including two guards and a cook; the two other victims were unidentified and may have been students. The terrorist organization said that this attack was a reaction to the massacre of Muslims in Kashmir, Palestine, and Afghanistan. The attempt had been widely condemned among officials and political leaders in Pakistan.
Sources: “Pakistan: New Terror Group Claims Responsibility for Christian School Shooting,” Islamabad Pakistan, August 6, 2002.
“Police Report Gunmen Attack Christian School in Pakistan, Five Dead,” Hong Kong AFP, August 5, 2002.
“Pakistan Daily Condems Terrorist Killings At Christian School,” Islamabad Khabra, August 6, 2002.

Description: 12/11/2020: Assailants attacked a checkpoint in Shuqra, Abyan Governorate, Yemen. Three Yemeni Armed Forces soldiers were abducted from a bus. The outcome of the abduction is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "The Brotherhood militia in Abyan kidnapped 3 soldiers from the Second Military Region," Yemen News, December 12, 2020.

Description: 11/28/2020: Assailants attacked the security escort of Sheikh Fadl al-Khamri, a General People’s Congress (GPC) leader, in Al-Nashma, Taizz, Yemen. Four soldiers were abducted in the attack, and the hostages were released later the same day. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "The kidnappers of the third brigade commander are guards of the Republic crossing from 22 points ... and the Taiz axis is silent," Yemen News, December 1, 2020.

Description: 11/28/2020: Assailants abducted Fadi Al-Barakani, the deputy security director of Mukha, and two other people in Al-Nashma, Taizz, Yemen. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "The kidnappers of the third brigade commander are guards of the Republic crossing from 22 points ... and the Taiz axis is silent," Yemen News, December 1, 2020.

Description: 11/27/2020: Assailants abducted Qaid al-Ward, the Third Brigade military commander, from his residence in Al-Turbah, Taizz, Yemen. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the kidnapping; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "The Brotherhood kidnapped the commander of the Third Brigade, the Republican Guards, from his home," Yemen News, November 28, 2020.

Description: 11/26/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting the convoy of a military commander (Brigadier General Farouq Al-Kaalouli) in Al-Buraiqeh, Adan, Yemen. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "Khaled Salman: The assassinations are the alternative "Brotherhood" plan to topple Aden from within," Yemen News, November 28, 2020.
"A source in the 9th Thunderbolt Brigade to "Newsyemen": The commander survived the palace bombing in the capital, Aden," Yemen News, November 26, 2020.
"Unidentified gunmen kill security officer in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua News Agency, November 26, 2020.

Description: 11/26/2020: Assailants abducted and a short time later killed a Thunderbolt Brigade officer (Jamal Al-Tina Al-Kazami) at the Caltex roundabout in Mansourah neighborhood, Shaykh Uthman, Adan, Yemen. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Caltex roundabout in Mansourah neighborhood.
SpecificDescription1: Thunderbolt Brigade Officer: Jamal Al-Tina Al-Kazami
WeaponDetails: Assault rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Khaled Salman: The assassinations are the alternative "Brotherhood" plan to topple Aden from within," Yemen News, November 28, 2020.
"Unidentified gunmen kill security officer in Yemen's Aden," Xinhua News Agency, November 26, 2020.
"Assassination continues in Aden," Al Sawha, November 26, 2020.

Description: 09/16/2020: Assailants abducted a Giants Brigade member, Abdullah Mubarak Mansour al-Jabwani and a companion in Shabwah, Yemen. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "Shabwa .. Brotherhood authority kidnapped a soldier from the Giants Brigades," Yemen News, September 17, 2020.

Description: 08/20/2020: Assailants bombed the Bayhan camp of the 35th Armored Brigade in Bayhan, Taizz, Yemen. It is unknown whether the attack resulted in any casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
WeaponDetails: Artillery and firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: "The Popular Mobilization Forces in Taiz bombard Al-Jabziya villages in Al-Maafer, causing casualties," Yemen News, August 20, 2020.

Description: 08/20/2020: Assailants attacked Jabal Yumayn, Taizz, Yemen. It is unknown whether the attack resulted in any casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
WeaponDetails: Artillery and firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: "The Popular Mobilization Forces in Taiz bombard Al-Jabziya villages in Al-Maafer, causing casualties," Yemen News, August 20, 2020.

Description: 08/20/2020: Assailants attacked the house of Colonel Abdulhakim al-Jabzi, head of operations of the 35th Armored Brigade, in Harar, Taizz, Yemen. At least three people were killed and several people were wounded, including the wife of Colonel Al-Jabzi. The son of Colonel Al-Jabzi, Aseel Al-Jabzi, was abducted from the residence. He was found executed the next day. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party.
SpecificDescription1: Family of Head of Operations: Colonel Abdulhakim al-Jabzi
WeaponDetails: Artillery and firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: "Taiz .. Brotherhood militias slaughter the son of the commander of operations of the 35th Brigade after storming his house," Yemen News, August 22, 2020.
"Brotherhood militias attack the house of the head of operations of the 35th armored brigade," Yemen News, August 20, 2020.
"The Popular Mobilization Forces in Taiz bombard Al-Jabziya villages in Al-Maafer, causing casualties," Yemen News, August 20, 2020.

Description: 08/12/2020: Assailants abducted a soldier in Ataq, Shabwah, Yemen. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party, noting that the victim was arrested after the assailants saw a picture of the head of the Southern Transitional Council on his phone.
Sources: "Brotherhood militia kidnaps a soldier in Shabwa security," Yemen News, August 22, 2020.

Description: 08/09/2020: Assailants shelled villages near the Security Administration headquarters in Jabal Habashy district, Taizz, Yemen. There were no reported casualties in the attack. This was one of two related attacks in the district on this date. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "Taiz .. Brotherhood militia attack Jabal Hubaishi security administration and bomb villages," Yemen News, August 9, 2020.

Description: 08/09/2020: Assailants attacked the Security Administration headquarters in Jabal Habashy district, Taizz, Yemen. It is unknown whether the attack resulted in any casualties. This was one of two related attacks in the district on this date. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "Taiz .. Brotherhood militia attack Jabal Hubaishi security administration and bomb villages," Yemen News, August 9, 2020.

Description: 08/09/2020: Assailants opened fire on the vehicle of Sheikh Yahya Al-Hajouri in Marib, Yemen. Al-Hajouri, a prominent Salafi figure, was injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah party, which the group denied.
Sources: "He led the first wars against Al-Houthi before Hadi and Ali Mohsen dispersed his groups ... a serious injury to Sheikh Al-Hajouri in Marib," Yemen News, August 10, 2020.

Description: 08/08/2020: Assailants raided a wedding and abducted two civilians in Ataq, Shabwah, Yemen. The outcome of the abduction is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "Brotherhood militia raids a wedding and kidnaps two young men in Shabwa," Yemen News, August 8, 2020.

Description: 08/06/2020: Assailants attacked Colonel Adel al-Hammadi, a member of the 35th Armored Brigade, in Al-Ain, Taizz, Yemen. Hammadi was not harmed, though one soldier was killed and three soldiers were injured in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
SpecificDescription1: 35th Armored Brigade Quartermaster: Colonel Adel al-Hammadi
Sources: "Taiz.. 35-armored brigade supply corner survived an assassination attempt carried out by Brotherhood militias," Yemen News, August 6, 2020.

Description: 07/25/2020: Assailants abducted Salem Muhammad Khamis, a member of the Balabid tribes, near Ataq, Shabwah, Yemen. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Islah Party.
Sources: "Brotherhood militia kidnaps a member of the Balabid tribe in Shabwa," Yemen News, July 26, 2020.

Description: 07/14/2020: Assailants abducted Radwan Al-Hashidi, a journalist, from Seiyun International Airport in Seiyun, Hadramawt, Yemen. The hostage was released on July 28, 2020. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party. Sources also noted that the victim was targeted because of his anti-ISIL views.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at Seiyun Airport.
Sources: "Brotherhood militia kidnapped journalist Radwan Al-Hashidi and sent him to a prison in Marib," Yemen News, July 14, 2020.

Description: 07/13/2020: Assailants abducted five Shabwah Elite Forces members in Ataq, Shabwah, Yemen. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Islah Party.
SpecificDescription1: Members: Saleh Hussein Muhammad Ali, Hamzah Hussain Muhammad Haidrah Al-Khulaifi, Abdullah Hamad Ali Saleh Farid Al-Jabwani
Sources: "Security forces loyal to the Brotherhood kidnapped 5 soldiers of the Shabwana elite," Yemen News, July 13, 2020.

Description: 07/11/2020: Assailants armed with projectiles and firearms attacked Jabal Baiyhan camp in Bayhan, Shabwah, Yemen. There were no reported casualties in the assault. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attacks to the Fourth Brigade, which is affiliated with the Al Islah Party.
Sources: "An officer in the 35th Brigade escapes an assassination attempt in Al-Turbah," Yemen News, July 11, 2020.

Description: 05/03/2005: Suspected members of Al-Ittihad al-Islami (Islamic Unity) and Takfir W’al Hijra bombed a stadium in Mogadishu where Somalian Prime Minister Mohamed Ali Gedi was speaking. The explosion killed 15 people and injured 40 others who were attending the event. No group claimed responsibility for the bombing.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at a stadium in Mogadishu.
SpecificDescription2: Supporters of Prime Minister Mohamed Ali Gedi
Sources: “Fifteen Killed as Bomb Blast Rocks Mogadishu Stadium During Somali PM's Speech,” Agence France Presse, May 03, 2005.
“Security Agents Link Somali Bombing to Groups Associated with Al-Qaeda,” Xinhua General News Service, May 09, 2005.

Description: 03/21/2004: Al-Ittihad al-Islami (Islamic Unity) militants were believed to have opened fire on a vehicle carrying three staff of the German Agency for Technical Assistance (GTZ), killing two and injuring one, near Hargeisa, Woqooyi Galbeed region, Somaliland. Police reported to have arrested five people in connection with the attack.
SpecificDescription1: Aid workers of the German Agency for Technical Assistance (GTZ) group near Hargeisa, Somaliland.
WeaponDetails: The specific gun type used in this incident was not reported.
Sources: “Somaliland blames militant Islamic group for murder of aid workers,” Agence France Presse, March 21, 2004.
“Somaliland accuses Puntland, interim government over killing of aid worker,” HornAfrik Online, March 22, 2004.
“Programme summary of Somaliland's Radio Hargeysa news,” Radio Hargeysa, March 22, 2004.

Description: 11/13/1999: A bomb exploded in the engine of an Ethio-Djibuti Railway Company train traveling from Dire Dawa to Addis Abba, Ethiopia. Two train engineers were killed in the attack and extensive damaged to the train was suffered.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Dire Dawa city
SpecificDescription2: Ethio-Djibuti Railway Company train traveling from Dire Dawa to Addis Abba, Ethiopia
Sources: “Ethiopian Government Statement Reviews 18 Months Of Conflict With Eritrea,” Financial Times Information, November 13, 1999.
“2 Killed In Train Bomb Blast In Ethiopia,” Xinhua General News Service, November 13, 1999.
“2 Killed In Train Bomb Blast In Ethiopia,” Financial Times Information, November 14, 1999.

Description: 1996-01-18: Al-Ittihaad al-Islami (AIAI) operated an attack in Ethiopia.
WeaponDetails: Bomb

Description: 1992-12-17: Al-Ittihaad al-Islami (AIAI) operated an attack in Somalia.
WeaponDetails: Pistol

Description: 1995-11-15: Al-Jehad operated an attack in India.
SpecificDescription1: Khalid Bhasir Mintu, son-in-law of NC leader

Description: 1994-09-16: Al-Jehad Hizbul Mujahideen (HM) operated an attack in India.
SpecificDescription1: Motorcade of Home Minister Mufti Mohammed Sayeed

Description: 1994-07-22: Al-Jehad operated an attack in India.

09/02/2014: Assailants set fire to a Gorbam Private School in Dasht area, Kech district, Balochistan province, Pakistan. There were no reports of casualties in the attack. Al-Jihad (Pakistan) claimed responsibility for the incident, stating that the school was targeted because it provided Pakistani children with Western education.
Sources: "School set on fire in Kech district," Dawn (Pakistan), September 3, 2014.
"Highlights: Pakistan Balochistan Press 4 September 2014," OSC Summary, September 4, 2014.
"Highlights: Pakistan Balochistan Press 3 September 2014," OSC Summary, September 3, 2014.

Description: 03/02/2016: Two explosive devices attached to power transmission tower detonated in Pagangan, Aleosan municipality, North Cotabato, Philippines. There were no reported casualties in the blast and a third device was discovered and defused at the scene. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, authorities suspected that Al-Khobar was involved.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Aleosan municipality.
EntityName1: National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP)
WeaponDetails: Two explosive devices fashioned from 60-mm mortars and a third explosive device were used in the attack.
Sources: "Cops eye extortion, ROW claim issue as motive in NGCP tower bombing," Philippines News Agency, March 5, 2016.
"NGCP tower bombed anew," Manila Times (Philippines), March 3, 2016.
"Philippines: Blast hits NGCP tower in Cotabato, causes brownout," GMA News Online, March 2, 2016.

Description: 10/09/2015: An explosive device detonated at National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP) transmission tower 45 in Batulawan village, Pikit town, North Cotabato province, Philippines. This was one of two related bombings targeting NGCP transmission towers in Batulawan on the same date. There were no reported casualties, although the towers were damaged in the blasts. Additionally, another explosive device was discovered and defused at tower 45 following the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incidents; however, police officials attributed the attacks to Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Movement (BIFM) and Al-Khobar.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Pikit district.
EntityName1: National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP)
WeaponDetails: Several 60-millimeter and 80-millimeter mortar shells were used in the attack.
Sources: "'Al-Khobar' blamed for bombing of NGCP towers in North Cotabato," Philippine Daily Inquirer, October 11, 2015.
"Bombs toppled power towers in S. Philippines," Xinhua General News Service, October 10, 2015.
"Blast topples NGCP transmission towers," Manila Bulletin, October 10, 2015.

Description: 10/09/2015: An explosive device detonated at National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP) transmission tower 44 in Batulawan village, Pikit town, North Cotabato province, Philippines. This was one of two related bombings targeting NGCP transmission towers in Batulawan on the same date. There were no reported casualties, although the towers were damaged in the blasts. No group claimed responsibility for the incidents; however, police officials attributed the attacks to Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Movement (BIFM) and Al-Khobar.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Pikit district.
EntityName1: National Grid Corporation of the Philippines (NGCP)
WeaponDetails: Several 60-millimeter and 80-millimeter mortar shells were used in the attack.
Sources: "'Al-Khobar' blamed for bombing of NGCP towers in North Cotabato," Philippine Daily Inquirer, October 11, 2015.
"Bombs toppled power towers in S. Philippines," Xinhua General News Service, October 10, 2015.
"Blast topples NGCP transmission towers," Manila Bulletin, October 10, 2015.

Description: 10/01/2015: An explosive device detonated inside a passenger bus in Polomolok municipality, South Cotabato province, Philippines. At least 18 people were wounded in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Khobar and the Pentagon Kidnap Group.
WeaponDetails: A modified grenade hidden in a bag was used in the attack.
Sources: "PNP tells bus firms not to pick up passengers in between terminals following blast," Philippines News Agency, October 3, 2015.
"Vice mayor survives Basilan roadside bombing; 3 aides killed," Manila Bulletin, October 1, 2015.
"Motorcycle-mounted bomb kills 3, hits convoy of southern Philippine city vice mayor," 570News, October 1, 2015.

Description: 10/10/2014: An explosive device detonated outside of Ondoy's Grocery Store in Libungan town, North Cotabato province, Philippines. Although no one was injured, two vehicles were damaged in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, a source attributed the incident to Al-Khobar.
WeaponDetails: A bomb planted between a hauler track and passenger van was used in the attack.
Sources: "NorCot guv orders speedy probe into twin blasts," Philippines News Agency, October 12, 2014.
"Police eye extortion behind fresh bomb attack in Cotabato," GMA News.tv, October 11, 2014.
"Bomb rocks NorCot town, hurts no one," Philippines News Agency, October 11, 2014.

Description: 03/12/2012: An explosive device detonated at the Tacurong City bus terminal in Tacurong City, Sultan Kudarat province, Philippines. One bus was slightly damaged, but there were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility, and while officials blamed Al-Khobar, sources offered conflicting information on the intended target of the attack.
WeaponDetails: A modified 81mm mortar shell was used in the attack.
Sources: "Military in Mindanao on alert after blast," BusinessWorld, March 14, 2012.

Description: 02/06/2012: An explosive device detonated targeting a bus in Carmen, North Cotabato, Philippines. One person was injured in the explosion. No group claimed responsibility, though authorities believed that the attack may have been part of an Al-Khobar extortion effort.
LocationDetails: Incident occurred in Barangay Cadiis
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "College Student Injured In Roadside Bombing," Manila Bulletin, February 7, 2012.
"Woman wounded in roadside bombing in N. Cotabato," The Philippine Star, February 7, 2012.

Description: 11/15/2010: On Monday morning around 1035, in Carmen, North Cotabato, Philippines, a homemade improvised explosive device, fashioned from a 81 millimeter mortar round, exploded in a bus depot causing an unknown amount of damage. A bus passenger and two other civilians were injured in the blast, one of the injured later died from injuries. About an hour after the incident, a group claiming to be Al Khobar, sent a text message to Senior Inspector Winston Seniel's phone, claiming responsibility for the attack, and warning that more attacks would occur if "protection money" was not paid to the group.
SpecificDescription1: A bus depot was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: Xiong Tong, “Three Hurt as Bomb Explodes in Bus Depot in S Philippines,” Xinhua News Agency, November 15, 2010, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-11/15/c_13607258.htm.
Carlo Agamon, “Al-Khobar Owns up Another Bombing,” LexisNexis Academic, Philippine Daily Inquirer, November 17, 2010.
Williamor Magbanua, “Boy Dead in Bomb Blast,” LexisNexis Academic, Philippine Daily Inquirer, November 16, 2010.

Description: 10/21/2010: On Thursday morning shortly before 1000, on a highway just outside Matalam in North Cotabato, Philippines, a bomb, hidden in a bag placed inside an overhead compartment, exploded in a passenger bus filled with over 50 passengers. Ten were killed and 30 were injured. No group claimed responsibility, but authorities suspected the al-Khobar extortion gang was responsible as the bus company had been targeted for extortion in the past. Five suspects identified as Piko Tnagkulo, Ibrahim Alimanan, alias Siang Ulama, Alex Samal, Yazer Talusiog and Abdulh AlibTalusog, were arrested in connection with the attack, which caused an unknown amount of property damage.
SpecificDescription1: A passenger bus was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: Guardian, “Deadly Bomb Blast Hits Philippines Bus,” Guardian, October 21, 2010, http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/oct/21/deadly-bomb-blast-philippines-bus.
Yang Lina, “Three Bus Bombing Suspects Seized in Philippines,” Xinhua News Agency, October 24, 2010, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-10/24/c_13572477.htm.
Yang Lina, “Philippines Security Forces Arrest Five Suspects in Bus Bombing,” Newspaper Name, October 24, 2010, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-10/24/c_13572875.htm.

Description: 04/04/2009: On Saturday morning at around 1015, six people were hurt, with two in critical conditions, as two bombs exploded inside a bus in Koronadal, South Cotabato, Philippines. The first blast went off just as the bus of Husky Company arrived at the bus depot. The bomb, fashioned from 60-milimeter mortar shell, was left by a woman passenger in a upper compartment behind the driver and detonated it using a cellular phone after she disembarked before the bus reached the depot. A second bomb, hidden in the baggage compartment, went off in the same bus after police finished inspecting the blast scene. No casualties were reported from the second blast. No group claimed responsibility, but Al Khobar was believed to be responsible.
SpecificDescription2: The target was a Husky bus at the bus depot.
WeaponDetails: Two improvised explosive devices were used in the attack.
Sources: Xinhua News Agency, "Double Bombings in South Cotabato," Xinhua News Agency, April 13, 2009.
Xinhua News Agency, "First LD Six Injured in Southern Philippines Bus Bombing," LexisNexis Academic, Xinhua News Agency, April 4, 2009.

Description: 01/06/2009: On Tuesday, a rifle grenade was launched at the 8th Avenue Lodging House in Rizal Avenue, Kabacan, North Cotabato province.  The attack was believed to have been launched by the Red Spider Group, a sub-group of the Al-Khobar Extortion Gang.  No casualties were reported.
WeaponDetails: A grenade was used in the attack.
Sources: Philippine Daily Inquirer, "Cotabato Town Hit by Second Grenade Attack," http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/regions/view/20090107-181898/Cotabato-town-hit-by-2nd-grenade-attack (January 7, 2009).

Description: 09/15/2007: A car bomb wounded a passerby in Cotabato City, Philippines. The Al-Khobar terrorist group was believed to have been responsible for the explosion.
WeaponDetails: The bomb was rigged from a live mortar underneath a hauler truck.
Sources: "Bomb blasts hits 1 in Cotabato City," Philippines News Agency, September 15, 2007.

Description: 03/00/2019: Sometime between March 3, 2019 and March 9, 2019, assailants assaulted Nasir al-Na'as in Al-Khums, Murqub, Libya. Al-Na'as, an House of Representatives member, was injured in the incident. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Al-Khums Revolutionaries' Union.
Sources: "Libya Open Source Highlights: 12 Mar," Summary, March 12, 2019.

Description: 7/2/2000: Members of Al-Ma'unah raided two army installations in Perak state, Malaysia. They stole approximately 100 weapons, including an M-16 with a grenade launcher. 27 members surrendered on July 6, 2000, after being surrounded on a jungle hilltop near Sauk by police and soldiers. The assailants had possession of at least two hostages, who they tortured and killed before they surrendered. It is reported that at least three members managed to escape with the grenade launcher; it was not surrendered. Authorities state that the incident was intended to cause concerns about security in Malaysia.
LocationDetails: Two army installations in Perak state
WeaponDetails: The assailants stole at least 100 weapons, including assault rifles and an M-16 with grenade launcher
Sources: "Weapons gang reportedly attacked targets in capital, Mahathir says," Agence France-Presse, July 19, 2000.
"Islamic cult on mission to bomb Kuala Lumpur: report," Agence France-Presse, July 18, 2000.
"Malaysian leader says Muslim cultists wanted to attack Kuala Lumpur," Associated Press, July 20, 2000.

Description: 7/6/2000: At least three members of Al-Ma'unah attempted to use a grenade launcher in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. There are reports of multiple intended targets, including a temple and a brewery. However, the attack did not succeed; according to authorities, the assailants did not know how to operate the weapon. One man was arrested on July 9th and the grenade launcher was recovered in Kedah state. Authorities state that the incident was intended to cause concerns about security in Malaysia.
LocationDetails: Kuala Lumpur
SpecificDescription1: A Carlsberg brewery in Kuala Lumpur
WeaponDetails: The assailants were armed with an M-16 with grenade launcher and assault rifles
Sources: "Weapons gang reportedly attacked targets in capital, Mahathir says," Agence France-Presse, July 19, 2000.
"Islamic cult on mission to bomb Kuala Lumpur: report," Agence France-Presse, July 18, 2000.
"Malaysian leader says Muslim cultists wanted to attack Kuala Lumpur," Associated Press, July 20, 2000.

Description: 07/29/2014: Assailants abducted Mustafa Abu Shagur in Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. Abu Shagur, a Member of Parliament, was released the same day. Al-Madani Brigade claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the abduction was carried out in retaliation to recent events in Tripoli city.

"Former Libyan deputy PM kidnapped," Xinhua General News Service, July 29, 2014.

Description: 03/19/2008: Islamic militant group Al-Madina [LeT Front] detonated an improvised explosive device on a flyover bridge inside an abandoned police post injuring 24 people in Srinagar, India.

Sources: Izhar Wani “24 hurt in bomb attack in Indian Kashmir: police, doctors,” Agence France Presse, March 19, 2008.
"World - 11 injured in Srinagar as bomb hits main road,” Morning Star, March 20, 2008.

Description: 11/02/2002: In a series of related attacks, Srinagar's police colony was attacked with rifle grenades. Two grenades hit an electric pole and did not cause any damage. No casualties were reported. The al-Madina regiment claimed responsibility for the incident.

Sources: “Congress Party Leader Killed in Terrorist Attack in Kashmir,” New Delhi Aaj Tak Television, November 2, 2002.

Description: 11/02/2002: In a series of related attacks, two perpetrators shot dead a Congress Party leader, two security guards, and a police officer in Srinagar, Kashmir, India. The al-Madina regiment claimed responsibility for the incident.
SpecificDescription1: Congress Party leader Mohammad Sikandar Khan
WeaponDetails: Unspecified guns were used in the incident.
Sources: “Congress Party Leader Killed in Terrorist Attack in Kashmir,” New Delhi Aaj Tak Television, November 2, 2002.
Rana Jawad, “Politician among 24 Killed in Day of Violence in Indian Kashmir,” AFP, November 2, 2002.

Description: 06/23/2002: Two grenades exploded outside of a building housing 500 members of the ruling National Conference party in Sriringar. No one was harmed. The groups Hizb-ul-Mujahidin (HM) and Al-Madina [LeT Front] both claimed responsibility for the attack.

Description: 06/15/2002: Militants with the group Al-Madina [LeT Front] fired two rocket propelled grenades at a building housing the chief minister of Indian Kashmir, Farooq Abdullah. No one was harmed.
SpecificDescription1: The Chief Minister of Indian Kashmir
Sources: Neelesh Misra, “Guerrillas fire grenades in attack on Indian Kashmir's top elected official; shelling kills three,” Associated Press, June 15, 2002.
“Further on Indian Kashmir Chief Minister Escapes Grenade Attack,” Agence Presse France, June 15, 2002.
“Kashmir Chief Minister escapes attempt on life by militants,” New Delhi Doordarshan DD-1 National Television, June 15, 2002.

Description: 10/29/2020: An assailant armed with a knife attacked civilians outside the Notre-Dame de L’Assomption Basilica in Nice, Provence-Alpes-Cote d'Azur, France. Three people were killed in the attack, and the assailant was shot and injured before being arrested by police. Al-Mahdi in Southern Tunisia claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for caricatures of the Prophet Mohammed. The group stated that they provided training for and prepared the assailant, Brahim Aouissaoui. Authorities stated that they found photos linked to the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) on Aouissaoui's phone, along with a recording in which he describes France as "a country of unbelievers." There were also photos of the perpetrator of the attack that killed Samuel Paty on October 16, 2020.
SpecificDescription1: Civilians: Nadine Devillers, Simone Barreto Silva
WeaponDetails: A 12-inch knife was used in the attack.
Sources: "Knife attack in French city Nice leaves one dead, several hurt," Al Jazeera, October 29, 2020.
"Attacker in Nice had a photo on his phone of the the man who beheaded teacher over cartoons," Straits Times, November 13, 2020.
"France raises security alert after 3 killed in Nice," RTE Online, October 29, 2020.

Description: 02/20/2007: Militants opened fire at two paramilitary CRPF [Central Reserve Police Force] personnel in south Kashmir district of Islamabad, Pakistan. Two soldiers were killed. Al-Mansoorian has claimed responsibility for the assault.
SpecificDescription1: Paramilitary CRPF [Central Reserve Police Force] personnel
Sources: “India:  'Militants' Kill 2 CRPF Men, 1 Soldier in Kashmir,” Srinagar Greater Kashmir (Internet Version-WWW) in English, February 21, 2007.

Description: 01/13/2007: Fifteen people, including eight civilians and seven police were injured in three grenade attacks in Srinagar, India. In a call to a local news agency, the attacks were claimed by the group al-Mansoorian.
