Description: 06/07/2016: Assailants attacked Ananda Kumar Ganguly in Koratipara, Jhenaidah district, Khulna, Bangladesh. Ganguly, a Hindu priest, was killed in the assault. The Islamic State in Bangladesh claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the victim was targeted in order to "cleanse Bangladesh from the wrath of polytheism." However, Bangladeshi officials refuted the claim. Sources also attributed the attack to Al-Qaida in the Indian Subcontinent, Jama'atul Mujahideen Bangladesh (JMB), and Jamaat-E-Islami (Bangladesh).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Jhenaidah district
Sources: "Bangladesh: Another Hindu priest murdered," The Daily Star Online, July 1, 2016.
"Islamic State Claims Latest Attack in Bangladesh," VOA News, June 11, 2016.
"Bangladesh identifies leaders behind killings," Straits Times, June 9, 2016.

Description: 06/05/2016: Assailants armed with machetes stabbed and killed a Christian shopkeeper in Bonpara, Rajshahi, Bangladesh. The Islamic State in Bangladesh claimed responsibility for the attack; however, Bangladeshi officials refuted the claim. Sources also attributed the incident to Al-Qaida in the Indian Subcontinent and Jama'atul Mujahideen Bangladesh (JMB).
WeaponDetails: Machetes were used in the attack.
Sources: "Islamic State Claims Latest Attack in Bangladesh," VOA News, June 11, 2016.
"Bangladesh identifies leaders behind killings," Straits Times, June 9, 2016.
"Suspected militants kill wife of Bangladesh anti-terror police officer," Reuters UK, June 5, 2016.

Description: 05/21/2016: Assailants shot and killed two traffic police officers in Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan. Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) claimed responsibility for the incident. However, authorities questioned the veracity of this claim and attributed the attack to Lashkar-e-Jhangvi and also suspected the involvement of Al-Qaida in the Indian Subcontinent.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Ayesha Manzil area of the Gulberg neighborhood.
Sources: "Pakistan: Suspects of Noted Singer Murder Being Tried in Military Court," Dawn Online, July 28, 2017.
"Pakistan: Report Says Police Focusing on Banned Militant Groups for Killing of Police Officers," Dawn Online, May 23, 2016.
"Two traffic cops gunned down in Azizabad," The News International, May 22, 2016.

Description: 04/25/2016: Assailants armed with machetes raided Xulhaz Mannan's apartment in Dhaka, Bangladesh. Mannan, a gay and transgender rights activist and a magazine editor, and his companion were killed and two people were injured in the assault. Al-Qaida in the Indian Subcontinent claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the victims were targeted for promoting LGBT rights. Authorities also arrested an Ansarullah Bangla Team member in connection with the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Kalabagan area of the city
SpecificDescription1: Apartment of Gay Rights Activist: Julhas Mannan
WeaponDetails: Machetes were used in the attack.
Sources: "Islamist Militants Suspected in Killing of Gay Rights Activist in Bangladesh," The New York Times, April 26, 2016.

Description: 04/06/2016: Assailants armed with machetes and firearms attacked Nazimuddin Samad in Dhaka city, Bangladesh. Samad, a blogger, was killed in the attack. Al-Qaida in the Indian Subcontinent claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that Nazimuddin Samad was targeted because the group believed he was an "enemy of Allah." Police officials, however, doubted the veracity of this claim and attributed the attack to the Ansarullah Bangla Team.
WeaponDetails: A firearm and machetes were used in the attack.
Sources: "Bangladesh: Eight suspects identified in Nazim murder," Dhaka Tribune Online, April 21, 2016.
"Bangladesh blames domestic extremists for activist’s murder," Pakistan Today, April 12, 2016.
"India: 'Bangladeshi secular bloggers should 'control' their writings'," Deccan Herald Online, April 11, 2016.

Description: 03/13/2016: Assailants threw an explosive device at a Pakistan Rangers checkpost in Gulshan-e-Iqbal neighborhood, Karachi, Sindh, Pakistan. There were no reported casualties in the blast. This was one of two similar attacks in neighborhoods of Karachi on the same day. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incidents to Al-Qaida in the Indian Subcontinent.

Description: 01/01/2019: A suicide bomber detonated at a police station in Ghadduwah, Sabha, Libya. The assailant was the only reported casualty. This was one of two similar suicide attacks in Ghadwa on the same day. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to both the Fezzan Province of the Islamic State and Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM).

Description: 02/14/2018: An explosive device detonated targeting a military patrol in Negrine, Tebessa, Algeria. At least five soldiers were killed and two soldiers were injured in the blast. Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) claimed responsibility for the attack.

Description: 02/04/2018: Assailants raided Inwelane, Menaka, Mali. At least four people were killed and the residence of an Islamic judge was set on fire during the assault. Additionally, three people were abducted; one hostage was later killed, and the fate of the remaining two hostages is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected the involvement of Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) or the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara (ISGS) in the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred 18 kilometers east of Talataye in the Menaka district.
GroupName: Islamic State in the Greater Sahara (ISGS) (suspected)
Sources: "Four civilians killed in Mali as army imposes traffic restrictions," News24, February 4, 2018.

Description: 12/10/2017: Assailants fired a projectile at a Congress for Justice in the Azawad (CJA) vehicle between Goundam and Douekire in Goudam district, Timbuktu, Mali. At least six people, including CJA members and civilians, were killed and other people were injured in the attack. Two people were also reported missing. Jamaat Nusrat al-Islam wal Muslimin (JNIM) claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources also attributed the attack to Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred between Goundam and Douekire.
EntityName2: Congress for Justice in the Azawad (CJA)
WeaponDetails: A rocket-propelled grenade (RPG) was used in the attack.

Description: 08/31/2017: A suicide bomber armed with an explosives-laden belt and a firearm attacked the Directorate General for National Security in Tiaret, Algeria. In addition to the assailant, two police officers were killed and a third was injured in the attack. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State and Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) issued competing claims of responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden belt was used in the attack.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Islamic State claims suicide bombing at Algeria police HQ," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, August 31, 2017.

Description: 08/13/2017: Two assailants armed with rifles opened fire at the Aziz Istanbul restaurant in Ouagadougou, Centre, Burkina Faso. The assailants held an unknown number of people hostage inside the restaurant for eight hours, before security forces killed both assailants and rescued 40 hostages. In addition to the assailants, at least 19 people were killed and 21 people were injured during the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected that Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) or Ansar al-Islam (Burkina Faso) may have carried out the attack. Ansar al-Islam (Burkina Faso) denied involvement and attributed the incident to Jamaat Nusrat al-Islam wal Muslimin (JNIM).
WeaponDetails: AK-47 assault rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Toll In Burkina Faso Restaurant Attack Hits 19," AFP (World Service), August 19, 2017.
"Burkina Restaurant Attackers 'Came From Mali': Security Source," AFP (World Service), August 16, 2017.
"Burkina Faso attack: At least 18 killed in restaurant," CNN, August 15, 2017.

Description: 01/18/2017: Five suicide bombers detonated an explosives-laden vehicle at a camp housing military and pro-government militia personnel in Gao, Mali. At least 82 people, including the five bombers, were killed and 115 people were injured in the blast. Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was carried out in retaliation for Mali's collaboration with France.
Sources: "Death toll from suicide blast at Mali army base rises," Al Jazeera, January 19, 2017.
"Mali car bomb attack toll rises to 77, French army spokesman says," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, January 19, 2017.
"Mali car bomb 'kills at least 50 people'," BBC, January 18, 2017.

Description: 12/24/2016: Three assailants abducted Sophie Petronin from her home in Gao, Mali. Petronin, a French-Swiss aid worker for Aide Gao, was released on October 8, 2020. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). In addition, on July 1, 2017, Jamaat Nusrat al-Islam wal Muslimin (JNIM) released a proof-of-life video showing the hostage.
Sources: "French aid worker kidnapped in Mali's Gao," Al Jazeera, December 25, 2016.
"Freed hostages returns home, say Mali extremists killed Swiss woman," CBC, October 9, 2020.
"Al-Qaeda in Mali releases video showing 6 foreign hostages alive: SITE," Deccan Herald, July 1, 2017.

Description: 12/18/2016: Assailants attacked civilians in Farach, Timbuktu, Mali. It is unknown whether there were any casualties in the incident. Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) claimed responsibility for the attack. Sources noted that the targets were accused of being spies.
Sources: "Article Says Jihadists in Central, Northern Mali Destroy Schools, Undertake Massive Teen Recruitment," Kibaru, December 13, 2018.

Description: 12/16/2016: Assailants opened fire on a military base in Nassoumbou, Sahel, Burkina Faso. At least 5 assailants and 12 soldiers were killed and an unknown number of people were injured in the assault. Two soldiers were also reported missing. Ansar al-Islam (Burkina Faso) claimed responsibility for the attack. Sources also attributed the incident to the Al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and suspected the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara (ISGS).

Description: 03/18/2009: A suicide bomber , Shamel al-Sanaan, struck a three car convoy using an improvised bomb in  Sanaa. The convoy was carrying a diplomat  from the  South Korean Embassy and two foreign officials from Seoul  sent to Yemen to investigate a bombing earlier in the week that killed four tourists from their country. The convoy was also carrying relatives of the victims of Sunday's attack who were in the country to recover the bodies of those killed in that attack. They were headed to the airport for a flight to return to South Korea when the bomber struck.  The windows of the vehicle were shattered in the blast but no injuries or casualties were reported. Al-Qaeda group claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on a road between the South Korean Embassy and the Sanaa Airport.
SpecificDescription1: The attack targeted a convoy carrying South Korean officials.
WeaponDetails: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: Ahmed Al-Haj, "Suicide bomber hits South Korean convoy in Yemen," Associated Press Online, March 18, 2009.
Japan Economic Newswire, "Blast hits convoy carrying S. Korean bereaved families in Yemen," LexisNexisAcademic. March 18, 2009.
Agence France Presse, "Qaeda claims second Yemen attack on Skoreans," Agence France Presse, April 10, 2009.

Description: 03/15/2009: On Sunday, at 1650, in Shibam, Hadramawt, Yemen, Ali Mohsen Al Ahmad, a suicide bomber detonated his improvised explosive device (IED) vest, killing four South Korean tourists and two Yemeni tour guides, and wounding five civilians (5 South Korean; 3 Yemeni). The attack occurred when the teenage suicide bomber asked the tourists to pose with him for a picture overlooking the hill  near the ancient fortress city of Shibamaâs site knows as the Manhattan of the desert.  Al-Qaida Organization in the Arabian Peninsula claimed responsibility. 12 suspects were arrested by Yemeni authorities.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in the city of Shibam.
SpecificDescription1: Yemeni tour guides were the targets of the attack.
SpecificDescription2: South Korean tourists were the targets of the attack.
WeaponDetails: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: Agence France Presse, "Yemen Bomber Posed for Pics with SKoreans," Agence France Presse, March 17, 2009.
Ahmed AL-Haj, "Yemen Bomber Posed for Pics with SKoreans," Associated Press Worldstream, March 15, 2009.
Agence France Presse, "Qaeda claims second Yemen attack on Skoreans," Agence Presse, March 15,2009.

Description: 10/20/2008: On Monday, a parcel bomb detonated in Sanaa city, San'a province of Yemen, killing Shaykh Mohammad bin Rabeesh Kaalan, security chief for Madghal district. Kaalan received an anonymous phone call from someone who asked him to collect a parcel said to contain security information from a nearby store. A soldier was also wounded by the parcel bomb, which was sent from Sanaa. Al Qaeda was suspected in the attack.
SpecificDescription1: The target was Shaykh Mohammed bin Rabeesh Kaalan, the security chief for the Madghal district.
WeaponDetails: The explosive was a letter bomb.
Sources: Monsters and Critics, "Five Killed, Nine Injured in Attacks in Iraq, October 22, 2008, http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/printer_1438461.php.
Thaindian, "Five Killed in Iraq Violence," October 22, 2008, http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world-news/five-killed-in-iraq-violence_100110442.html.
Voice of Iraq, "Urgent/Civilian Killed, Six Wounded in Two Blasts in Baghdad," October 22, 2008, http://en.aswataliraq.info/?p=101654.

Description: 09/17/2008: On Wednesday, between 0915 and 0930, suspected Al Qaeda militants disguised as security forces detonated two vehicle-borne improvised explosive devices, fired rocket propelled grenades, rockets and firearms on the U.S. Embassy in Sanaa, San'a, Yemen. A suicide bomber also blew himself up at the embassy. Six Yemeni police, four civilians, including an American civilian, and six attackers were killed while six others were wounded in the attack. Nineteen people were arrested in connection with the attack. The Islamic Jihad, a group connected with Al Qaeda in Yemen, claimed responsibility for the attack. The attack occurred at the U.S. Embassy in Sanaa, San'a, Yemen.
SpecificDescription1: The United States Embassy in Yemen
WeaponDetails: Two vehicle-borne improvised explosive devices, a suicide bomber, rocket propelled grenades, rockets and firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: Zain Verjee, Caroline Faraj and Mark Bixler, "Al Qaeda Blamed for U.S. Embassy Attack," Cable News Network, http://www.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/meast/09/17/yemen.blast/index.html.
Ian Black and James Orr, "Yemeni Police Arrest 19 After Deadly Suicide Bomb Attack on US Embassy," Guardian, September 18, 2008.

National Counterterrorism Center, "Six Security Guards, Three Civilians, One Nurse Killed, Three Civilians Wounded in VBIED and Armed Attack by al-Qaida in Yemen in Sanaa, San'a', Yemen," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, September 3, 2009.

Description: 05/30/2008: On Friday, in Adan, 'Adan, Yemen, armed assailants fired two Katyusha rockets at oil refineries and pipelines, causing no injuries or damage.  Al Qaeda Organization in the Arabian Peninsula claimed responsibility.
LocationDetails: At several oil refineries and pipelines in Adan, Yemen.
SpecificDescription1: Armed assailants fired rokcets at oil refineries and pipelines.
WeaponDetails: Two Katyusha rockets were used in the attack,
Sources: Robert F Worth, "Gunman Kills Eight Worshippers at Mosque in Yemen," New York Times, May 31, 2008.

Description: 04/23/2008: On Wednesday, in Say'un, Hadramawt, Yemen, assailants threw three grenades, damaging a police station but causing no injuries.  Al-Qaida claimed responsibility.
SpecificDescription1: A police station was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: Three Grenades were used in the attack.
Sources: Deutsche Presse-Agentur, "Three Blast Rock Police Centre in Easter Yemen, No Casualties," Deutsche Press Agentur, April 22, 2008.
National Counterterrorism Center, "One Police Station Damaged in Grenade Attack by Al-Qaida in Say'un, Hadramawt, Yemen," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, April 23,2008.

Description: 04/14/2008: On Monday, militants thought to be affiliated with Al Qaeda fired two unspecified rockets at the provincial military headquarters in Marib province. The rockets landed in an empty lot causing no casualties.
SpecificDescription1: The provincial military headquarters was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: Two rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: Triton Reports, "Militants Fired Two Unspecified Rockets at the Provincial Military Headquarters," Triton Reports, April 14, 2008.
Hammound Mounassar, Agence France Presse, " Bomb Attack Kills Three Police in Yemen,"  Agence France Presse, LexisNexisAcademic, April 16, 2008.

Description: 04/13/2008: On Sunday, militants thought to be affiliated with Al Qaeda conducted a small arms attack in Marib, Yemen on the vehicle of the local military commander. The driver was killed and four people were injured, the commander was not in the vehicle at the time of the attack.
SpecificDescription1: The vehicle of the local military commander was targeted in the attack.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: Triton Reports, "Militants conducted a small arms attack in Marib on the vehicle of the local military commander," Triton Reports, April 13, 2008.
Hammoud Mounassar, Agence France Presse, "Bomb Attack Kills Three Police in Yemen," LexisNexis Academic, April 16, 2008.

Description: 4/6/2008: On Sunday, Al Qaeda militants fired three rockets on villas housing US oil experts of the Yemen-owned Safer Oil Company in the Al-Hadda neighborhood in Sanaa, San'a, Yemen. There were no reports of casualties. Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack via the Internet.
WeaponDetails: Three rockets were fired at the compound.
Sources: World News Connection, "Al-Qaeda Claims Responsibility for US Oil Company Attack in Yemen," Agence France Presse, April 7, 2008.
Al Jazeera, "Westerners Targeted in Yemen Attack," Al Jazeera, http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2008/04/200861503422767275.html.

Description: 03/18/2008: Al-Qaeda's wing in Yemen, Jund Al-Yemen Brigades, claimed to have fired five (local officials say three) mortar rounds toward but missed the US embassy. Instead they hit a girls school nearby the embassy killing a guard and a schoolgirl and injuring 19 others in downtown Sanaa in the district of Sawan. The US state department said that the terrorists' target was the embassy while local police disagreed. Yemeni police arrested 5 suspects but did not reveal their identities or motive.
Sources: Hamoud Mounasser, “Two killed in Yemen school blasts near US embassy,” Agence France Presse, March 18, 2008.
Ahmed Al-Haj, “5 Arrested in Attack Near US Embassy,” Associated Press online, March 20, 2008.
"Qaeda in Yemen wing says it attacked US embassy: SITE,” Agence France Presse, March 24, 2008

Description: 07/03/2007: Seven Spanish tourists and their 2 Yemeni guides were killed in a suicide car bombing in the Marib Province of Yemen. Al-Qaida has taken responsibility for the attack.
Sources: Thomas Catan, "Spanish tourists killed as suicide bomber strikes in Yemen," The Times, July 3, 2007.
Ian Black, "Tourists killed in car bombing in Yemen," The Guardian, July 3, 2007.
Suicide Bomber Attacks Tourists at Yemen Temple, Killing 9, The New York Times, July 3, 2007.

Description: 10/31/2005: Unidentified gunmen ambushed and killed 12 policemen northeast of Sa’dah City in Yemen. Authorities suspected numerous groups including Al-Qaida, but no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the northwest area of the city.
SpecificDescription1: Policemen stationed northeast of Sa’dah City
Sources: Faysal Mukarram, “Yemen: 12 Policemen Reportedly Killed in Ambush in Sa'dah Governorate,” London Al-Hayah,” London Al-Hayah, October 31, 2005.

Description: 09/29/2010: On Wednesday, in the al-Dawoodiyah village, Sulaymaniyah, As Sulaymaniyah, Iraq, a suspected Al Qaeda suicide bomber was noticed by Kurdish security forces, also known as Asaish, and fired upon him. The suicide bomber was forced to detonate his improvised explosive device constructed into a vest targeting a crowd of security men waiting to get their check, prematurely. Two Kurdish security force members were also wounded. No damages were reported. No group claimed responsibility; however, authorities indicated that al-Qaida Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) was responsible for the attack.
WeaponDetails: An improvised explosive device was used in the attack.
Sources: Xinhua News Agency, "Suicide Bomber Hits Kurdish Security Men in Northern Iraq," Xinhua News Agency, September 29, 2010, http://www.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/middleeast.htm.
Voice of Iraq, "Suicide Bomber from Iran Hits Peshmerga in Qalaa-Diza," http://en.aswataliraq.info/?p=137360 (September 29, 2010).
van Wilgenburg, Wladimir, "Iraqi Kurdistan Hit by First Suicide Bombing in Six Years," Al Monitor, September 30, 2013.

Description: 05/07/2007: A suicide car bomb attack struck the building of a Kurdish regional ministry in the northern city of Arbil, Iraq. The attack killed 19 people and wounded 11 others. No group claimed responsibility for the attack; however, authorities indicated that a group called al Qaida Kurdish Battalions (AQKB) was responsible.
EntityName1: Kurdish Ministries of the Interior and Security
Sources: "Up to 30 Killed, Wounded in Car Bomb Attack in Iraq's Kurdistan," Beijing Xinhua, May 9, 2007.
van Wilgenburg, Wladimir, "Iraqi Kurdistan Hit by First Suicide Bombing in Six Years," Al Monitor, September 30, 2013.

Description: 02/03/2006: Two bombs were hurled at Rashid Agrofood, a rice mill owned by a Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) leader, in the Kushtia (District) of Bangladesh, injuring no one. After the attack, a man claiming to be an organizer for the Al-Qaida network in the Khulna Division claimed responsibility for the attack, as well as another attack that occurred on the same day in which three bombs seriously injured a local BNP leader in Amanatpur village.
GroupName: Al-Qaida Network for Southwestern Khulna Division (suspected)
Sources: “B’desh Ruling Party Leader Injured in Bomb Attack,” Press Trust of India, February 4, 2006
“Al-Qaidah Claims Responsibility for Bangladesh Blast 3 February,” Prothom Alo, February 4, 2006.

Description: 02/03/2006: A local Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) leader was seriously injured in Amanatpur village of the Khulna Division after three bombs were hurled at him. After the attack, a man claiming to be an organizer for the Al-Qaida network in the Khulna Division claimed responsibility for the attack, as well as another attack that occurred on the same day in which two bombs were hurled at Rashid Agrofood, a rice mill owned by a BNP leader.
GroupName: Al-Qaida Network for Southwestern Khulna Division (suspected)
Sources: “B’desh Ruling Party Leader Injured in Bomb Attack,” Press Trust of India, February 4, 2006.
“Al-Qaidah Claims Responsibility for Bangladesh Blast 3 February,” Prothom Alo, February 4, 2006.

Description: 12/14/2005: An Iraqi polling station was unsuccessfully attacked by three individuals with Molotov cocktails in Kista, Sweden. A Swedish group, claiming to be a branch of Al-Qaida, took responsibility for the attack in a letter.
SpecificDescription1: Iraqi Polling station in Kista, Sweden
WeaponDetails: The source mentions Molotov cocktails and police were said to have found bottles filled with what was thought to be gasoline.
GroupName: Al-Qaida Organization for Jihad in Sweden
Sources: “Al-Qaida Group in Sweden Claims Responsibility for Iraqi Polling Station Attack,” Stockholm Dagens Nyheter, December 16, 2005.

Description: 10/21/2014: Assailants fired rockets into Kikla city, Jabal Al Gharbi district, Libya. At least one civilian was killed and four others were wounded in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Sawaiq Brigade and Al-Qaqa Brigade.
WeaponDetails: Grad rockets were used in the attack.
Sources: "Africa Command OSINT Daily 21 October 2014," OSC Summary, October 21, 2014.

Description: 08/19/2014: Assailants launched rockets at Andalus neighborhood, Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. Three people were killed across this and a similar incident in Gargaresh district. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to both Al-Qaqa Brigade and Al-Sawaiq Brigade.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Andalus neighborhood
Sources: "Libyan militia fires rockets into affluent Tripoli districts," The Daily Star Online, August 19, 2014.
"Libya: Open Source Highlights 19 August 2014," OSC Summary, August 18, 2014.
"SOCAFRICA: Libya Incident Tracker: 16 – 22 August 2014," SOCAFRICA, August 16, 2014.

Description: 08/19/2014: Assailants launched rockets at Ghawt al-Sha'al district, Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. The outcome of the attack is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to both Al-Qaqa Brigade and Al-Sawaiq Brigade.
Sources: "Libya: Open Source Highlights 19 August 2014," OSC Summary, August 18, 2014.
"SOCAFRICA: Libya Incident Tracker: 16 – 22 August 2014," SOCAFRICA, August 16, 2014.

Description: 07/20/2014: Assailants abducted Sulayman Zubi in Tripoli city, Libya. Zubi, a General National Congress (GNC) member, was released unharmed on September 9, 2016. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Qaqa Brigade.
Sources: "Hosted Product: Libya Press Review Security Terrorism Arabic Sources September 8, 2016," Libya Foreign and Domestic Affairs Digest, September 8, 2016.
"SOCAFRICA: Libya Incident Tracker: 01-08 August 2014," SOCAFRICA, August 1, 2014.
"Libyan General National Congress member arrested by Al-Qa'qa Battalion," Al-Tadamun Online, July 20, 2014.

Description: 02/06/2014: Assailants attacked army headquarters in Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. No casualties were reported; however, the assailants stole some weapons and property. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, officials attributed the attack to Al-Qaqa Brigade.
Sources: "NFA official claims assassination attempt," Libya Herald, February 7, 2014.
"Libya: attack on army headquarters, premier lands in Malta," ANSAmed, February 7, 2014.
"Gunmen try to storm Libya army command in Tripoli - official," Reuters UK, February 6, 2014.

Description: 08/23/2007: Three Israeli soldiers were injured in clashes with Palestinian gunmen in Ein Beit El Maa, Israel. Abu Ali Mustafa, Al-Qassam and Al-Aqsa brigades have claimed joint responsibility for the attacks.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Ein Beit al-Ma neighborhood of the city.
GroupName: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) (suspected)
Sources: “West Bank: Three Israeli Soldiers Wounded in Clashes with Palestinian militants” Ma’an News Agency.  August 23, 2007.

Description: 1988-11-06: Al-Sa'iqa operated an attack in Lebanon.

Description: 1984-05-29: Al-Sa'iqa (suspected) operated an attack in Cyprus.

Description: 02/14/2015: Assailants kidnapped two National Human Rights Committee officials from Tripoli city, Tripoli district, Libya. The officials were released on February 28, 2015. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the kidnapping to the Al-Saadawi Militia.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Ayn Zarah area of the city.
SpecificDescription1: Officials: Al-Hadi bin Talib, Ali al-Satti

SpecificDescription1: Senor Pedro Manuel Aristegui, 56, spanish ambassador

12/30/2020: Assailants abducted a civilian in Burujed, Galguduud, Somalia. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.

Sources: "Al-Shabab reportedly abducts central Somalia resident," Radio Kulmiye website, December 30, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 30-31 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 31, 2020.

Description: 12/29/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting an ambulance driving towards El Wak Referral Hospital near El Wak, Mandera, Kenya. The assailants then opened fire on the vehicle. One person was killed, two others were injured in the attack, and the vehicle was set on fire. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Kenya: Al-Shabaab kills man, pregnant wife survives," Anadolu Agency (AA), December 31, 2020.
"Kenya: Al-Shabab kills man taking pregnant wife to hospital," ABC News, December 30, 2020.
"Al Shabaab militants attack ambulance ferrying woman in labor, kill husband," KenyanNews.co.ke, December 30, 2020.

Description: 12/29/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting the vehicle of Muhidin Hassan Afrah, a former member of parliament, in Kaaraan, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. Afrah was not harmed, but his bodyguard was killed, and two others were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Kaaraan neighborhood.
EntityName1: Parliament of the Republic of Somalia
SpecificDescription1: Vehicle of Former Member: Muhidin Hassan Afrah
Sources: "Bodyguard of clan elder killed in IED blast in Mogadishu," Hiiraan Online, December 29, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 29-30 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 30, 2020.

Description: 12/28/2020: Assailants attacked an African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) base near Ceel Waaq, Gedo, Somalia. At least one Kenyan soldier was killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Terrorism Digest: 28-29 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 29, 2020.

Description: 12/28/2020: Assailants opened fire on National Intelligence and Security Agency (NISA) members in Bundoyinka, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. At least four NISA members were killed in the attack. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the victims were members of a security force unit that harassed locals.

WeaponDetails: Pistols were used in the attack.
Sources: "How Al-Shabaab finds NISA informants and executes them in Mogadishu," Radio Garowe, December 29, 2020.
"Six killed after their vehicle hit a land mine in Lower Jubba," Hiiraan Online, December 28, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 27-28 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 28, 2020.

Description: 12/28/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a civilian vehicle near Tabda, Lower Juba, Somalia. At least nine civilians were killed, and an unknown number of civilians were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected the involvement of Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Landmine blast kills 9 in Somalia," Anadolu Ajansi, December 29, 2020.
"Seven killed in southern Somalia roadside blast," Radio Kulmiye, December 29, 2020.
"Nine civilians killed in landmine explosion in Southern Somalia," Africa Direct.news, December 29, 2020.

Description: 12/18/2020: Assailants kidnapped Omar Adan Buul, a village chief, in Gumarey, Wajir, Kenya. Buul's head was found on December 21, 2020. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack.
Sources: "Al-Shabaab claims beheading of local chief in Kenya," The Nation Pakistan, December 23, 2020.
"Panic in Wajir as al Shabaab abducts, cuts assistant chief into pieces," Hiiraan Online, December 22, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 26-27 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 27, 2020.

Description: 12/20/2020: An explosive device detonated, and assailants opened fire targeting a police escort convoy along Lamu-Gamba road in Nyongoro, Lango La Simba, Lamu, Kenya. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Lamu-Gamba road.
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "Red alert after Shabaab attack in Lamu," Daily Nation (Kenya), December 21, 2020.
"Armed gang attacks police escort vehicle in Lamu," East African Standard, December 20, 2020.
"Kenyan police officers escape death in roadside blast," Xinhua News Agency, December 20, 2020.

Description: 12/18/2020: Assailants detonated explosive devices targeting a telecommunications mast near Elele, Mandera, Kenya. The attack resulted in an unknown number of casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Kenya says Al-Shabab militants destroy telecom mast in border region," Daily News Egypt, December 18, 2020.

Description: 12/18/2020: A suicide bomber detonated targeting a rally for Prime Minister Mohamed Hussein Roble at Abdullahi Isse Stadium in Galkayo, Mudug, Somalia. In addition to the assailant, at least 21 people were killed, including three senior military officials and a former mayor, and at least 19 people were injured in the blast. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the incident.
SpecificDescription1: Rally of Prime Minister: Mohamed Hussein Roble
SpecificDescription2: Senior Military Officials: General Abdiazis Abdullahi Abdi, Colonel Mukhtar Abdi Aden
WeaponDetails: An explosives-laden vest was used in the attack.
Sources: "Death toll rises to 16 in Somalia suicide bombing," Jordan Times, December 19, 2020.
"Suicide Bomber Kills 10 in Somalia Just Before Scheduled Address by PM," VOA News, December 18, 2020.
"Suicide bombing kills six in central Somalia," News24, December 18, 2020.

Description: 12/14/2020: Assailants attacked a police station in Borehole 11, Mandera, Kenya. There were no reported casualties, but the assailants caused significant damage to the station. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Newly Built Police Station Bombed to the Ground," Kenyans.co.ke, December 15, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 14-15 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 15, 2020.
"‘Al-Shabab’ destroys police station in north-eastern Kenya," BBC Monitoring, December 15, 2020.

Description: 12/13/2020: Assailants attacked Somali National Army (SNA) personnel in Wajid, Bakool, Somalia. The attack was repelled and at least eight assailants were killed in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Somali military says kills 8 Shabab militants," Xinhua General News Service, December 14, 2020.

Description: 12/12/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a Somali military convoy along Abdiqaasim Road, near K-4 junction, Mogadishu, Banaadir, Somalia. There were no reported casualties in the attack. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources suspected the involvement of Al-Shabaab.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred on Abdiqaasim Road in Hodan neighborhood.
WeaponDetails: A roadside bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "Somali Military Convoy Hit By Roadside Bomb in Mogadishu," Shabelle Media Network (Mogadishu), December 12, 2020.

Description: 12/11/2020: Assailants abducted three gold miners in Milho, Sanaag, Somalia. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Laasqoray district
Sources: "Somalia’s Puntland forces launch operation against al-Shabab," Radio Kulmiye website, December 11, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 10-11 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 11, 2020.
"BBCM Africa Watchlist for 11 December," African media, December 11, 2020.

Description: 12/10/2020: Assailants armed with assault rifles attacked Milho, Sanaag, Somalia. The village mayor, Mohamed Jama Aar (Bulbul), and other village officials were abducted in the attack. The outcome of the kidnapping is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Laasqoray district.
WeaponDetails: Assault rifles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Somalia’s Puntland forces launch operation against al-Shabab," Radio Kulmiye website, December 11, 2020.
"BBCM Africa Watchlist for 11 December," African media, December 11, 2020.

Description: 12/10/2020: Assailants publicly executed a man accused of being a sorcerer in Tayeeglow district, Bakool, Somalia. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Terrorism Digest: 10-11 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 11, 2020.

Description: 12/05/2020: Assailants attacked a police station in Sheik Barrow, Mandera, Kenya. The attack resulted in an unknown number of casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the incident to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "Terrorism Digest: 6-7 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 7, 2020.

Description: 12/02/2020: Assailants opened fire on a police patrol base and launched a rocket-propelled grenade at the base’s armory in Fafi, Garissa, Kenya. An unknown number of officers were killed, one officer was wounded, and one other was reported missing. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
WeaponDetails: Rocket-propelled grenades (RPGs) were used in the attack.
Sources: "Al Shabaab Attack In Garissa Police Base Leaves One Cop Dead, Another Injured," KahawaTungu, December 2, 2020.
"Kenya police: Al-shabab militias attack a camp in Mandera," PRObserver.com, December 2, 2020.
"Suspected al Shabaab Militants Attack Garissa Police Base," KenyaNews247.com, December 1, 2020.

Description: 11/30/2020: Assailants attacked a Somali National Army (SNA) base in Bacaadweyn village, Mudug, Somalia. At least 66 people, including four soldiers, 11 civilians, and 51 assailants, were killed and at least six assailants were wounded in the ensuing clash. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
Sources: "At least 51 militants killed in intense clashes with Somali ...," Radio Garowe, December 1, 2020.
"Shabaab raids military base in central Somalia," The Long War Journal, December 1, 2020.
"Militants claim killing 56 soldiers in central Somalia," Calamada website, December 1, 2020.

Description: 11/29/2020: An explosive device detonated targeting a police vehicle in Jabibar, Mandera, Kenya. At least five police officers were injured in the blast. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Shabaab.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred between Jabibar and Rhamu.
WeaponDetails: A roadside landmine was used in the attack.
Sources: "Terrorism Digest: 30 Nov - 1 Dec 20," BBC Monitoring, December 1, 2020.
"Kenya: Military vehicle ambushed by suspected Al-Shabaab militants in Mandera County November 30," GardaWorld, November 30, 2020.
"Roadside blast injures 5 Kenyan police officers in border region," SINA, November 29, 2020.

Description: 09/13/2010: On Monday morning at 0700, in Salmon, Shabwah province, Yemen, militants threw grenades at a pipeline run by the Yemen LNG Company, a liquefied natural gas venture led by French oil giant Total. The blast caused a huge fire and the pipeline was badly damaged but no casualties were reported. Later, authorities found and safely defused unspecified explosives planted near the pipeline. Both the Al Qaeda Organization in the Arabian Peninsula and the Believing Youth / Al Shabab Al Mumin Ma'rib Youth League claimed responsibility.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at a natural gas pipeline in Salman.
WeaponDetails: An unknown number of grenades were used in the attack and unknown explosives were defused.
Sources: Xinhua News Agency, "Al-Qaida Claims Credit for Bombing LNG Pipeline in South Yemen," Xinhua News Agency, November 12, 2010, http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-11/12/c_13604341.htm.

National Counterterrorism Center, "One Gas Pipeline Damaged in Armed Attack in Shabwan, Ad Dali', Yemen," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, January 14, 2011.

Description: 04/22/2010: On Thursday, in the Sa'dah district, Sa'dah province of Yemen, three people were killed during an armed clash at a security checkpoint. Government and local tribal sources claimed that Al-Shabab al-Muminin militants opened fire on security force personnel at the checkpoint and that three militants were killed by retaliatory fire. No group claimed responsibility.
WeaponDetails: Unknown firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: Jane's Intelligence, "Armed Clash Leaves Three Dead in Yemen's Saada," Terrorism Watch Report, April 23, 2010.
Saudi Gazette, "Gunfight Kills Three in Yemen; Violence Threatens Truce," Saudi Gazette, April 22, 2010, http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2010042370204.
Daily Star, "Gunfight Kills Three in Yemen as Violence," LexisNexis Academic, Daily Star, April 23, 2010.

Description: 05/11/2009: On Monday, in the Al Safra district in the Sa'dah governorate in Yemen, three people were killed and four were wounded in an ambush by Believing Youth rebels. The ambush targeted several supporters of the authorities from Al-Asnaj clan. No damage or motive were reported and no group claimed responsibility.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in the Al Safra district in the Sa'dah governorate, Yemen.
WeaponDetails: Unknown weapons were used in the attack.
Sources: BBC Monitoring Middle East, "Yemen's Huthist Rebels Reportedly Preparing For War," Al-Sharq al-Awsat, May 11, 2009.

Description: 05/07/2005: Two gunmen hurled grenades at a bus carrying members of Yemen’s air defense academy, injuring five on board, including three Iraqi military advisers, in the capital of Sanaa, Yemen. Authorities suspected members of the Al-Shabab al-Mu'minin.

Description: 04/25/2005: An unidentified Yemeni military official was the target of a failed assassination attempt in Sana'a, Yemen. The perpetrators threw a grenade at the official’s vehicle which exploded injuring numerous bystanders. Authorities suspected that members of the Believing Youth Organization were behind the attack.

Description: 10/27/2020: Assailants shelled military positions in Tanjara, Hamah, Syria. This was one of seven related attacks targeting military positions throughout the country on this date. At least 12 soldiers were killed and an unknown number of soldiers were injured across all of the attacks. The National Liberation Front (NLF-Syria) claimed responsibility for the incident and stated that the attack was in retaliation for a Russian airstrike that had targeted a Faylaq Al-Sham training camp the previous day. Sources also attributed the attack to Hay'at Tahrir al-Sham.
WeaponDetails: Missiles were used in the attack.
Sources: "Rebels fire 900 shells on gov't positions in northern Syria: monitor," Xinhua General News Service, October 27, 2020.
"Turkish-backed forces unleash large attack in retaliation for devastating Russian strikes," Aysor.am, October 27, 2020.
"Syrian rebels bomb regime positions following Russian airstrike which killed scores of opposition fighters," Al-Araby Al-Jadeed, October 27, 2020.

Description: 04/13/2015: An explosive device planted in a tunnel underneath the Air Force Intelligence Directorate Headquarters detonated in Jamia al-Zayraa neighborhood, Aleppo city, Aleppo governorate, Syria. Description: 06/18/2014: Assailants attacked K.P. Suresh Kumar, the Hindu Munnani general secretary, in Chennai city, Tamil Nadu state, India. Kumar was killed in the assault. At least three members of Al Ummah claimed responsibility for committing the attack.
Sources: "Arrest of 'Al Ummah' men: Focus back on Chennai station blast," Indian Express, August 7, 2014.
"3 suspected Al Ummah men detained for Hindu Munnani leader's murder," Indian Express, August 6, 2014.

Description: 07/19/2013: Assailants attacked V. Ramesh near his residence in Salem city, Tamil Nadu state, India. Ramesh the Tamil Nadu unit general secretary for the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), was hacked to death in the assault. Three members of Al Ummah claimed responsibility for committing the attack.
SpecificDescription1: Tamil Nadu Unit General Secretary: V. Ramesh
Sources: "3 suspected Al Ummah men detained for Hindu Munnani leader's murder," Indian Express, August 6, 2014.
"BJP leader in Tamil Nadu hacked to death, party calls for statewide bandh on July 22," The Times of India, July 20, 2013.

Description: 07/01/2013: Assailants attacked S. Vellaiyappan in Vellore city, Tamil Nadu state, India. Vellaiyappan, the Tamil Nadu State Secretary of Hindu Munnani, was hacked and beaten to death. Three members of Al Ummah claimed responsibility for committing the attack.
Sources: "3 suspected Al Ummah men detained for Hindu Munnani leader's murder," Indian Express, August 6, 2014.
"Hindu Munnani leader murdered," The Hindu, July 2, 2013.

Description: 04/17/2013: An explosives-laden motorbike detonated near a Bharatiya Janata Party office in the Malleshwaram area of Bangalore city, Karnataka state, India. Sixteen people, including eleven police officers, were injured in the incident. No group claimed responsibility for the incident, however police suspect Panna Ismail, a former member of Al Ummah, of parking the motorcycle. Some police also separately attributed the attack to the Indian Mujahideen (IM).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Malleshwaram area.
WeaponDetails: A motorcycle bomb was used in the attack.
Sources: "3 suspected Al Ummah men detained for Hindu Munnani leader's murder," Indian Express, August 6, 2014.
"Al Ummah man planted bomb: Cops," Indian Express, May 6, 2013.
"'IM set off blast to hit BJP leaders'," New Indian Express, April 20, 2013.

Description: 02/14/1998: Thirty-six people were killed and approximately 100 people injured in a series of car bomb explosions in Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu State, southern India. A total of 12 explosions occurred in several parts of the city within about 15 minutes. No one claimed responsibility for the blasts, but members of the militant group Al Ummah were reportedly responsible.
SpecificDescription1: Indian Civilians and property in Coimbatore
WeaponDetails: Time fuse
Sources: “36 killed, 100 injured in car bomb blasts in south India,” Japan Economic Newswire,  February 15, 1998.
“40 Killed, More Than 200 Hurt by Bombs in India,” Los Angeles Times, February 15, 1998.

Description: 06/14/2017: Assailants attacked a civilian residence and abducted Mohammed Ayub near the Kutupalang refugee camp in Ukhia, Chittagong, Bangladesh. At least two people were injured in the initial attack and Ayub was killed on June 25, 2017. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected that Al-Yakin Mujahidin may have been involved.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred near the Kutupalong refugee camp.
WeaponDetails: Machetes were used in the attack.
Sources: "Murders, Masked Men Spook Rohingya in Bangladesh Camps," New York Times, July 14, 2017.

Description: 06/13/2017: Assailants attacked Kutupalang refugee camp in Ukhia, Chittagong, Bangladesh. Two civilians, identified as Ayub Majhi and Mohammad Selim, were abducted in the attack. Selim was killed and his body was discovered on June 18, 2017 and Majhi was killed on an unknown date. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to Al-Yakin Mujahidin.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred at the Kutupalong refugee camp.
WeaponDetails: Machetes were used in the attack.
Sources: "Murders, Masked Men Spook Rohingya in Bangladesh Camps," New York Times, July 14, 2017.
"New Burmese Militant Organization Al-Yaqin Training Rohinygas in Refugee Camps Inside Bangladesh," Dainik Janakantha Online, July 15, 2017.

Description: 10/09/2016: Assailants attacked police officers in Buthidaung, Rakhine, Myanmar. Two police officers and seven assailants were killed and one police officer was reported missing in the ensuing clash. This was one of three coordinated attacks on police posts in the area on this date. Al-Yakin Mujahidin claimed responsibility for the incidents. In addition, a government official also attributed the attacks to the Rohingya Solidarity Organization, though other sources questioned the group's involvement.
WeaponDetails: Explosive devices, rifles, knives, and slingshots firing iron bolts were used in the attack.
Sources: "Nine police dead on Myanmar border," BBC, October 9, 2016.
"Myanmar probes Rohingya Muslim's death in custody during military operation," Reuters India, October 28, 2016.
"Burma: Death toll in Arakan higher that reported: activists," Democratic Voice of Burma Online, October 24, 2016.

Description: 10/09/2016: Assailants attacked a police border patrol camp in Rathedaung, Rakhine, Myanmar. A police officer was killed and two others were injured in the attack. This was one of three coordinated attacks on police posts in the area on this date. Al-Yakin Mujahidin claimed responsibility for the incidents. In addition, a government official also attributed the attacks to the Rohingya Solidarity Organization, though other sources questioned the group's involvement.
WeaponDetails: Explosive devices, rifles, knives, and slingshots firing iron bolts were used in the attack.
Sources: "Nine police dead on Myanmar border," BBC, October 9, 2016.
"Myanmar probes Rohingya Muslim's death in custody during military operation," Reuters India, October 28, 2016.
"Burma: Death toll in Arakan higher that reported: activists," Democratic Voice of Burma Online, October 24, 2016.

Description: 10/09/2016: Assailants attacked a police station in Maungdaw, Rakhine, Myanmar. Six police officers were killed and two others were injured in the attack. This was one of three coordinated attacks on police posts in the area on this date. Al-Yakin Mujahidin claimed responsibility for the incidents. In addition, a government official also attributed the attacks to the Rohingya Solidarity Organization, though other sources questioned the group's involvement.
WeaponDetails: Explosive devices, rifles, knives, and slingshots firing iron bolts were used in the attack.
Sources: "Nine police dead on Myanmar border," BBC, October 9, 2016.
"Myanmar probes Rohingya Muslim's death in custody during military operation," Reuters India, October 28, 2016.
"Burma: Death toll in Arakan higher that reported: activists," Democratic Voice of Burma Online, October 24, 2016.

Description: 01/08/2017: Assailants attacked a National Oil Corporation (NOC) gas pipeline leading to Al-Zawiya Power Plant in Bir Tirfas, Misrata, Libya. There were no reported casualties in the incident. Al-Zawiya Syndicates Council claimed responsibility for the attack and demanded that 90 recently abducted people be released.
Sources: "NOC says shutdown of gas pipeline in Al-Zawiya ‘criminal act’," The Libya Observer, January 11, 2017.
"Hosted Product: Libya Press Review Security Terrorism Arabic Sources January 17, 2017," Libya Foreign and Domestic Affairs Digest, January 17, 2017.
"Libya: Protesters Shut Down Gas Pipeline Feeding az Zawiyah Electricity Plant," Al-Naba Television Online, January 9, 2017.

Description: 10/11/2014: Assailants attacked Operation Dawn forces in Kikla town, Jabal Al Gharbi district, Libya. At least 21 people were killed and 43 others were wounded in the incident. Al-Zintan Revolutionaries' Military Council claimed responsibility for the attack.
WeaponDetails: Shrapnel was used in the attack.
Sources: "23 Killed in Libya as Islamist Militants Battle Rival Militias," New York Times, October 12, 2014.
"Militia Says Libya Western Mountain Towns Uniting To End Kiklah Battle 'Soon'," Al-Jazirah Satellite Channel Television, October 19, 2014.
"Scores killed in clashes in west of Libya's Tripoli," Xinhua News Agency, October 12, 2014.

Description: 08/12/2001: National Liberation Army (Macedonia) and Albanian Liberation Army members attacked a police checkpoint in the village of Ljubanci, near Skopje, Macedonia. No casualties were reported in connection with this incident..
Sources: “Macedonia: Radusa, Ljubanci areas reported quiet following earlier clashes," BBC Monitoring Europe – Political, August 12, 2001.
Brian Denny, “Albanian rebels attack Ljubanci,” Morning Star, August 13, 2001.

Description: 09/24/2003: A Serbian military vehicle was targeted in an attack near the southern village of Dobrosin. Two officers were wounded. The Albanian National Army later claimed responsibility in a message on the group's website.
LocationDetails: Near the village of Dobrosin on the Llucan [Lucane]-Dobrosin road
SpecificDescription1: Army Major Rahman Bandic; Private Vladica Subasic
Sources: "S-M Defense Minister Condemns 'Terrorist Attack' by 'Albanian Extremists'," BETA, September 24, 2003.
"Communiqué 33," Shqiperiaebashkuar [Albanian National Army website], September 26, 2003.
"OSCE Mission Chief 'Strongly' Condemns Attack on S-M Army Near Bujanovac," BETA, September 24, 2003.

Description: 05/17/2003: The underground organization which calls itself the Albanian National Army (ANA) took attacked a Macedonian military facility in the town of Tetovo, Macedonia. In the attack several rocket propelled grenades were fired at the garrison. No casualties were reported in the incident.
SpecificDescription1: A Macedonian Army garrison in Tetovo, Macedonia
WeaponDetails: Several rocket propelled grenades were used in the incident.
Sources: "Underground army responsible for attack on Macedonian garrison," Deutsche Presse-Agentur, May 18, 2003.

Description: 2/14/2003: A bomb exploded at the Basic Court in Struga, Struga municipality, Macedonia. The Albanian National Army (ANA) claimed responsibility for the explosion; they stated that the Skenderbeg special unit placed the device in the courthouse. The press release on their website stated that the attack was in response to the unjustified arrest of Albanians; the ANA claimed that Albanians were being arrested simply because of their origin. Five suspects were detained for questioning; one remained in custody under suspicion of involvement.
LocationDetails: The Basic Court in Struga
Sources: "Albanian National Army Claims Responsibility for Courthouse Blast in Macedonia," MIA News Agency, February 16, 2003
"Macedonian Police Detain One Suspect in Struga Courthouse Blast," SRNA News Agency, February 18, 2003

Description: 08/26/2002: Safet Beluli, Selam Selmai, Bejtulla Ramadani and Alil Uselni of the Albanian National Army (ANA) shot and killed two Macedonian policemen in a drive-by shooting in Gostivar, Macedonia. Ten people were arrested in connection to the attack. Although it was known that the perpetrators were part of the Albanian National Army (ANA), the group never claimed responsibility for the attack.
EntityName1: MPB Internal Affairs Ministry reserve unit
Sources: Jasmina Mironski, “Murder of police stirs fear of unrest in Macedonia," Agence France Presse, August 26, 2002.
“Trial of four ethnic Albanians on terrorism charges begins in Macedonia," Fakti, BBC World Monitoring, December 27, 2002.
“Macedonian police gunned down," CNN.com, August 26, 2002.

Description: 11/17/2001: Albanian perpetrators attacked a police checkpoint near the village of Preljubiste, Macedonia. The Albanian National Army (ANA) claimed responsibility for the incident, which caused no casualties.
LocationDetails: This incident took place near the village of Preljubiste in the vicinity of Tetovo, Macedonia.
SpecificDescription1: Macedonian police officers at a police checkpoint near the village of Preljubiste
WeaponDetails: Automatic weapons and grenades were used in the incident.
Sources: "Macedonia: Police Checkpoint near Tetovo Reportedly Attacked by Albanian Rebels,” BBC Monitoring Europe – Political, November 17, 2001.
"FYROM: Police Checkpoint near Tetovo Reportedly Attacked by Albanian Rebels,” Bijeljina SRNA, November 17, 2001.
Aleksandar Vasovic, "Macedonian Forces, Ethnic Albanian Militants Exchange Fire in Tense Northwest,” Associated Press Worldstream, November 17, 2001.

Description: 08/14/2001: After peacekeepers arrested 16 members of the Albanian National Army (ANA) who were trying to cross the Kosovo-Macedonia border near the Kosovo village of Gorance in Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY), two unidentified men opened fire on the group of Polish and Ukrainian KFOR soldiers. No one was injured in the exchange of fire.
LocationDetails: This incident occurred on the Kosovo-Macedonia Border near Gorance, Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (FRY).
SpecificDescription1: KFOR Patrol near the Kosovo-Macedonia Border
Sources: “Peacekeepers come under fire as Albanian rebels arrested,” Deutsche Presse-Agentur, August 14, 2001.
“NATO-led peacekeepers detain ethnic Albanian rebels,” Associated Press Worldstream, August 14, 2001.
KFOR Troops Shot at After Arresting FYROM Albanian 'Rebels' 13 Aug, Agence France Presse, August 14, 2001.

Description: 1994-08-16: Albatros Commando operated an attack in Argentina.
WeaponDetails: Explosive

Description: 11/22/2007: One person was killed and seven were hurt when a bomb exploded in a shopping mall in the city of Kidapawan in the Philippines’ Cotabato Province. Two suspects were arrested shortly after, but their affiliation was not reported. However, authorities believe the Alcubar group could have been responsible.
Sources: “World News Briefs,” 24 Hours, November 23, 2007.
“One dead, four injured in Kidapawan blast,” Business World, November 23, 2007.
“Kidapawan bombing suspects charged,” Philippines News Agency, November 23, 2007.

Description: 10/15/2016: Assailants attacked two Civil Guard officers and their partners while they were dining in Alsasua, Navarre, Spain. All four victims suffered unspecified injuries in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the incident to the Alde Hemendik Movement.
Sources: "Spain: Arrested Eight People On Charges Of Alleged Terrorism," Eurasia Review, November 15, 2016.
"Alsasua and the streak of shame," elmundo.es, October 19, 2016.

Description: 1990-01-01: Alejo Calatayu operated an attack in Bolivia.
WeaponDetails: Grenade

Description: 1987-05-11: Alejo Calatayu operated an attack in Bolivia.
WeaponDetails: Explosive

Description: 07/11/2016: Assailants armed with projectiles and firearms attacked Bustan al-Zahra neighborhood in Aleppo, Syria. This was one of six projectiles attacks in different areas of Aleppo on the same day. At least eight people were killed and 80 others were wounded across all six assaults. The Aleppo Fatah Operations Room claimed responsibility for the attacks.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Bustan al-Zahra neighborhood in Aleppo city.
WeaponDetails: Artillery and machine guns were used in the attack.
Sources: "Aleppo - Rebels launch fierce assault in Syria's divided Aleppo," AFP (North European Service), July 11, 2016.
"Islamist Factions Launch Missiles in Aleppo, Kill at least 5," Latin American Herald Tribune, July 12, 2016.
"Syrian rebels fight back in Aleppo, recapture key district from regime troops," MyInforms, July 12, 2016.

Description: 07/11/2016: Assailants armed with projectiles and firearms attacked an unknown number of residential neighborhoods in Aleppo, Syria. This was one of six projectiles incidents in different areas of Aleppo on the same day. At least eight people were killed and 80 others were wounded across all six assaults. The Aleppo Fatah Operations Room claimed responsibility for the attacks.

WeaponDetails: Artillery and machine guns were used in the attack.
Sources: "Aleppo - Rebels launch fierce assault in Syria's divided Aleppo," AFP (North European Service), July 11, 2016.
"Syrian rebels fight back in Aleppo, recapture key district from regime troops," MyInforms, July 12, 2016.

Description: 07/21/2015: Assailants fired several rockets at Syrian Armed Forces (SAF) soldiers and militia members in Fuah town, Idlib governorate, Syria. This was one of two related projectile attacks in Idlib on the same day. At least seven soldiers were killed and hundreds of others were injured between the two incidents. The Aleppo Fatah Operations Room claimed responsibility for the attacks. However, sources also attributed the incidents to the Free Syrian Army.
WeaponDetails: Three hundred improvised rockets and mortars were used in this and another similar attack.
Sources: "Rebels rain rockets on Syrian villages," The Gulf Today, July 22, 2015.
"Rebels unlikely to find success in Aleppo," AlMonitor, July 30, 2015.
"Syrian Unrest: Roundup of Opposition, Pan-Arab Reports on Field Incidents 21 July 2015," OSC Summary, July 21, 2015.

Description: 07/21/2015: Assailants fired several rockets at Syrian Armed Forces (SAF) soldiers and militia members in Kafrayah town, Idlib governorate, Syria. This was one of two related projectile attacks in Idlib on the same day. At least seven soldiers were killed and hundreds of others were injured between the two incidents. The Aleppo Fatah Operations Room claimed responsibility for the attacks. However, sources also attributed the incidents to the Free Syrian Army.
WeaponDetails: Three hundred improvised rockets and mortars were used in this and another similar attack.
Sources: "Rebels rain rockets on Syrian villages," The Gulf Today, July 22, 2015.
"Rebels unlikely to find success in Aleppo," AlMonitor, July 30, 2015.
"Syrian Unrest: Roundup of Opposition, Pan-Arab Reports on Field Incidents 21 July 2015," OSC Summary, July 21, 2015.

Description: 07/27/2019: Assailants opened fire inside the home of former Ayungun mayor Edsel Enardecido in Tampocon I, Negros Oriental, Philippines. Enardecido and his cousin were killed in the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected that the attack was carried out by the New People's Army (NPA), which denied involvement. Sources also attributed the attack to the Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB).
Sources: "Burst of Violence Grips Philippine Island, Negros, and Some See Duterte’s Hand," The New York Times, July 29, 2019.
"NPA: Deployment of SAF troops a prelude to martial law," Philippines Daily Inquirer, July 31, 2019.
"CPP slams Negros Oriental killings," Philippines Daily Inquirer, July 27, 2019.

Description: 07/26/2019: Assailants opened fire inside the home of councilor Ramon Jalandoni in Panubigan, Negros Oriental, Philippines. Posadas was killed in the attack. This was one of two attacks on local leaders in Negros Oriental on this date. The New People’s Army (NPA) claimed responsibility for the incident, but later denied involvement. Sources also attributed the attack to the Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB).
WeaponDetails: Long firearms were used in the attack.
Sources: "NPA: Deployment of SAF troops a prelude to martial law," Philippines Daily Inquirer, July 31, 2019.
"Ex-mayor, 3 others shot dead in Negros Oriental," Tempo, July 27, 2019.
"CPP slams Negros Oriental killings," Philippines Daily Inquirer, July 27, 2019.

Description: 12/17/2018: Assailants opened fire on a delivery truck in Caraudan, Iloilo, Philippines. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, source attributed the attack to the New People's Army (NPA) and the Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB).
WeaponDetails: A .45-caliber handgun was used in the attack.
Sources: "Armed men fire  at delivery truck," The Daily Guardian, December 19, 2018.
"Delivery men survive strafing," Panay News, December 18, 2018.

Description: 10/01/2017: Assailants opened fire on civilians fishing along the Bago River in Bagong Silang, Salvador Benedicto, Negros Occidental, Philippines. At least one civilian was killed in the attack. The Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB) claimed responsibility for the attack; however, sources disputed this claim and also suspected the involvement of the New People's Army (NPA).
LocationDetails: The incident occurred along the Bago River, in the Salvador Benedicto district.
SpecificDescription1: Civilians: Mario Dulman, Reynold Selendron, Robert Selendron
Sources: "3 NPA rebels die in clash with RPA-ABB," Philippine Star, October 2, 2017.

Description: 04/24/2012: Assailants opened fire on Henry Arles along the national highway in Manalad, Negros Occidental, Philippines. Arles, a local trial court judge, was killed in the assault. No group claimed responsibility; however, sources attributed the attack to the Alex Boncayao Brigade (ABB).
Sources: "The RPA-ABB: Whatever happened to the 2000 peace agreement?," Manila Times, October 8, 2017.
"Arles murder case hearing in Quezon," Panay News, July 21, 2014.
"Mayor tagged in murder of judge," INQUIRER.net, July 27, 2012.

Description: 02/17/2008: At approximately 1:30 a.m. local time, Phibun Pura, a laborer arbiter, was assassinated in Talisay City, Philippines upon exiting the cockpit of an airplane. He was killed by Edgar Nicor, a/k/a Ka Joshua, who used a .45-caliber pistol who was a member of the Alex Boncayao Brigade. The group, however, claimed that the attack was not sanctioned by them. Nicor was then shot dead by Pura's brother-in-law, Kenneth Tirthdas. The motive was unclear.
Sources: Nanette L. Guadalquiver, “Labor arbiter gunned down in Talisay City,” BusinessWorld, February 19, 2008.
“RPA-ABB says labor arbiter's killing not sanctioned”, Philippines News Agency (PNA), February 21, 2008.

Description: 12/02/1999: Ten Alex Boncayao Brigade members bombed the Shell headquarters in Makati, Philippines. The group commandeered a van and proceeded to drive by the Shell headquarters where they fired a grenade and shot at the building. One guard was injured as a result of the attack.
Sources: “Manila Shell Oil Grenade Attack, Coup Rumor Affect Shares,” Agence France Presse, December 2, 1999.
“Manila Tightens Security After Attack,” Xinhua General News Service, December 2, 1999.
“ABB to Step up Bombing Operation,” The Filipino Express, December 19, 1999.

Description: 01/19/1998: In the second of two related incidents, the Petron Oil Corporation offices in Makati, Philippines, were bombed by the Alex Boncayao Brigade.
SpecificDescription1: Offices of the Petron Oil Corporation
Sources: “Communist Rebel Claims Responsibility for Bomb Explosion,” GMA-7 Radio-Television Arts Network, January 19, 1998.
“Ramos Orders Tightening of Security for Offices, Depots,” GMA-7 Radio-Television Arts Network, January 20, 1998.
Ma. Christina V. Deocadiz, “Oil firm's HQ hit by blast; ERB strafed (... in wake of oil price hike),” BusinessWorld, January 20, 1998.

06/03/2009: On Wednesday, during the late evening, in the Melissia area of Athens, Attiki, Greece, a group of about ten assailants threw Molotov cocktails at a police station, destroying two nearby vehicles and damaging four others but causing no injuries. The group was repulsed by the police station's guard, who fired shots in the air, while the duty officer threw two non-lethal grenades, emitting sound and light. The assailants fled on motorcycles and on foot. Alexandros Grigoropoulos Anarchist Attack Group claimed responsibility.
LocationDetails: The attack took place in the Melissia area of Athens.
WeaponDetails: Molotov cocktails were used in the attack.
Sources: National Counterterrorism Center, "Two Vehicles Destroyed, Three Others Damaged in Incendiary Attack by Alexandros Grigoropoulos Anarchist Attack Group in Athens, Attiki, Greece," Worldwide Incidents Tracking System, November 17, 2009.
Athens News Agency, "Fire-Bomb Attack on Police Station in Melissia," LexisNexis Academic, Athens News Agency, June 4, 2009.

Description: 02/09/2020: A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden vehicle targeting an army unit in Timiaouine, Adrar, Algeria. In addition to the assailant, at least one soldier was killed and six other soldiers were injured in the blast. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Suicide bomber attacks Algerian barracks, killing a soldier-defence ministry," Reuters UK, February 9, 2020.
"Terrorism Digest: 9-10 Feb 20," BBC Monitoring, February 10, 2020.
"Contradictory reports about 'suicide' blast in southern Algeria," BBC Monitoring, February 9, 2020.

Description: 05/31/2017: Assailants opened fire on national gendarmerie personnel in Ben Omar, Blida, Algeria. At least four security personnel were injured in the attack. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Ouled Slama district.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Four soldiers injured in a terrorist attack in Algeria," Xinhua General News Service, June 1, 2017.
"Hosted Product: Algeria Press Review Security Arab Sources June 1, 2017," Algeria Security Digest, June 1, 2017.
"Islamic State Claims Attack on Algerian Patrol, 4 Wounded," DailyMe.Com, June 1, 2017.

Description: 04/19/2017: Security forces identified two suicide bombers in Ibn Badis, Constantine, Algeria. One assailant was arrested while the second assailant detonated, killing only himself. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Algeria Province of the Islamic State.
WeaponDetails: Two explosives-laden belts were used in the attack.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Algerian army kills IS-linked militant, arrests another," Xinhua General News Service, April 19, 2017.
"State PAO: Algiers Media Digest 22-23 April 2017," US Embassy Public Affairs Office, April 23, 2017.
"Hosted Product: Algeria Press Review Security Arab Sources April 20, 2017," Algeria Security Digest, April 20, 2017.

Description: 02/26/2017: Two assailants opened fire on a police station in Boudjenana area, Constantine, Algeria. There were no reported casualties. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources suspected the involvement of the Algeria Province of the Islamic State in the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Boudjenana area.
WeaponDetails: AK-47 assault rifles were used in the attack.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State (suspected)
Sources: "Islamic State attack in Constantine indicates group's intent to revive its campaign in Algeria, despite limited capabilities," IHS Global Insight, February 28, 2017.

Description: 02/26/2017: Security forces identified and opened fire on a suicide bomber targeting a police station in Bab al Kantara area, Constantine, Algeria. The bomber detonated, killing himself and injuring three police officers. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Bab al Kantara area.
WeaponDetails: An explosive device concealed in a bag was used in the attack.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Islamic State claims foiled Algerian bombing," Adnkronos International, Rome, February 27, 2017.
"1 Dead, 3 wounded in Algeria suicide attack," EFE, February 27, 2017.
"3 policemen injured in suicide bomb attack in eastern Algeria," Xinhua News Agency, February 26, 2017.

Description: 10/29/2016: Three assailants shot and killed a police officer in Ziadia area, Constantine, Algeria. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in the Ziadia area of the city, in Constantine district.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "IS claims killing of Algerian police officer," San Francisco Chronicle, October 30, 2016.
"Algeria forces hunt militants after policeman assassinated," Reuters Africa, October 30, 2016.
"Police killed by IS-linked terrorists in eastern Algeria," Xinhua General News Service, October 29, 2016.

Description: 10/08/2016: An explosive device detonated targeting a People's National Army (PNA) convoy near Tamalous, Skikda, Algeria. No casualties were reported in the blast. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Islamic State Announce Start of Algerian Operations," Tunisia Live, October 11, 2016.

Description: 12/18/2015: An explosive device detonated targeting a People's National Army (ANP) convoy in Djebel el-Wahch area, Constantine, Algeria. At least four soldiers were wounded in the blast. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Islamic State claim of attack near Algerian city of Constantine does not yet signal new capability," IHS Global Insight, December 21, 2015.
"IED attack wounds four soldiers in Algeria's Constantine," Jane's, December 29, 2015.
"Algeria Daily Digest December 21, 2015," Algeria Digest, December 21, 2015.

Description: 03/06/2015: Assailants opened fire on a police patrol in Tablat town, Medea province, Algeria. Two police officers were injured in the attack. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Web monitoring report for 20 March 2015," BBC Monitoring, March 20, 2015.
"Algeria Security Daily Digest March 5-11, 2015," Algeria Security Digest, March 11, 2015.

Description: 02/02/2015: Assailants opened fire on two police officers at a checkpoint in Laaijba municipality, Bouira province, Algeria. The officers were killed in the attack. The Algeria Province of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the incident.
WeaponDetails: Kalashnikov assault rifles were used in the attack.
GroupName: Algeria Province of the Islamic State
Sources: "Web monitoring report for 20 March 2015," BBC Monitoring, March 20, 2015.
""  Terrorists  " kill two Algerian officers southeast of country," BBC Monitoring Middle East - Political Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring, February 4, 2015.

WeaponDetails: Incendiary

Description: 09/06/2020: Assailants attacked security outposts in Bihsud, Wardak, Afghanistan. At least two soldiers were injured and another soldier was taken hostage in the attack. The outcome of the abduction is unknown. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to the Alipour militia.
LocationDetails: The incident occurred in Markazi Bihsud district.
Sources: "Afghanistan- Alipour's men ambush Afghan security outpost," Global English (Middle East and North Africa Financial Network), September 6, 2020.
"Alipour’s men abduct, beat policemen in Maidan Wardak," Pajhwok Afghan News, September 6, 2020.
"Alipour's men abduct, beat policemen in Maidan Wardak," Pajhwok Afghan News English, September 6, 2020.

Description: 06/23/2020: Assailants abducted and beat dozens of road construction workers in Bihsud, Wardak, Afghanistan. No group claimed responsibility for the incident; however, sources attributed the attack to a Hazara militia loyal to the Alipour militia.
Sources: "Alipour's men kidnap, beat road workers in Wardak," Pajhwok Afghan News English, June 23, 2020.
"Alipour’s men kidnap, beat road workers in Wardak," Pajhwok Afghan News, June 23, 2020.

Description: 12/05/2018: An explosive device was discovered and defused at a civilian residence in Goreswar, Assam, India. The All (Baksa District) B.F.D.N Sangodan claimed responsibility for the incident. Sources noted that the attack was likely related to an extortion demand.
Sources: "Remote-controlled bomb recovered," Assam Tribune, December 8, 2018.

Description: 12/01/2018: An explosive device detonated on a passenger train in Harisinga, Assam, India. Three people were injured in the blast. The All (Baksa District) B.F.D.N Sangodan claimed responsibility for the incident.
Sources: "Assam: Police confirms bomb blast in Kamakhya-Dekargaon Express trai," Ani News, December 2, 2018.
"ULFA (I) denies role in train blast," ShillongTimes.com, December 2, 2018.
"11 persons injured in Assam train blast," India Today, December 1, 2018.
